111244: Save the placards for another day — take your rage out on something inanimate! Because money, and the insufferably greedy 1% who control it, will soon cease entirely to exist!
111246: ...and live on in immortality! Defy the insidious capitalist agenda with plain hard work, your greatest weapon in this war! Be a cruel taskmaster to yourself! Strive for self-sufficiency!
111248: Young or old, it makes no difference — go to work like the rest of us and receive basic food and clothing in absurd quantities!
111261: All Luxury Need Public Services + Police Stations
111262: Some anarchist defectors are requesting asylum on your island.
111263: The anarchist defectors would like to offer you something as a reward for your kindness.
111264: Increases the productivity of all production buildings.
111266: Increases the amount of workforce in all sessions.
111489: Von Malching, loathsome baron of only the vilest form of liberalism, must be overthrown! He's drilled fear deep into his workers' brains, they need a push — nay, inspiration! — to rise against their oppressor!
111490: Mercier thinks it's time for Von Malching's workers to realise that they have the power to put him in his place. He's tasked you with sneakily delivering some of his most brilliant instigators to Von Malching's shores, so they can spark a revolution.
111491: Slavery is murder. Property is theft. Merchants prance the waters carrying the stolen fruits of the workers' labour, and claim to have the right to cut the hands of those who take back what's rightfully theirs. An enlightened soul would cut *their* hands...
111492: A good friend of mine wrote that "the idea of God is the most decisive negation of human liberty, and necessarily ends in the enslavement of mankind." That church you have is indoctrinating your people into conformism. It is despicable. Many would celebrate you breaking those chains...
111493: There isn't a single church left on this island, I made sure of that. But the preachers... still they creep in our streets, spreading their poisonous creeds. We cannot allow this — it is our moral duty to put an end to this age of obscurantism!
111494: Each individual must participate in the farming of the land: get grime under their nails; learn the gruelling labour that goes into providing for their community. But... not everyone yet equipped to farm the land properly, so the last harvest was not... efficient. It's a learning process, and I will not let them be discouraged by a small inconvenience! Send us some rations — no one needs to know.
111495: I would never dream of taking away people's right to revolt, but honestly, why can't these people understand that it takes time to build a new society? The issues they raise are nothing but a few bumps in the road to our utopia! You should talk some sense into them...
111496: People can be so slow witted! I have commissioned my favourite playwright to enact a play about the heroes of the commune, to hopefully stimulate our people's minds, and open their eyes as to the unlimited benefits of our system. A sugar coating can make the pill easier to swallow, and all that. Take a picture of the theatre goers to inform of the mandatory attendance. I will make sure they all look excited.
111497: The establishment propaganda machine will have you believe that anarchy is violent, chaotic, and unstable, but it is them who abuse violence to amass power and tear down those who defy them. I need to let my people know that they need not fear, for we have built a strong wall of defences to repel the weapons of the capital.
111498: War reminds men of the things that truly matter. It'd be hard even for these simpletons to complain about the petty details with an enemy at our doorstep. They leave me no choice but to fabricate one...
111499: As a leader, I am no ruler — I am a vessel. A vessel for the voice of every individual in this community. I need to hear their true voices, what their minds and hearts are claiming for. They would discuss it more openly with a neutral party. A party like you.
111500: Do not underestimate the dirty tricks the establishment is willing to use to undermine regimes such as ours. They have infiltrated our community, and now they are conspiring to take me down. Find them — I believe they'll be pretending to enjoy culture...
111501: Oh, hello! Apparently some people from our community have arrived at your docks... by mistake. They were meaning to go, er... somewhere else. As they have no means of return, I must ask that you deliver them to us — back to their friends and families, of course.
111502: Decayed traitors, willing to lick the boots of those who stomp on us in exchange for shiny, meaningless trinkets! Wreck them! Make an example out of them!
111504: No sane person can see that many flaws in our perfect utopia. One of my mentors at the Academy of Medicine, Dr. Cotton, discovered mental illness to be but a reflection of untreated infections in the body. My people deserve to be cured. I will require her expertise — and some new tools...
111505: If those separatists have time to dwell on harmful thoughts, it is because they're not working hard enough! Disorders of the mind vanish with every blister you burst for the well-being of your community. Gather my patients, I will ease their minds!
111506: Remember, remember... how their so-called justice has failed and abused us all. A true envoy of justice would blow up the very foundations of that crooked system. And from the smouldering remains, genuine freedom would arise....
111508: Leon and I have stood together ever since we first picketed at the Academy... Could it be him? He contradicts my every decision, second guesses every word I say... It wouldn't be past that wretched Queen to hold my trust in my comrades against me...
111510: The very concept of "property" is in itself an abuse — a usurpation. Simply put: theft. Hugo claims merchants should be the ones paying the price for their crimes.
111511: Religion poisons the minds of individuals into submission, such is the anarchists' conviction. Dr. Mercier hints that many people will be immensely happy if you could get rid of the archaic institution of the Church.
111512: No matter how many churches Hugo razed to the ground, some pious preachers still remain on his island. As Hugo puts it, if you are virtuous, you will help him find them and stop them from pouring their venom.
111513: Hugo established a job rotation so everyone in his community will, at some point, learn what it's like to work in the fields. Unfortunately, many of them are not quite there yet, and they are having some trouble keeping up with the basic demands of the population. Hugo has asked you to deliver some food — all the better if no one ever gets to know it was you who filled up their storerooms...
111514: Sometimes, people can be truly short-sighted. Those who expect immediate results will naturally become agitated at the first sign of any inconvenience. Gently persuade the rioters on Dr. Mercier's island that a few bumps are to be expected on the road to a new society — and they should just learn to keep quiet...
111515: Hugo is fed up with having to explain the benefits of anarchy to his comrades, so he's staging a play at which attendance is mandatory — a play he hopes will spark their interest. Take a picture of the first batch of obligated theatre-goers to announce the event as if it were an exciting occasion.
111516: Dr. Mercier wants to spread the message that his people need not worry about being attacked by capitalist powers, which is why he would like you to take and print a photograph of his solid harbour defences.
111521: Hugo Mercier is having trouble keeping his people in line. He hopes that focusing their energy on a war against a common enemy will distract them from the petty details that have been raising their scepticism, but he needs your help in putting together his charade.
111522: Dr. Hugo Mercier needs to hear the voice of his people in order to be a good leader for them, but he believes they will speak their minds more candidly to you.
111523: Dr. Mercier is certain that there's a group of establishment infiltrators conspiring to overthrow him. He has tasked you with finding them. They might be around one of the few places on Mercier's island that has something to do with entertainment.
111524: A group of people from Mercier's island have appeared at your docks. Never mind them saying that they mean to stay with you — they are a bit disoriented from the swaying of the ship, and need your help to get back home.
111525: A gang of traitors have fled Mercier's island. He has asked you to sink their ship, and help him make an example out of them.
111527: What greater indication of mental illness is there than the inability to recognise the many advantages of anarchy? Dr. Mercier needs some new tools — and the knowledge of his former mentor, Dr. Harriet Cotton — to treat those who dissent against his policies.
111528: More and more people are finding reasons to complain about Dr. Mercier's leadership. He, of course, considers this to be a symptom of their foggy minds. Luckily, he's devised a way to clear them: excruciatingly tough labour.
111529: In an even more eloquent manner than usual, Dr. Hugo Mercier has suggested you install a large volume of gunpowder around the landmark of Her Majesty's justice system: Wormways Prison.
111531: Dr. Hugo Mercier feels it — the prying gaze of his old comrade Leon upon his every move, waiting for the perfect moment to sell him out to the Queen... In order to either confirm or dispel Mercier's doubts, you must follow the man and see what business he is truly up to.
111533: What!? A riot!? No, no, no!! Stay where you are! I will not have this! Make them shut up, you incompetent milksops!!
111535: A brand new script from the revolutionary playwright Umberto Brocht will be premiered in Hugo Mercier's theatres. "It is my brainiest, driest, most didactical script thus far", declared the author about the mandatory cultural event. Preview attendants looked like they tried their very best to enjoy every last bit of entertainment!
111537: Dr. Hugo Mercier has worked on reinforcing his shore's incisors with plenty of metal fillings that will stop cloying capitalists from striking the nerves of his city.
111539: Landslide victory of Dr. Hugo Mercier casts away the fiendish enemies that wish to incarcerate his people within vicious liberalism. Trust towards their selfless leader reaches historical heights, as their profound sense of community strengthens in the face of adversity.
111541: A survey conducted on Dr. Hugo Mercier's island reveals that 100% of its population agrees with every decision their beloved leader makes.
111549: [AssetData([NotificationContext CharacterGUID]) Text] offers you a propaganda quest.
111550: [AssetData([NotificationContext CharacterGUID]) Text] offers you a propaganda quest.
111552: ... and we're almost out of medicam-... Oh! Hello, comrade! Our thoughts on Dr. Hugo? Well, things couldn't be going better! Yes, everything's fine — everything's absolutely perfect. Now, if you'll excuse me...
111553: ... what are we going to do when the cold comes b-...? Shh! Good day, comrade! Dr. Hugo? Yes, yes, he's the greatest leader we could ask for! We have nothing — absolutely nothing — bad to say about him. Adieu.
111554: ... there's only so much left after my children have finished eat- W-wow, you startled me! What was I saying? Oh, never mind... We love Dr. Hugo, yes we do! And my children do too! Yes, yes, very much so! Well, good day.
111555: We aren't conspirators, I swear! My children were hungry — I had to take a bit more than usual! Please, please, don't take us to Dr. Hugo! We can take the next ferry out of here, and you can just pretend you never saw us.
111556: Please, we have children with us! All we wanted was to live in peace. Have pity, please! I will work for you!
111557: It's been a long time, Dr. Cotton. Please, make yourself at home. Yes, this is our first patient. He has already been numbed. So, which molar should I pull out...?
111558: Gunpowder, treason and plot... Such are the charges "Her Majesty" holds against me. Yet I am but a vessel that carries the indignant fire of a nation, on my way to ignite the blast that will demolish their fabricated order.
111559: I see no reason why this gunpowder treason should ever be forgot! May this historical moment provide a blueprint for generations to follow!
111560: In an almost overly dramatic move, Dr. Hugo has set a whole ship on fire as a metaphor for his bombastic leadership. It now falls to you to be its chaperone, on its way to blow Wormways to pieces.
111561: After the theatrical detonation at Wormways Prison, many a prisoner managed to escape from their cells and jump into the water. You can't just leave them to drown!
111574: A fair trade again, Mr. Leon. But I must admit, I am surprised at your colleague, Dr. Mercier. I had imagined an advocate for chaos would be a less reliable supplier. Do give him my compliments.
111575: A simple trade? He must have noticed you and concealed any sign of his betrayal... There must be something in his books that proves he is double-crossing our people! We must dig deeper!
111577: Far from being convinced of Leon's innocence, Dr. Mercier has urged you to go through his old colleague's personal records, both at his workplace and his home, to see if you can find any evidence that would prove him guilty of treason.
111580: My apologies... We've looked everywhere, and there is nothing at all that would lead anyone to believe that Leon is anything but a devoted anarchist and a competent representative of the people...
111581: What exactly are you looking for? Is my Leon in trouble...? But he's the most loyal man in the world! He talks with such passion about how exciting it is to be part of this revolution, hand in hand with his old friend Hugo...!
111583: Lies! Of course he made sure to erase every trace of his treachery! Or are you on his side too!? No? Then prove it! Sneak this into his ship's hold! I will expose the viper at any cost, and save my people from his poison!
111584: Not yet satisfied with the results of your investigation, Dr. Mercier wants you to make sure that there is evidence to incriminate his old friend Leon of conspiring against his regime. Even if you have to create it yourself.
111588: People from every corner of the world have joined our community since we embarked on this endeavour, but we haven't received any newcomers for months now... I have reason to believe the crown are blockading us. Someone must look into this...
111589: The number of people joining Dr. Mercier's utopia has suddenly halted, and he suspects the Queen may be to blame. He needs you to conduct some investigations into this matter.
111590: Help! Please! We were attacked on our way to Dr. Hugo's utopia! Ohh, we worked so hard to build those ships, and now... all of them, burnt to ashes! The attackers, they bore the Crown's sigil! Don't leave us here, I beg you!
111591: Flamethrowers! So that's what that queen has been up to! Well, I guess the apple doesn't fall far from the tree after all. We will have to be very wary of them...
111592: Oh, hello! I merely intended to alert you about Dr. Mercier. He most definitely has a gift with words, but there may be less... consequential content to them than one might imagine. I believe your heart is in the right place, but please... Bear this in mind in future.
111593: We abhor violence, but this abuse from the Crown must be repaid in kind! So many honest lives lost at sea, and their only crime was to believe a better world was possible! Enough! What goes around comes around.
111594: Unable to bear the Queen's pressure any longer, Dr. Mercier has asked you to help him warn her that any harm she does to his people will be returned.
111595: Whyever would you do that!? Attacks...? Well, I can assure you Her Majesty knows absolutely nothing about that! He is manipulating you like he manipulated all those people! Do not fall for it, I sincerely beg of you. Stay loyal to your queen!
111596: You have earned our trust. My trust. Being discreet as you always are, you will have no problem delivering this man to the royal residence unseen. Believe me, it is of the utmost importance.
111597: Dr. Mercier requires you to sneak past Sir Archibald's patrols, and make sure a very enigmatic masked man arrives at High Clarence Hall docks unseen. Where have you seen that mask before...?
111602: The fuse is burning, we must brace for the grand finale! As the royal fleet heads for us, you must decide: are you willing to fight for enlightenment and equality, or will you support centuries of oppression and obscurantism?
111603: After months of tensions between Mercier and the Crown, the conflict is about to reach an armed resolution. You must now choose which side you are on: anarchy or monarchy.
111604: A truly individual thinker! I am so proud of you, comrade! Here — our scientists have developed these explosives. Regrettably, we will very soon be needing them.
111605: Thank you for staying a sane constant throughout this most regrettable affair... Her Majesty didn't want things to come to this, but alas, it seems to be the only way forward now...
111606: The flame has risen, our job is done. Time to report back.
111607: You have spotted a mysterious ship observing the battle from afar. Follow them, and find out what their role was in the events that just unfolded.
111608: Everything went exactly as planned. Now both Mercier and the Queen are weak enough for us to take control. Igne Natura Renovatur! Wait, who are you...? Intruders! They mustn't escape!
111609: It can't be... Were the Pyrphorians manipulating us all from the start? Oh dear... Dr. Mercier really did believe it was us who attacked his people. I must speak to him at once — as much as we disagree, neither of us meant these hostilities.
111610: The... the Pyrphorians...? But... No, it was the Queen...! She hates our utopia — she is a despot and a schemer! Those people must have been under her command all along! Yes.... yes, that's it...
111612: War declared on Dr. Hugo Mercier
111613: Alliance signed with Dr. Hugo Mercier
111614: Peace signed with Dr. Hugo Mercier
111615: Trade Rights signed with Dr. Hugo Mercier
111630: Dr. Hugo Mercier looks down on you for producing alcohol.
111631: Dr. Hugo Mercier hates fur coats.
111633: Dr. Hugo Mercier admires the backbone of cigar makers.
111634: Dr. Hugo Mercier applauds your production of potatoes.
111635: Dr. Hugo Mercier commends you on building framework knitters.
111636: Dr. Hugo Mercier praises you for building a trade union.
111637: Dr. Hugo Mercier detests you for promoting religion.
111647: Dr. Hugo Mercier is disgusted by your police station.
111648: Dr. Hugo Mercier rejoices at the riots happening in your city,
111649: Dr. Hugo Mercier admires you for publishing the truth.
111650: Dr. Hugo Mercier detests you for lying to your citizens.
111651: Dr. Hugo Mercier supports your use of anarchist propaganda.
111679: I am not here to escape domestic dissatisfaction, but to address it. Our nation has lost its pride! But pride can be restored! This place, Trelawney, is the site of my father's great naval victory over our rivals La Corona.
111680: Finding the sunken Sceptre of Capon — the trophy we never claimed for that victory — will remind us of our past glories and restore the people's faith in their monarch.
111681: Dear old Archie has been like a father to me, but had I told him I was coming here, he'd have sent for far too many flowers and servants.
111682: Ever been on a treasure hunt? Mother let me out in the garden on sunny days.
111683: I had rather a stuffy childhood. So being out here, free and incognito, has one feeling pretty giddy.
111684: As this could easily be my last unofficial visit anywhere, I intend to enjoy my freedom.
111685: We share a bloodline, you know. I have as much right to the Sceptre as King João.
111686: The Sceptre of Capon has long granted its bearers indisputable authority. But it sank to the depths, along with La Corona's fleet.
111687: It was father's greatest regret that he was never able to hold the sceptre. I'm sure that insecurity about his position made him cling to power all the more perfervidly.
111688: He may have been on the winning side, but father always said Admiral Nadasky's carelessness had meant the Sceptre being lost to the waves.
111689: We were the victors here at Trelawney, yet all the spoils remain in the lap of Poseidon.
111690: Father's command from up on the cliff, that's what won us the day. Not the actions of the much-trumpeted Admiral Nadasky.
111691: The child that was me played out the battle of Trelawney countless times in the parlour on a miniature campaign table.
111692: I can still smell father's victory here at Trelawney, it is his greatest legacy.
111693: I am curious as to how father was able to relay these instructions so quickly from such a distance.
111694: La Corona wanted to move their national treasures while they still had chance, but the fleet caught them in the act.
111695: The warm southern air makes me feel strong and well. Purposeful, you might say.
111696: I can see it — a brilliant metropolis rising here, from the memory of the victory my father masterminded. A shining new jewel in the crown of my empire.
111697: I see the new settlement is progressing well. The empire needs to develop a lasting presence here in the south.
111698: A humble outpost now, perhaps. But it promises to become the largest capital of my empire!
111699: It's obvious why they're here. It's the same reason we're here; for the emblematic power that sceptre will grant to whoever owns it.
111700: One imagined if one was secretive enough, La Corona might not discover one's intentions — yet of course, here they are at the double.
111701: Admiral Nadasky writes that he defied the orders of my father! That treasonous Jack Tar, father should have had his head!
111702: Another part of Admiral Nadasky's logbook… Fascinating reading…
111703: This entry shows that they persisted in deviating from father's instructions…
111704: This log is proof Nadasky may at least have had good intentions in his defiance of father's orders.
111705: The King, my father, draws further away from his daughter with each new revelation in Nadasky's log.
111706: The facts here are plain. Had they followed only father's orders, La Corona would have won.
111707: I may have been wrong about Admiral Nadasky. Upon my return to the capital, I shall have a great big pillar built in his honour.
111708: I always believed my father, when he claimed to be the unsung mastermind of the battle of Trelawney, but it was Nadasky all along that was saving his blushes.
111709: Father should have trusted those with naval expertise… I mean, it's now quite obvious he had little of that expertise himself.
111710: Some of father's orders were utterly baffling…
111711: Isn't he the spit of those chaps in the beggar's opera? We do so want to like the poor.
111712: He's with us, one hopes? Or is he the peculiar sort who doesn't take sides?
111713: The empire needs these potterers; those willing to try new things.
111714: What a remarkable innovation! Can I have a go?
111715: My mother had a great deal of trouble saying the words "ocean bottom", but I find I have no difficulty at all!
111716: Now, if it were the centrepiece of a grand exhibition, the people in these parts would be reminded of just how far-reaching the influence of an empress can be.
111717: When the exhibition is over, do remember to give it to my busbies, so I can toss it in with the rest of the bling.
111718: This waterlogged log is in a terrible state. Did you not bring any art restorers with you?
111719: One is no dunce-hatted imbecile, but I rather think we'll need a class swot or two to decipher this; a university with a budding college of palaeographers to decipher Nadasky's shameful handwriting.
111720: Oh, it's all much clearer now! Do thank your expert bods at the University for all their brio.
111721: The sceptre is worthless if it is not whole.
111722: Why did their Admiral Silva think it prudent to break up a lucky sceptre?
111723: Let us see if you have the prowess of Admiral Nadasky…
111724: In a way, I would be excited to see the battle of Trelawney recreated!
111725: This Oliveira reeks of defeat! You just have to tip the scales...
111726: I dreamed of seeing such a battle at Trelawney every night as a child!
111727: Marvellous! You know, now I that see it, it really doesn't look much like an eagle, does it? Oh well — none of my subjects will ever dare to question it!
111728: My gratitude is heartfelt.  This is a new emblem of state behind which my subjects will surely rally!
111729: I hear it has been stolen from the exhibition?! Crime is becoming a terrible problem for the empire. I will find that sceptre, but for now, I'm sorry your efforts have gone in vain.
111730: So the Sceptre of Capon has somehow made it into the hands of La Corona? Well-played… but it jolly billy better not have been you responsible!
111731: But, in the end, I care less for the sceptre, and more for Nadasky's revelations concerning my father.
111732: The father I saw — the great tactician — appears never to have existed; and yet a daughter's love prevails through the absurdity of his weakness.
111735: Dr. Hugo Mercier approves of your workers.
111736: Dr. Hugo Mercier despises your investors.
111739: Welcome to Trelawney, graveyard to thousands; the gift that keeps on giving, he he.
111740: Trelawney, site of one of the great naval battles, now a veritable trove of lost treasure.
111741: There's plunder to be had if you sink down deep enough. I may be able to help you along a tad with that.
111742: There's a lot of meat and cartilage left on the bones of these ships, especially on their underbellies.
111743: Don't worry about what he's up to. You just concentrate on your own digging.
111744: This Vasco looks stiffer than week-old bat kabob— on his last legs, like. No match for someone like you.
111745: Work with Oliveira? Who said that, he he! No, no, no — I'm all yours!
111746: Yaps a lot about his cousin, I find. Easy to boot a man when he's down, eh?
111747: Even after all this time, you still see the odd eyeball surface, belched up from that tomb of a trench below.
111748: Terrible, wars, ain't they? Well, for the luckless beggars who have to fight in them… ha ha ha!
111749: Sometimes you'll see a skull on the seabed, watchin' you like. I just smile back.
111750: If you're waiting for them dead sailors to give you permission, you'll be waiting a long time, ha ha ha ha!
111751: Don't plan on fixing yourself there too long — this place is like a thoroughfare for conqueror-types.
111752: Your peninsula might be under Queenie's umbrella for now, but I know from experience — nothing ever lasts.
111753: If you don't pick a side, you can't wind up on the wrong one.
111754: While the big boys and girls are duking it out, the likes of you and I can sneak stuff away while they ain't looking.
111755: Alright, you got me. I've been helping Vasco. Now, don't take offence, old mucker — it=s only common sense to back both horses.
111756: How's about I do you a special favour — just for you mind — to make up for my heinous betrayal of trust…
111757: I'm more interested in all the other sweet collector's items down there.
111758: All so hung up on that chicken-on-a-stick — what about the rest of the Trelawney hoard!
111759: Forget all that old flannel about her father — old Queenie's in it for the loot just as much as we are.
111760: Don't forget — Admiral Nadasky disobeyed his King, and it all paid off.
111761: Being a prototype, I will ask you sign a waiver for yer life, before you use it.
111762: Without the metal shell, you're as vulnerable as a homeless hermit crab.
111763: The Trelawney hoard's a diversion — everyone's forgotten all the older, more valuable finds.
111764: I have a personal asphyxiation with underwater treasure.
111765: Watch out for them octopuses, they like to keep all the good stuff under wraps.
111766: The diving bell gives them sharks something to chew on, at least.
111767: See anything shiny down there, then?
111768: Any mermaids open their purses of pearls for yer, then?
111769: Never be too sure that the life's all gone out of something.
111770: It'd cost you an arm and a leg to buy that new.
111773: Looks like it was made to be split into three. Shouldn't be too hard to put back together...
111774: There you have it! One reconstituted chicken stick, good as new.
111775: The maiden descent for me beautiful diving bell! I've got all three of me fingers crossed for you, you little ocean-going guinea pig, you.
111776: Botched the dive, did ya? Glass all get misted up or something?
111777: Hopefully the water won't gush in like the only other time I tested it. Well, good luck!
111778: Either you've got the bends, or you've come back disappointed.
111779: Corr, that'll fetch a few clams…
111780: Now here's something; a proper pressure gauge. You'll be able to go to much deeper and darker places now…
111781: This balloon is a rather special innovation of mine! Gives you a much better view of them hidden reefs!
111782: Now this is arguably my greatest invention to date! 'S'like invisible hands reaching through the air, and… there! That sound will keep you true.
111783: He's quite clever that Vasco, I'll give him that.
111784: Maybe I'll wait until you two finish each other off before diving in.
111785: Another battle of Trelawney? Oh goody!
111786: There you go! I told you I'd give you special treatment.
111787: There! Never say I don't care about you — even if it is true.
111788: The spaniel fetches the stick for its Queen then, eh? Well, a man like me can't afford to be loyal.
111789: It'd be funnier if you gave the three of us one bit each…
111790: Give me the sceptre? Corr, I'm honoured! And rich! Haha, good on yer — my absolute gamble on you has paid off.
111791: You do realise I'm just going to sell this sceptre to the highest bidder, right? So no moral victory for you, if that's what you thought it was.
111792: You gave it back to La Corona, 'cos it was theirs to begin with!? Whatever happened to finders keepers?
111793: Maybe that miserable geezer Vasco will be happy now. Or maybe not. That's how it is with miserable geezers.
111794: Exhibition royalties? Blimey, you're really milking that chicken stick for all its got, ain't yer?
111801:
Publish in your newspaper:
At least 1 anarchist propaganda article
111802: Who are you to refuse your people the knowledge of anarchy? Publish anarchist propaganda in your newspaper, or Dr. Mercier will assume you are against it.
111803: Open up your newspaper's draft and click 'edit'. Then drag one of the relevant articles to replace the standard news.
111805: Publish at least one of Dr. Hugo Mercier's propaganda articles in your newspaper (The Anarchist).
111812: Establish an alliance with Dr. Hugo Mercier (The Anarchist).
111813: Complete Dr. Hugo Mercier's main arc (The Anarchist).
111815: Defeat Dr. Hugo Mercier without luxury needs, public services or police stations (The Anarchist).
111819: Sir Archibald Blake has requested your presence at High Clarence Hall to discuss a touchy subject.
111820: Sir Archibald Blake has requested your presence at High Clarence Hall immediately.
111837: In the Festival of Reason, anarchists come together to celebrate truth, liberty, community and the abolition of governments.
111839: An anarchist demonstrator is satisfied that you fulfilled his demands.
111840: An anarchist demonstrator is satisfied that you fulfilled her demands.
111841: Some anarchy defectors would like to thank you with a gift.
111862: Dr. Hugo Mercier smirks at the trouble his infiltrators are creating on your island.
111887: When you see the happy smiling faces among Dr. Mercier's commune, you know their struggles are over. Their pain is over. Why not show your own people what they're missing?
111888: The folk who came over from Dr. Mercier's island have opened our eyes! If we have the skill to fashion products from steel, then it is us who is entitled to that product, not you!
111889: Oi, boss, ever heard of the labour theory of value? It's our sweat and blisters that should give gubbins their pricetag! Yet our wages are risible compared to what those soft-handed artisans get. Redress the balance, before we break it!
111890: Bread is but the basics of a meal! Are you a stuck up bourgeois that just tells the common people to go "eat brioche"? Hand out the loaves, now!
111891: We workers know what we're doing! Let us manage our own! Give us a space to unite and decide collectively, like on Dr. Hugo's island!
111892: You intoxicate us with the lies of priests to keep us compliant in the face of oppression! We don't want any more churches — give us temples of democracy instead!
111893: As long as we depend on goods from other nations, we are hostages to the free market! You'd better make sure we're not buying more than we're selling!
111894: If we must play along with the laws of capitalism, then we'll play them at their own game! If we over-supply, prices will have to drop. Maybe to the point where anyone can just help themselves to whatever they need!
111895: Why build so many police stations? Are you scared of the voice of the people? We will not tolerate this authoritarian repression! Try and address our problems instead!
111896: Your laws protect the privileged! It's time you legislate for the people, or we'll destroy the entire system!
111897: Our new anarchist peers have opened our eyes to the evils of society! The boys made this poster at the union to spread the word. I reckon you'll have no issue in putting it up on our town hall, right?
111898: You embody the establishment! We will join Dr. Hugo's commune and become free, equal individuals! You want to prove you're a decent human being? Then don't be a sore loser, and shelter our path!
111899: No wonder we're turning against capitalism when we lead such pathetic lives! If we were twice as happy, we wouldn't be looking for a way out!
111900: Dr. Hugo is the brightest mind of the century! If he doesn't respect you, why should we!?
111901: Your people are envious of life in Dr. Mercier's commune. They are insisting you publish an image of one of his islands in your newspaper — even if it tarnishes your own reputation in the process.
111902: Dr. Mercier's ideas are spreading among your residents, and they're beginning to suspect it is only you who benefits from all they produce. They demand a large quantity of the steel beams and weapons they've sweated over be awarded to them.
111903: The workers have become acquainted with some aspects of anarchist theory, and they now demand to be compensated for all the value their labour has lost on the capitalist free market.
111904: Your workers will not settle for the crumbs! If you want to keep your empire from crumbling from within, you'd better keep their bellies full.
111905: Your workers are claiming their right to control and manage the means of production. A trade union would be the perfect space for them to come together and debate.
111906: Your workers are fed up with having their minds numbed by religion. They demand you take down a church and replace it with a town hall — or else...
111907: It's important for your workers that you make sure your nation is self-sufficient, and doesn't rely on goods from other nations. They will not be satisfied until your trade balance is positive.
111908: Overproducing, Mercier argues, is actually a good thing for the people, since the prices drop so much it becomes unnecessary to track who helps themselves to what. That is what your workers want for your island too.
111909: When police are everywhere, justice is nowhere. So your workers have come to believe after learning more about anarchy. They have destroyed all your police stations, and their violence will resume if you can't maintain the peace without them.
111910: Fed up with an unjust system, your people demand you institute laws that protect the common classes.
111911: Your workers are thrilled by everything they've learnt about anarchy. In fact, so taken are they that they've stayed up all night creating a poster to paste on your town hall.
111912: There is no stopping these workers from leaving your island to join Dr. Mercier's people, but if you still want to be decent towards them, you can make sure they at least have safe passage to his island.
111913: The only reason your workers are starting to find anarchy attractive is because they are miserable. Well, maybe miserable is putting a bit strongly, but they could certainly be happier!
111914: You are at odds with Dr. Hugo Mercier, which means your workers — who look up to the anarchist leader — are at odds with you. Perhaps winning the heart of the doctor will earn you the love of your people.
111916: An unprecedented photographic report illustrates the idyllic life of people on Dr. Hugo Mercier's island, where all individuals are equal, and not one is better clothed or fed than their neighbour.
111925: Dr. Mercier's voice drills into the minds of his followers from these towers.
111935: A concerned artisan pleads for you to prevent the rise of anarchism.
111936: A concerned investor pleads for you to prevent the rise of anarchism.
111937: A concerned farmer pleads for you to prevent the rise of anarchism.
111938: A concerned engineer pleads for you to prevent the rise of anarchism.
111941: Meet Dr. Hugo Mercier, the Anarchist. Will he antagonise you, or become your greatest ally? Discover his unique approach to leadership as you get to know him through his exclusive quest line, and advocate for anarchy using his new propaganda articles and items. But beware — there are many downsides to anarchy spreading into your cities...
111944: As workers, labour is our greatest power! The lads that came over from Mercier's say they feel mighty good after a long day of hard work. Come on, let's add some more fuel!
111945: Dr. Hugo's anarchist theory states that workers achieve their greatest value when their produce remains within their community. You're not sure if your workers understand the full picture, but they do want to work harder, so who are you to argue with them?
111957: Start a new game with Dr. Mercier
111958: Will Dr. Hugo Mercier become your most dreaded rival, or an enlightening ally?
111961: Unlock Dr. Mercier's portrait through Uplay
111962: With so much talk about the evils of religion, priests are starting to be persecuted! Even if you can sympathise, no soul deserves to be threatened because of their beliefs. Protect them!
111963: The anarchist mistrust of the clergy has spread to your population. It appears some of your workers are harassing priests! A concerned citizen has asked you to find them and defend them.
111964: Oh no... Oh, there you are! I just heard something very — deeply! — vexing.  It appears the anarchists are planning an attack! You must stop the man with the torch! Please, I beg of you!
111965: Inspector Langdon says he's too busy chasing away anarchist troublemakers to look into the disappearance of my hens! Can't you give them a hand...?
111966: The anarchists are setting fire to every piece of writing that doesn't align with their convictions! Even if I can see where their grievances are coming from, this is the greatest crime I can possibly fathom! Please, stop this intellectual genocide!
111967: Darn those lousy, wretched anarchists! You! You're lucky my family were lounging at the Dawson's summer resort when they torched our household! Restore it! Immediately!
111968: No! My factory! My life's work, ruined! Why would anarchists confuse my modest craftsmanship with their dragon, capitalism? Please, would you restore the dreams they robbed me of?
111969: You saved our lives! We are eternally grateful! Please, if there's anything we can do — any way at all that we could be of use to you — allow me to repay your kindness with my expertise!
111970: Make no mistake — I might look like a worker, but I'm a trained engineer. I joined Mercier on the promise of a better world, but it turned out to be a fallacy... My designs will serve a better purpose here.
111971: I was so fed up with Mercier screaming lies at our faces with this loudspeaker, I just had to take it away from him! Ugh, I can't even stand the sight of this wretched thing. Take it off me, please!
111972: A panicked artisan came looking for your help. He overheard a group of anarchists discussing an impending attack on your city. Find the man bearing the torch before it's too late!
111973: The police have been overwhelmed lately, as they try to uncover the anarchist infiltrators, but your people have other problems they need their help with! Help them unearth the anarchist gangs to free up some space on their plate.
111974: Aghast, an engineer has alerted you to some anarchists who are going around burning books. It doesn't matter whether their ideas are valid or not — in her eyes, no book must ever be burnt.
111975: As much as Dr. Mercier likes to brag that anarchy is peaceful, his followers on your island seem to have a different perspective. They've wrecked an investor's residence, and he's now demanding that you build him a new one, at once.
111976: The anarchist attacks are not only targeting wealthy investors, but humble artisans too. With his business reduced to ashes, this poor man has lost his livelihood. Help him restore it.
111977: Among the people who arrived from Dr. Mercier's island, some have pledged to work for you as a way of repaying you for your hospitality.
111978: There was a brilliant engineer amongst the last batch of anarchist defectors you allowed into your city. He is more than happy to share his creations with you.
111979: This anarchist defector was so done with listening to Dr. Mercier through his loudspeaker that he snatched it away the second he had the chance. He is now offering it to you.
111983: An anarchist defector would like to repay your hospitality with a gift.
111984: Anarchists are causing chaos since you failed to address their demands.
111985: The anarchist defectors are disgruntled at your refusal to shelter them.
111986: A citizen regrets that you failed to prevent anarchy from spreading.
111991: Find the torchbearer running around the streets of your city.
111992: The priests are being persecuted by workers in the streets of your city.
111993: The anarchists are gathered around a fire, hiding in your city.
111994: Anarchists are burning books in your city.
111995: Find the rioting mobs stomping down the streets in Dr. Hugo Mercier's city.
111996: Look for the conspirators near Dr. Mercier's variety theatre.
111997: Look for the preachers near Dr. Mercier's marketplace, trade union and town hall.
111998: Find the dissidents hiding near Dr. Mercier's workers' residences.
111999: Talk to Dr. Mercier's residents at the variety theatre, the town hall and the trade union.
112000: A citizen regrets that you failed to prevent anarchy from spreading.
112064: Use the Diving Bell for the first time (Sunken Treasures).

112198: Dr. Mercier used to be a respectable dental practitioner before he became the leader of an anarchist regime. You either see eye to eye with him, or you are an ally of his oppressors, there is no middle ground... But if he agrees to trade with us, we may get access to some very unique merchandise on his trading post.
112202: Dr. Hugo Mercier endorses the anarchist items for sale on his trading post.
112204: It is far from being the capital I envisioned. There is much to do!
112205: Once my capital is all set, Archie will let me return to these sunny shores any time I like!
112206: My dreams — one's youthful imaginings of this place of triumph — so dutifully have you made whole.
112207: This is it: my metropolis, standing tall and proud — forever a symbol of my greatness.
112208: I saw it from the deck: an impish little man dredging up bits and pieces. He may be exactly what we require…
112209: If we are to find anything in this graveyard, we might as well commission the vulture.
112210: I will happily shake those greasy paws if it means I get my sceptre.
112211: What? We know the spot now. Or do you need a ducking?
112212: It must be around here somewhere. Proceed with your... goobling, or however you call it.
112213: So you're playing best of three? I hope you realise the seriousness of such a gamble — it seems you had better win.
112214: If you had the guts to bet my sceptre, you had better get to it first…
112215: Yes! Oh, for a second I thought he'd beaten us to it!
112216: Now it's time for Vasco to hold up his end of the bargain.
112217: We have the eagle! And Vasco promised to yield the pommel — he promised!
112219: If this is to become a radiant metropolis, we'll need to make some additions…
112220: How could these people possibly go without this!? I know I couldn't…
112222: The magic of the crown: I ask for it, and it appears!
112223: This city is now closer to magnificence!
112224: We have the pieces! Now it's time to puzzle it together...
112225: I have not undergone all this trouble so that flea may lay his oily digits on it!
112226: As if I'd leave my sceptre under his supervision…
112227: Haven't we plenty of scholars versed in the art of restoration already?
112228: I have one last vision: a World's Fair, sitting atop this magnificent metropolis!
112229: It will not be an imperial capital until the World's Fair is complete.
112230: The World's Fair! This may very well be the finest city in the whole of my empire!
112231: People will come from far and wide to behold the Sceptre of Capon — the ultimate exponent of my authority.
112232: There's no use owning such a treasure, unless it can be grandly displayed for my subjects. They shall see that — in ambition — I am at least my father's equal!
112233: The most precious of cherries to top the cake!
112234: Mr. Oliveira was truly a man of his word. Had it been me, I'd never have let him have our piece of the sceptre.
112235: In particular I am indebted to you for helping me see the king, my father, as he really was — warts and all.
112236: Well it's high time I returned to rescue poor old Archie — he may otherwise start chattering about his bowels. Look after Crown Falls for me, won't you? I only really care for the taxes now.
112238: We're groping in the dark here! How does that carrion bird know where to plunge?
112245: Rod of the Sceptre of Capon
112246: But we can't afford a war with La Corona — feeble though they may be — so I'm afraid you'll have to rely on wits to beat this Oliveira to it.

112261: A mere frigate against a ship-of-the-line...? Only Father's obsession with the sceptre could have clouded his judgement so! The last piece must be down there in the murk.

112352: The Queen revels in the metropolis you have built.
112354: The Queen runs no secular state: if this city is to become an imperial capital, she needs a church to remind her people it was an almighty God who chose her for the throne.

112395: Sir Archibald Blake urgently requests your help.
112396: Dear friend, what you read in the news is true — Her Majesty is gone! My one consolation is that her absence seems by choice, for she left me this parting note: "Don't fret, Archie dear. I'm off South to restore our imperial glory — will return when that's done". Please, can I trust you to ensure her safe return? I must remain here, to allay the chaos in her absence.
112397: Where has the Queen gone!? Worried sick and left to deal with a headless state, Sir Archibald Blake has come to you for help. You are his only hope in finding Her Majesty and convincing her to return to her royal duties. Organise an expedition south to go after her.

112410: At last, it is complete. After many days and nights of meticulous work, Nadasky's journal can be read in full for the first time. Here are the last pages, with the conclusion of his account of the Battle of Trelawney. A first-hand testimony of the Empire's history.

112418: Crown Falls, a rich and majestic land overlooking the bay of Trelawney, is where the Empire once won their much-heralded victory over La Corona. In other words, the perfect place to establish a new capital for the Queen.
112419: The spoils left behind by the battle of Trelawney have attracted many a treasure hunter. The Queen recalls spotting someone that may prove useful in her quest to retrieve the Sceptre of Capon, and wants you to find and commission him.
112420: You have acquired a diving bell from Old Nate. There's no way to know if the creaky prototype will hold up until you try it...
112421: The test dive went well enough, but the bell came up with nothing but worthless junk. Old Nate won't mind, though — he has a knack for finding value in everything. Bring the scrap to him, and he may be able to make something useful out of it.
112422: After your unfruitful diving attempt, Old Nate has taken pity on you. He'll let you have the co-ordinates of a juicy diving site, for what he claims is a reasonable price.
112423: Old Nate has given you the co-ordinates for a promising diving spot. Sail your salvager there — it's as good a spot as any to start looking for the Sceptre of Capon.
112424: You've recovered Nadasky's journal, but its pages are barely readable. Exposing the fragile pages to a long sea journey would be too risky. Instead, you must make room for art restorers at Crown Falls.
112425: Artisans will begin the restoration of Nadasky's journal by rebinding it. They need flour for the glue, and sewing machines for the stitching.
112426: While Nadasky's journal is being restored, the Queen wants you to establish a university in the region; its scholars should be able to help decipher the journal's contents.
112427: The first few pages of the journal are a first-hand account of the naval battle at Trelawney — it's evident Nadasky didn't think much of the King's strategy. The log also hints at the compass bearings at which you may find the sceptre.
112428: Nadasky pinpointed the great battleground of Trelawney in his journal as being somewhere to the east of Crown Falls. Chances are that part of the sceptre sank along with one of the many ships that fell during battle — but there are still active sea mines all over the area. Perhaps Old Nate has some apparatus that can help you navigate those dangerous waters.
112429: Once again, it seems you're not the first to come to Old Nate for help; he's already used up all his materials putting something together for Vasco. Nevertheless, he is prepared to help you catch up, if you bring him the scrap he needs...
112430: Thanks to Old Nate's invention, you can now take your diving bell to the battle site without fear of stumbling into mines — old or new — and find the rest of the sceptre.
112431: You were too late. The second piece of the Sceptre of Capon has fallen into the hands of Vasco Oliveira. But, unlike his cousin Vicente, Oliveira prefers to settle matters without violence. He has proposed a deal: if you are the first to recover the last piece of the sceptre — the Eagle — he will surrender the pommel. But if he gets to it first, you will have to hand over the rod section you found.
112432: The scholars say Nadasky's Journal is about as good as they're ever going to get it. Hopefully, it will give you more clues about what happened during the battle, and what became of the last part of the sceptre.
112433: Nadasky reveals in his journal that, despite his best attempts to avoid it, the King sent a frigate — the HMS Ajax — to chase after the Santíssima Vitória in an attempt to retrieve the Sceptre of Capon. No good came from this command: La Corona's flagship was never seen again, and the Ajax's crew all lost their lives after being stranded on an island without fresh water for a week. Her Majesty believes that you may find more clues about the whereabouts of the flagship if you look into the fate of Richardson and his sailors.
112434: Thanks to Richardson's log, you know that the Santíssima Vitória crashed on the east coast of Crown Falls. Her Majesty is certain that the eagle section of the Sceptre sank along with the ship, but where exactly? There are many such wrecks along those cliffs. Luckily, there may be a clue — Nadasky was so struck by his first sight of the Santíssima Vitória that he sketched it in his journal.
112435: The Santíssima Vitória — the magnificent ship-of-the-line that was the pride of La Corona — lies broken on the seabed, as if it were the skeleton of a colossal whale. Scour the bottom of the ocean, scrape every bone, and find the gleaming eagle — that timeless emblem of empire.
112436: The contract is unequivocal: whoever finds the Eagle of the Sceptre first, shall receive the third piece from the counterparty. The Eagle is in your hands, so Vasco Oliveira has no choice other than to surrender the sceptre's pommel to you.
112437: Despite Old Nate's attempt to lay his hands on the sceptre, the Queen has chosen to leave the restoration to the trained art restorers of Crown Falls. They will see to it the moment they have the special materials they require.
112438: The Sceptre of Capon has been recovered and restored — along with the pride of the Empire, apparently. The Queen has little use for it locked up in a vault: she wants her subjects to come from every corner of the nation to behold the sceptre in all its glory.
112439: The Sceptre of Capon has been recovered and restored — along with the pride of the Empire, apparently. The Queen has little use for it locked up in a vault: she wants her subjects to come from every corner of the nation to behold the sceptre in all its glory.

112444: We're lucky there's even a faint possibility of returning this journal to a semblance of its original condition. We must first see to the binding: people tell me a flour-based glue will be gentler on such a delicate manuscript than an acid one, and that we'll also want the precision and punch of modern sewing machines for the stitching.

112465: Ahh, the sceptre! A wonderful piece! But it has suffered structural damage — we will need metal to restore it to glory!
112466: The soul of the sceptre has returned, but it still needs plating in precious metals.
112467: The Sceptre of Capon has almost been returned to its former splendour! There are just two final details missing: the inlay of pearl it once had, and the delicate filigree I have seen in the paintings.
112468: We are finally finished. This is, without a shadow of a doubt, the greatest masterpiece we have ever laid eyes upon. We hope Her Majesty will be satisfied with our work.

112543:
Following the King’s commands to intercept Admiral Silva’s flotilla, we arrived at Cape Trelawney at 1pm.
La Corona’s entire armada is here — their flagship, especially, being of imposing size and might. Such a disproportionate escort suggests that our informants were correct: they must be transporting the Sceptre of Capon that our King is seeking.
112544:
La Corona opened fire this morning. We engaged in battle at 10am, south east of the region — a conflict which lasted until seven in the evening.
We lost many good men today — the sly young Admiral Silva having deployed mines to protect the enemy convoy. It was the King's command that we attack in a single line, parallel to the enemy formation. Fortunately, I was able to persuade the fleet to ignore this instruction, and instead arrange themselves into two perpendicular columns to cut through the enemy line — and as a corollary, avoid the mines. Our lead ships were blown apart, but it left a path clear for the rest of us. The enemy fleet, being snipped into thirds, were vulnerable to broadsides. We proceeded to drive them toward their own mines, and though in the mayhem there were casualties on both sides, we knew victory for the Empire had been won.
We thank those brave sailors who lost their lives today that we ourselves survived, and shall never forget their sacrifice. The price would have been far greater had we sworn blind obedience to the King's strategy.
112545:
The King is, indeed, mad. He appears to care nothing for our victory, and was upset in the extreme to learn that we hadn't yet begun pursuit of the Santíssima Vitória, for he is adamant that the Sceptre of Capon is on board.
Having received word that the flagship was heading northeast, His Majesty ordered Captain Richardson — of the HMS Ajax — to go after her. Under no circumstances will he permit us to accompany them. I have tried to inform the King that the Ajax is ill-equipped for the duel, but my injury leaves me weak, and I have had to retire to my quarters. Santíssima Vitória may be the largest man-of-war ever built. Richardson knows he leads his men to their deaths, but he has always been a man unwavering in his sense of duty.
112579: Old Nate's basic prototype is the standard for exploratory diving.
112580: Old Nate quirkily affixed a moon pool to the base of this diving bell, enabling better access to the abyss.
112581: Old Nate's proudest work. A controlled flow of gas sent via its umbilical cable enables this bell to dive deeper than ever before.
112582: Old Nate's first attempt at mapping the depths using sound.
112583: An improved version of Old Nate's echo-ranger, with more bells and whistles.
112584: Sound out even the most sunken of sunken treasures with this subsurface detector — an innovation in sea surveying far ahead of its time.
112585: A new standard in diving cables.
112586: The elasticity of these cables allows for more flexibility in the bell's carry weight.
112587: Nate's most cunning cabling: durable under heavy loads, while supporting a variety of systems between the diving bell and its parent.
112589: Brings scores of fascinating marine creatures to the surface.
112590: Has the miraculous power to draw the most bizarre abyssal creatures in creation to the surface.
112591: Dinky magnet that draws up dross. Demagnetizes over time.
112592: A big magnet that attracts the attention of some really great junk. Demagnetizes over time.
112593: Nate stroked this monster magnet with his master magnet. Expect to find the ripest, rustiest junk going. Demagnetizes over time.
112594: Sifts the seabed for ancient artifacts.
112595: Sifts a large area of the seabed for obscure and ancient artifacts.
112596: Sifts a very large area of the seabed, revealing remarkable artifacts that incrustations have long kept concealed.
112597: For scraping the bottom of the barrel.
112598: A slightly more ambitious dredge of Old Nate's, designed to plumb deeper water for sunken machinery.
112599: Old Nate's most far-reaching scavenging dredge, designed to plumb the ocean's deepest trenches for sunken machinery.
112603: Maybe first designed to make car races, who knows.
112604: Maybe first designed to make car races, who knows.
112605: Maybe first designed to make car races, who knows.
112606: Blows up one in every ten passing ships (probably).
112607: Bigger and prongier. Adds a bit of froth and fizz to the mix whenever its destructive services are called upon.
112608: A mine of monstrous size and ferocity, whose horns really hertz. Look close, and you can see steam puffing from its wetted nostrils.
112739: Phragmites australis. Whispers along the edges of estuaries.
112748: Hevea Rigidifolia. A New World spurge producing resinous rubber.
112749: Acropora Cervicornis. A hard coral that reaches out like a tree.
112750: Dendrogyra cylindrus. Figures huddling in the water's gloom.
112755: Nymphaea alba. Frequently accompanied by the croaking of toads.
112756: Saxifraga Oppositifolia. Breaks out among rocks after the thaw.
112757: Roystonea regia. Its giant leaves magically detach in tropical storms.
112758: Rhododendron. A genus of bold-coloured shrubs so diverse, botanists can't agree on a taxonomy.
112759: Cyperus Papyrus. Once used as paper, but also for boats, clothes, and even as food.
112761: Prunus serrulata. Clouds of graceful blossom to drink and picnic beneath.
112762: Cocos nucifera. Make sure a falling drupe doesn't bonk you on the coco.
112763: Bertholletia Excelsa. A gigantic nut-bearing tree of the rainforest, frequented by capuchins.
112764: Victoria Amazonica. 'On unbent leaf, in fairy guise... stands Annie, Paxton's daughter.'
112765: Metaxya Rostrata. A primitive fern whose abaxial sori appear in uniform lines.
112766: Montastraea Cavernosa. Its lumpish colonies are likely to trigger trypophobes.
112770: Althaea Officinalis. Its roots may be combined with egg white to form 'pâte de guimauve', a scrummy treat.
112771: Eucalyptus Pauciflora. The cream-cocoa twist of its trunk is reminsicent of inter-muddled putty.
112772: Nelumbo Lutea. A forest of leafen trumpets and soft lemon flowers, stilting up from the water's bed.
112774: Nelumbo Nucifera "Perry's Giant Sunburst". The yellow flowers burst open at dawn, like suns floating on the surface of the pond.
112775: Ceiba Samauma. Mesoan stories claim that its twisted limbs are commanded by the evil spirits that dwell in it.
112776: Nymphaea Caerulea. Stone carvings depict the sun god of the delta emerging from its flower bud each morning.
112777: Nymphaea Lotus. The bright red variegations in the foliage resemble the stripes of a tiger.
112778: Nelumbo Nucifera "Angel Wings". The pristine lotus flower that grows over the murky waters symbolizes purity of heart and mind in many religions.
112779: Ficus Benghalensis. Temples are erected under the immense canopy of this sacred fig.
112780: Saraca asoca. The vivid colours of the ashoka blossoms are often mentioned in south-eastern literature as a symbol of love and seduction.
112781: Ziziphus Lotus. Eating its flowers and fruits causes a pleasant drowsiness that made legendary sailors forget their natal shores.
112782: Taxus Baccata. An earthly remnant of the Northern mythical Yggdracca, rising tall from the temple of Uppsidaisi.
112783: Ficus Religiosa. It was beneath its heart-shaped leaves that Siddhattha sat for forty-nine nights and attained enlightenment.
112826: Psychrolutes marcidus. A melted human face with fins.
112827: Periphylla periphylla. Avoids the light, as with so many of us these days.
112828: Stomiidae. Normally dwells deeper than even submersibles can reach, but was caught when coming to the surface for oxygen.
112829: Species Unrecorded. This species has not yet been categorised. Why not name it after yourself!
112830: Mitsukurina owstoni. Captures the imagination with its extensive proboscis, much like the mythical goblin Tengu.
112831: Chiasmodon niger. Stuffs prey larger than itself into a stretchable cocoon-like basket that dangles from its belly.
112832: Cyanea capillata. The rapunzel of the sea, this great hairy stinger can grow even longer than the blue whale!
112833: The legendary Kraken, captured! It propels itself wildly around the tank! Tiny human observers cower under its mesmerising gaze!
112834: The great strategist's blade. Last seen held aloft and glinting in the southern sun, just before the fleet cut through the enemy line.
112835: Evidence of a long-lost civilisation? They say the Kingdom of Atlantis spanned a vast and fertile continent that, according to legend, tragically subsided into the sea.
112836: This sunken shrine to fork-wielding Poseidon seems ironic now. Why did Poseidon not save his children, when the oceans were his to command?
112837: No courthouse could bridle the hubris of the Atlanteans, and so it was left to the fates instead to condemn those peoples to the eternal abyss.
112838: A statue cut from a material so rare that for millennia it has been known only by its name. It is quite possible that this is the only example of this mineral that remains.
112839: The megalithic structure lends further credence to the existence of a lost continent to the west. Experts say this stepped pyramid could have been at the heart of Atlantean ritual.
112840: A tablet so mystifying it will convince the vast majority of museum visitors that Atlantis existed, while leaving true scholars of the ancient world pretty sceptical.
112888: Increases your prospects of striking gold.
112889: A sideline in copper and zinc.
112890: Ensures not a drop goes to waste.
112891: A bit of hip-wiggle in this iteration seems to attract even more gold.
112892: This model is the gold standard. Simply pour black gold in and get gold gold out.
112893: A proper cropper of zinc and copper.
112894: Gathers fossil goop the average sucker might miss.
112895: One of Old Nate's more down-to-earth inventions. Gathers precious metals at a remarkable rate.
112896: Only five star crude will pass this extractor's exacting selection process.
112926: Places a mine below the surface that explodes on enemy proximity.

112966: The captain informs you that the diving bell has returned.

113228: This map marks the lost ruins of a small village in the Old World.
113229: This map shows the location of an ancient trading post in the New World.
113230: This map will lead you to the remains of an abandoned ship near Cape Trelawney.
113231: The people who built this temple couldn't have foreseen the catastrophe that drove their place of worship to the bottom of the sea.
113232: No one knows who built this pyramid, or how it sank to the bottom of the ocean.
113233: This map reveals the place where a thriving city once stood, now resting below the surface.
113234: The pleasure palaces of Baiea were pulled under the sea, along with their owners' luxuries and excesses.
113235: This map appears to show the entrance to the legendary lost city of Paititi, but nobody has yet been able to find it...!
113236: A cartographer and linguist studied this ancient manuscript to produce a map that leads to the legendary city of Atlantis.
113237: This map will help you uncover the rare species that lie tangled in the kelp forest.
113238: The rich fauna of the seagrass meadow awaits you where the X marks the spot.
113239: This map will lead you to a coral garden, and all the different species that thrive in it.
113240: Some of the mysterious species that roam the depths of this oceanic trench have yet to be discovered.
113241: This map marks one of the richest ecosystems on the planet.
113242: It's hard to believe that some of these creatures truly exist, and are not the stuff of dreams — or nightmares.
113243: It's hard to believe this map will lead you to the colossal serpent deity ⁠— but the myths must have stemmed from something...
113244: Could this really be the place where the Huacan God rests...?
113245: Multiple sightings confirm that this may be the best place to capture the legendary Kraken — or be captured by it.
113246: A map of a large naval battle that occurred in home waters recently. Some machines may still be at the bottom of the sea...
113247: A map of a large naval battle that occurred abroad recently. Some machines may still be at the bottom of the sea...
113248: A map of a large naval battle that occurred at Trelawney recently. Some machines may still be at the bottom of the sea...
113249: A very rare map indicating the location of the wreckage of a wealthy merchant ship in home waters.
113250: A very rare map indicating the location of the wreckage of a wealthy merchant ship in foreign waters.
113251: A very rare map indicating the location of the wreckage of a wealthy merchant ship in the waters of Trelawney.
113253: A unique map marking the location of Willie's special fortune. If there's anything down there, it will surely be of high value.
113254: A unique map marking a vault of contingencies for Isabel's rebels. If there's anything down there, it will surely be of high value.
113255: A unique map marking the wreck of Vicente's favourite ship. If there's anything down there, it will surely be of high value.

113270: Dive at the location marked on the treasure map.
113299: Knows what to look for, and how and where to look.
113300: If there's a chance of recovering the past, she'll be the first to dive in.
113301: Said to vomit at the sight of soot, Flinders' passion for keeping immaculate exhibits is both his gift and his curse.
113302: He'd like to be under the sea.
113303: Seems to speak the language of fish — at least, that's how she sounds underwater...
113304: Has named zillions of marine lifeforms, receiving nothing but positives for her growing collection of underwater negatives.
113305: Has no problem keeping his eyes open while underwater.
113306: Nadia started dredging up machines after her father Igor's business took a bit of a dive.
113307: A master machine dredger, Anchovy has travelled the seven seas, shrivelling above deck in the sun and salt.
113308: Swings a pendulum in search of a fifth dimension.
113309: Lamie accumulates fortunes as easily as he has the days, weeks and years.
113310: Unimpeachable virtue has rarely been so well-rewarded. A heroine of the east, Mai is also no slouch with a sword.
113312: Starts a quest to find a sunken treasure.
