113435: An exhibition to show off the reclaimed Sceptre of Capon — an heirloom said to run in the blood of Her Majesty and epitomize the triumph over La Corona at Trelawney — opened its grand doors earlier today. The queuing was endless, for not only were there denizens of Trelawney in attendance, but curious and patriotic visitors from all corners of the empire.
113437: After great service to both a city and a nation, [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] has been officially appointed Warden of Trelawney and Governor of Crown Falls at a grand ceremony conducted by Her Majesty The Queen, Empress Royal of The Southern Territories.
113440: You can only equip items in your museum if they are stored in your trading post. Make sure to transfer the sceptre to the trading post from your ship.
113441: Keep the exhibition of the Sceptre of Capon open for the requested amount of time.
113442: The Sceptre of Capon gives your city a lot of attractiveness!
113462: Breaking news! Her Majesty the Queen seems to have vanished! No official statement has been released as yet, but Her Majesty's steward, Sir Archibald Blake, appeared frantic when seen descending the palace steps this morning...
113463: Centrophryne spinulosa. A deep-dwelling anglerfish whose lantern lights the prey that it minces with its many recurved teeth.
113468: Old Nate asks if you're ready to pay.
113470: Latimeria chalumnae. Old Nate looks at you and says, "This isn't the only living fossil hanging around the sea bed".
113474: A remarkable figurehead belonging to a resplendent imperial ship that fought in the battle of Trelawney.
113475: Nadasky's dying wish was that this medal be recovered for his young son, who dreamed of becoming an admiral like his father...
113499: Old Nate can never get enough scrap for his projects. He'd be delighted if you could give him any you find during your dives.
113500: Old Nate is after a specific bit of sunken machinery to help inspire his own designs. Be on the lookout during your dives — he'll no doubt be willing to give you something for it.
113501: Old Nate wishes to conduct post-mortems on some of the more peculiar species of deep-dwelling sea life, knowing their many adaptations will be able to inspire his own designs.
113502: Old Nate wants you to keep a lookout for any ancient technology on the seabed. This region was once a cradle of civilisation, and good ideas are timeless.
113503: Old Nate wants you to recover a sacred pirate talisman before the pirates do, lest it bring about their reunification and resurgence. Either that, or because it'll sell for a lot of gold.
113504: A peculiar society, believing themselves the descendants of Atlantis, will do all they can to prevent you discovering the city of their forefathers.
113505: Old Nate has acquired a treasure map from a dubious source. The marked co-ordinates will lead you either to riches, or a whole world of trouble.
113506: Old Nate has found an area for you to scan with an echo sounder. Believe it or not, one of his underlings claims to have seen an underwater city there, inhabited by nymphs.
113507: Old Nate has found another promising spot for you to scan with the echo sounder. Up, up and away from the action as usual, he saw no reason to get involved until the fighting was over. While not unsympathetic towards the rebel cause, he sees no reason not to loot their ship now it's good and sunk.
113508: A flotilla of mines surround a diving spot that Old Nate thinks very promising indeed. He just needs someone brave enough — or foolish enough — to go there for him.
113509: Old Nate has asked you to avoid some mines laid by unscrupulous looter-rival Scofield, who is trying to plunder a popular trade route. If there happen to be any victims already though, Old Nate sees no harm in picking through the bodies.
113510: The (very) elusive Scofield has been laying mines to snare unsuspecting ships again. Old Nate nobly urges you to do the right thing once more, and destroy them.
113511: Old Nate wants you to bring him some soap, so that his employees can keep the automata in clean working order.
113512: Old Nate wants you to bury him in spectacles, providing him with a stock of assorted lenses for his new inventions.
113513: Old Nate has asked you to deliver some materials in their purest form.
113514: Old Nate wants you to deliver some modern technology for him to examine and re-purpose.
113515: Old Nate is missing that special something to bring one of his creations to life. He hopes you'll have what he needs.
113516: Old Nate swears by fish oil as a daily supplement, and would like you to deliver some for him and his employees. There seems to be a silent accord that it'll do them all good.
113518: Old Nate is desperate for some caffeine to keep him ticking through the night as he works on his inventions. Sounds like his employees are depending on it too.
113519: Old Nate is trying to recover some of the spoils of war, even while the fighting still rages! Wary of being sucked in, he has asked for your protection.
113520: Old Nate is constructing a mechanical wonder — a lifelike automaton designed to go about its business like a human — and he needs your help with the parts.
113524: Old Nate doesn't care for grand occasions, but the challenge of making elaborate fireworks is just too tempting for him to resist. He wants you to bring him all he needs to get started.
113527: Old Nate wants to make sure that everything is settled before your first dive.
113529: Just so you know, any old scrap you find, I'll be interested in it. The grubbier and tattier the better.
113533: A paper company ship sank 'round here. Perhaps you can help me sniff out a story? Maybe a gummed-up print press...
113537: Drill bits or bits of drill — not fussed — need 'em for me next bore. There must be some down there, what with all the quarrying along our coasts nowadays.
113538: As a self-sustaining bloke, I'd be overjoyed to see any smashed-up hydroelectric wheels you find, alright?
113539: Obsolete machines can tell us a lot — almost all the best ideas lie screwed up at the bottom of the paper bin.
113540: Best to learn from other people's mistakes, I say. There's no shortage of ship turbines down there, thanks to all them accidents that made way for the steamships we know today.
113541: The rotten prow of a ship that sank during the battle of Trelawney.
113542: This well-preserved sculpture once led from the prow at the battle of Trelawney.
113543: A colourful and talismanic bust that fronted one of the great ships that sank at Trelawney.
113544: A remarkable figurehead belonging to a magisterial La Corona ship that sank at the battle of Trelawney.
113545: This flag formed the first part of a famous signal during the battle of Trelawney.
113546: This flag formed the middle part of a famous signal during the battle of Trelawney.
113547: This flag formed the last part of a famous signal during the battle of Trelawney.
113548: Awarded to an unknown sailor for bravery in a previous arena.
113549: A medal belonging to a high-ranking officer, who may have died at Trelawney.
113550: A fine military decoration of an experienced campaigner present at the battle of Trelawney.
113551: We'll never surpass Mother Nature's powers of invention, I don't imagine. Not unless we start taking her weirdest creations apart, and stirring through their insides.
113552: Fascinating food filters they have — all them little planktons bouncing off the blades in their gobs. I can use that!
113553: Fascinating food filters they have — all them little planktons bouncing off the blades in their gobs. I can use that!
113554: This one's not for science, by the by — it's for eating. I got a taste for it when I was out ballooning in the east. Now, which bit was the liver again...?
113555: This thing is nine-tenths water! Imagine that! Boggles the mind it does — but as a matter-of-fact, I'm working on some organics myself...
113556: Ancient-looking thing, eh? But that's a sign it's stood the test of time, like all the greatest inventions...
113557: I accumulate know-how the same way I accumulate junk. Down on the seabed lie all the little tidbits of wisdom left to us by our forefathers — it'd be a terrible shame not to cannibalise 'em, eh?
113558: The pirates are desperate for that ring! Fend 'em off, or the power of the old pirate kings will be restored, and piracy will rule the seas once more! Also, if they pinch it I won't be able to sell it.
113559: Oh gawd, get yer tridents out — it's the Society of Atlanteans again! If they reckon their ancient city's down there, they'll stop at nothing to keep its entrance a secret.
113560: I've got this one treasure map... And it's not that I don't trust the rotten human that gave it me, but... we won't know if it's a trap 'til we dive. That's where you come in...
113561: I knew it! That map was as genuine as me back tooth. Here's your share of the spoils, me old bird.
113562: Sorry about that mix up — win some, lose some. Don't let one dodgy tip-off dent your enthusiasm, or next time you could be missing out!
113564: One of my... employees... swears they were 'nabbed by sea nymphs — wined and dined in the sunken court of a coral queen. Far be it from me to disbelieve them — why not sound it out with that ocarina I gave yer?
113565: I took me seat up in the gods to watch Her Majesty drub another of her poor, oppressed colonies into submission — and I'm pretty sure I'm the only one that noticed that tragic beaut go down with all its plunder... Find the echo, it's down there somewhere!
113566: Since I'm a poor frail old man who never leaves his workshop, (ahem) I need a brave navigator to recover something precious to me. Alright, I won't lie, there'll be mines everywhere — place is a ruddy lobster trap. The cache down there though, corr!
113567: When villains like Scofield kill to deprive people of their possessions... I know I ain't so bad. He set mines on a major seaway — think of all those lives! ...'Course, anything wrecked already is fair game though, right?
113568: Scofield's up to his old tricks again — fancy laying mines in a tranquil reef! You'll blow up those charges for me, won't yer? My only concern is for the welfare of the passing ships, y'see...
113569: Lovely — now I can gather all the loose sea sponge I need! Eh? What, Scofield? Oh, right — THAT Scofield. Well, why didn't you say?! Ha! Showed him didn't we, eh? Hmm.
113571: A bit of shine is dandy, but if the automata aren't kept clean, their mechanisms jam. They're a sorry sight when it happens. It's like they've lost all self-respect.
113572: There's nothing wrong with my beady eyes — twenty-twenty vision, me! No, I want glasses for the lenses — for me telescopes and such.
113573: It's good to have some alloys...
113574: I like tearing new stuff apart with me talons. So much so I'll even pay you to bring it me — how about that?
113575: I'm missing a few last bits and bobs...
113576: A spoonful of oil a day stops me rusting up — and all me employees, too! They're made in my image, them machine-heads!
113577: You can't expect to work all night without coffee to sip... My employees practically run on the stuff!
113583: I'm on the lookout for metals in particular...
113589: If you're a scavenger, you can't always wait for the battle to die down — and yet I don't bloody-well want them thinking I'm taking part neither. What I'm trying to say is — I need you as a human shield... Hahaha!
113590: I've always dreamt of sophistication. Not for meself, you understand, but for me automata. They still ain't nothing like humans though, even after five-hundred-and-thirty-odd tries. Perhaps I could use your brains for nr. 531?
113591: Nahhhh — even with your help, the 531 ain't anywhere close to being perfect. One for the scrapheap, methinks. Unless you want it, of course?
113592: Right — this time, a completely different line of automata. I find it's always easier to get sense out of these bloody things if you put them in their place. Talking of which — ha! — mind giving us a hand?
113593: After all that effort, this is one of the worst I've ever made! Ruddy thing keeps combusting on me! If you want to take it off me hands, I'm not going to stop you...
113594: I bloody swear, this is my last try before I go back to making cars and zeppelins like any sensible person. Reckon I've learned me lessons from the Mk.8 — long live Mk.9!
113595: I should've called it the IncinerN8, stupid ruddy thing! I mean it has its moments, I'll give it that, but I'm not risking all me other stuff on its behalf. If you want it, take it — I've lost me appetite for automata.
113596: The Queen wants you to build a church.
113597: The Queen wants you to enlarge your harbour area.
113598: The Queen wants you to promote culture.
113601: In death, a ray of inspiration.
113628: Bit off more than it could chew...
113629: In the end, it was just too puffed out...
113631: At least it had a good innings...
113632: These stone pictographs contain, among other things, details of a cast iron water screw for the transportation of water to elevated gardens.
113635: Anatomies and flying machines survive because the paper on which they were drawn is fibrous, and was preserved within a safe.
113636: An ancient stone tablet covered in trigonometric ratios and other mathematical treats.
113637: Insulated within a metal chest, this manuscript describes the various innovations in medieval warfare during the crusades.
113638: Part of an ancient analogue computer capable of predicting cosmic events — such as eclipses — years in advance.
113639: An ancient pirate talisman coruscating with wickedness. The inner band is inscribed "The dead never die".
113640: May not necessarily lead to something good...
113641: All the sparkle that remains of a resistance against an all-consuming empire.
113642: Specially-designed by Old Nate for the systematic removal of sea mines.
113656: A ship must be in range.
113657: Reach the diving spot using an echo-locator.
113671: Read Nadasky's journal closely, and find the three locations he describes.
113673: Click on the echo-locator on your ship. The golden signal echoing back to your ship will tell you where to go.
113681: Sir Archibald Blake asks if you'd be willing to help him.
113682: The Queen offers you the materials to set up an outpost.
113685: The Queen is pleased with your progress.
113686: The Queen is exhilarated to have found the last piece of the sceptre.
113687: To reach the next city status, you must attract a certain number of residents. Build enough residences for them, and make sure at least their basic needs are fulfilled.

113802: Joined after you helped the Queen at Trelawney. Formerly of the Royal Mint, the Queen sent Susannah to make your gold go further.
113803: Joined after you helped the Queen at Trelawney. Fernando used to make Vasco's morning coffee, but King João put paid to that.

113821: Follow the Queen to Cape Trelawney; a new session with an immense continental island. Remarkable treasures are said to be buried in these waters— the remnants of a great sea battle. You're going to need a diving bell to get them— the newest invention of Old Nate, a nearby drifter. He'll also help turn any rubbish you find into inventions to fuel the growth of your territorial capital!
113824: Explore the story of the Battle of Trelawney, and meet two new characters: Old Nate and Vasco Oliveira.
113826: Use your new diving bell to recover shiny sunken treasures.
113827: Explore and settle in a new session, with multiple islands and one vast continental island.
113828: Craft inventive new items at Old Nate's island with scrap you find.
113834: La Corona’s fleet is vast in terms of size and number, but ours is staffed with seamen both seasoned and loyal. We have a chance of winning a decisive victory against the enemy here at Trelawney — but not if we fixate on recovering the sceptre, as the King is insisting... I admit, taking the talisman would greatly damage La Corona's national spirit — but what of our own, when a thousand or more sailors are sent to their deaths for a trinket! No, we must have no other thought than employing the very best tactics to win the day.
113835:
Since the King will no longer leave the safety of his fortress atop the cliffs, we may be able to blame the fog for not complying with his signals.
There were a few other incidents today. At 3pm we intercepted two enemy gunboats, and ran them aground between two small islands to the Southeast, with cliffs like two guard dogs facing one another.
At 4:30pm we discovered a frigate bearing the emblem of La Corona, smuggling crates out of a pirate cove in the spiral-shaped cluster of islands that lie due east.
Lastly, we had a skirmish with a ship-of-the-line near an old watchtower, between the three large islands due west. She sank with all her cargo.
113837:
It will doubtless anger him to hear his orders were defied, but I stand by my decision. It may even please him to hear I have been wounded for my arrogance. It's likely my dress and decorations made me a conspicuous target, and I took a shot of musket to my side.
My arm still has full function — and my head is not half as foggy as the doctor thinks it to be — so I will continue my command until our operation here has concluded. La Corona may have suffered a defeat of magnitude today, but their flagship — the gargantuan Santíssima Vitória — managed to escape unscathed.
113840:
It is unseasonably, morbidly hot. A rowboat was found this morning, beached on the headland — brought in on the current, presumably, for its occupants are three days dead of thirst. In a clenched hand, one held a letter from Richardson — these men were sent to find help, the crew of the Ajax surviving a clash with the Santíssima Vitória only by swimming to an island south east of the headland.
We immediately dispatched a rescue boat, but it was too late: Richardson and his crew have met the same fate. We found no trace of the Santíssima Vitória, either. His Majesty's reaction is predictable. These lives were taken by his hands, yet he weeps only for the sceptre.
My wounds fester, and my fever worsens. The doctor says I must put down my pen.
113842: In the best interest of both our nations, I, Vasco Oliveira Silva, servant of His Majesty King João of A Coroa, agree to surrender the piece of the Sceptre of Capon currently in my custody, namely the pommel of the sceptre, in the event of my failing to discover the final piece of the sceptre (the eagle) first — so long as the counterparty agrees to do the same in the opposite event.
113861: 2 AM: Our patrol was uneventful. The night is calm. Thanks to Admiral Nadasky’s exceptional strategy, the HMS Ajax and many of her sister ships have prevailed in the battle of Trelawney.
113862: 9 AM: We have new orders. The Ajax has been chosen by His Majesty himself to chase and board the Santíssima Vitória, where we are to retrieve an object of great importance. The enemy have a significant advantage, but the HMS Ajax is a logical choice, being one of few frigates still in good condition. I must have faith we can achieve our goal, or else my men will not.
113863: 12 PM: We encountered the Santíssima Vitória south east of the mainland. She opened fire on sight. I commanded the Ajax to retaliate. We disabled their rudder, and saw the enemy flagship wreck against the east coast of the mainland, pulled in by a strong current. The sceptre has gone with her — and we too are filling with water.
113864:
HMS Ajax sunk. One rowboat, myself and rest swimming for shore. Desolate island, no fresh water. Heat unbearable. Current too strong to attempt crossing — sending rowboat to get help.

19th October,
No word from the rowboat. We will die here...

October 21st,
All hope is lost. Our King has forsaken us.

114382:
November 14th, 1847:

Made camp on King William Island, it shall shelter us for the winter.

January 3rd, 1848:

Met a group of Inuit to the Northwest. They were reluctant at first, but later approached us to trade for iron. They offered us dead seals, which o.c. we civilly declined —having enough fine canned food aboard Styx and Hades to last a lifetime— but instead they may know of a route to NW passage.

March 11th, 1848:

The Inuit led us to a channel heading deeper into the ice. Inuit look worried, but our instruments report freeze is thinning by the day — time for our mighty icebreakers to prove their prowess! Soon we shall be the first to cut the miracle shipping canal bridging East and West! We set out tomorrow.

114596:
April 26th, 1848:

We've been forced to abandon the HMS Styx and HMS Hades. We waited the entire summer for the thaw, but the weather gods were against us: they're still stuck fast in the ice. I am certain we can still find the NW passage by foot, walking inland.
We've filled two lifeboats with essential supplies, and will pull them over the snow like sleds. When next we find water, it will be a passage to the east! Then the lifeboats can row us to a safe haven.

May 4th, 1848:

The men tire. Dragging two lifeboats was perhaps ambitious, so they've been stopping to rest at regular intervals.
I have ordered that all remaining supplies be trusted to one of the lifeboats from now on, giving us double the pulling power.
Despite setbacks, morale is good, and we've lost no men since winter on Baffling Island.
114597:
May 11th, 1848:

We are at a crossroads. To determine the best way forward, I sent a team led by Cdr. H. Sturgeon through the canyon to the north. A second team led by Lt Cdr. R. Des Yeux went over the snow dunes to the west. The last team, led by Lt Cdr. E. Couch, went towards deep chasms in the east.

May 14th, 1848:

No team has yet returned. Camp supplies are becoming rather scarce, and there's little out here to hunt. I think we'd even gobble up those seals the Inuit offered us now.

May 16th, 1848:

Only two of the three teams have returned. I fear the worst has befallen Edgar Couch's men — a risk we all took the day we volunteered. It's hard out here; cruel. The rest of us are to move without delay; their sacrifice will not be wasted if we make it.
Cdr. Sturgeon reports that his canyon tapered to a dead end. Des Yeux, God thank him, reports something more promising. We will take the path he took. The ground looks too weak for the boat, but I'm sure we'll think of something. We always do.
114598:
June 21st, 1848

Perhaps the warnings of these Inuit had worth. The ice desert has been treacherous, and we have lost both men and equipment. I see darkness in the eyes of the living, now that their companions lie buried. If you knew that we are also at the end of our supplies, you might understand their anger.
But they are loyal men, and know they cannot hope to survive alone. They will only challenge me if I admit defeat, and that I refuse.

A sheer mountain lies ahead. I have had to stifle my shock at its sudden appearance, and at the perilous climb we must now undertake, for morale among the men is already low. I would not appear in my right mind as their leader if I asked them to turn and face the horrors of the desert we had all thought behind us. No. We climb. And meeting us at the summit, I believe, will be a view upon the shimmering water of a Northwest Passage that shall sate the hunger.
114599:
June 30th, 1848:

Lost my best man, Cdr. Sturgeon, in the mountains. Poor man was too anxious to prove me right. Some made it, but all hungry and desperate. You need shovel-loads to fuel your belly up here, and we have no food at all. There were grunts and growls in the night. Either we eat the resident bears, or they eat us.
114610:
August 3rd, 1848:

Sir John has entrusted me, Lt. Cdr. Remi Des Yeux, with the completion of his log, as he no longer has the strength to put pen to paper. Still, there likely won't be many more entries left for me to write.

We are no longer killed by bears, but have been lost days and weeks in high valleys that all look the same, having lost our compass. We are now only six: Captain John Faithful; Sargent, the first mate; Little, an engineer; Hodgson, an assistant surgeon; Irving, a ship's boy; and myself. The boy lives because he is a good lad, and none of us could suffer to eat of him. The bear meat never was going to last, you see. Sir John did have us swear never to speak of that shame, but who does he think we will tell?

114935: The explorers are understandably fed up with pemmican. Although bread wouldn't last a day in the Arctic, tunnbröd — a typical Northern flatbread — would be easy enough to cook on the fire and alleviate their craving, but it requires flour.
114936: Ah, I miss bread... Pemmican is convenient, but- hey, I know! We could make some tunnbröd! I've read about it — it should be easy enough to cook, if we had flour...
114938: The Arctic is dangerous enough without having to worry about slipping in a puddle of melted snow at every step. The explorer has asked you for felt, to line their soles and keep their feet in place.
114939: I learned my fair share of tricks back when I traversed the Pampas. Fishermen lined the soles of their boots with felt to stop them slipping. We could use anything that would help us stay in place!
114941: It looks like you may be staying in the Arctic for quite some time. In that case, the explorer has a suggestion to better insulate the floor of the camp from the cold: laying a thick layer of cement between it and the frozen ground.
114942: Will our mission in the Arctic last much longer...? If so, we might want to look into improving the thermal insulation of our tents. Cement is cold, but the frozen ground is colder!
114954: The explorer has asked you to bring some saltpetre. It looks like she has something in mind.
114955: The explorer's dear little brother is turning eleven! She has never once missed the celebration before, so she has asked you to take a picture of her family, to help her cope with the homesickness.
114956: From its endless dreamlike landscapes to its mighty predators, the explorer has grown fascinated by the Arctic. She has asked you to take a picture of one of its wonders, so she can keep the memory close to her heart once the adventure is over.
114960: The reality of the Arctic is very different to what the explorer had dreamt of. Still, she is determined to make her family proud. She has asked you to take a picture of her and her colleagues, and she will do her best to pose with her biggest smile.
114961: One of the passions the explorer has inherited from her father is sketching the fauna during her travels. There are some species she is still missing in her Arctic sketchbook. You can help her find them.

114963: The explorer wants people back home to know about the Inuit and their culture, so she has decided to leave the gift they gave her in your custody, to be displayed in one of your museums.
114965: I have an idea! Could you have a ship bring me some saltpetre?
114966: My family will be celebrating my little brother's birthday. If only I had a tiny window, so I could feel like I'm there at the pub with them... Could you bring me a picture?
114967: Harp seal pups are some of the most endearing creatures I've ever come across. Granted, they don't exude the most pleasant of smells, but you can't smell a photograph, can you?
114968: I wouldn't want to remember whales for the long hours we've spent elbow-deep in their blubber, but rather swimming free — gargantuan yet majestic — breaching off the icy ocean...
114969: Polar bears hold an enormous significance to the Inuit people. Not only are they essential for their subsistence, but they honor them as if they were human — nay, gods. Could you capture one for me? I-In a picture, of course!
114970: Icebergs are born when ice shelves break apart. A dazzling giant block of ice floating away — that's a sight I would love to keep with me for the rest of my days!
114971: Mother and father have been nothing but supportive of my dream of exploring the Arctic. Yes, it is tougher than I anticipated here, but I will not let them worry. They shall only see my beaming smile!
114972: My father drew the most beautiful wolves when he hiked through the fjords. I would like to make a sketch of my own, but I have yet to actually see one...
114973: It is pure arrogance to think we know more about the Arctic than the Inuit. They should be put in charge — of our administrations!
114974: If people back home knew half of what I've learned from the Inuit, they would stop acting as if they were better than them! Here — they gifted me this after I stayed with them for a fortnight: display it in a museum, and spread their culture!

115046: The technician wants his picture taken alongside his instruments and equipment, just in case his seismic contribution to science isn't given the attention it surely merits.
115047: I want my picture taken so that I receive due credit for this earth-shattering discovery. We are now a step closer to understanding how the world came into being, so naturally I deserve to be the centre of attention.

115165: The technician is amazed by the prehistoric human you found in the ice.

115189:
August 7th, 1848:

Sir John speaks again. He says the silhouette of a great wolf came to him in his sleep, and that he wishes to meet us.

Our pack is down to three. Sir John, the boy Irving, and me, Remi Des Yeux. We shall remember Sargent, Little and Hodgson. We shall remember the others who tripped and fell, who froze, who fell ill, who starved, who drowned, who were maimed by bears, who slipped on high, or fell through the cracks. And we shall remember those who, when we ran out of food, drew the short straw... in vain!

If a passage exists, we have not found it. But though he is mad, I will accompany Sir John to the end. The ferocious ship's boy, Irving, is our guardian spirit — the same who, with superhuman strength, was able to fend off grown men in the snow who were after his legs for supper.

116788: Lady Faithful has spotted the icebreakers.
116793: Lady Faithful rewards you for your progress.
116794: Qumaq warns you that visibility will be low in these conditions.
116795: Lady Faithful gives you funds to help clear the channel of ice.
116798: Lady Faithful gives you the funds to help build an airship.
116801: Lady Faithful is astounded at your achievement in building a hangar.
116803: Lady Jane is delighted to hand you the reward she promised.
116835: Dare you face the challenges of the Arctic? Venture to the edge of the world; conquer the most hostile of environments with a brand new heating system; build monumental hangars to claim the sky with your very own airships; and assist Lady Jane Faithful in her quest to find her husband, Sir John, and his lost expedition to the Northwest Passage...
116836: Conquer the Arctic's extreme conditions with new residents and production chains.
116837: Look for the Lost Expedition alongside new and familiar characters, like Lady Faithful, Old Nate, and the Inuit shaman Qumaq.
116838: Light up your megapolis with a much more efficient gas-fired power plant that doesn't require a railway connection!
116839: Construct your own airships and be the first to rise above your competitors!
116843: Qumaq has asked you to monitor the progress of a group of young hunters who have disappeared in the north.
116844: Ah, daring youth! The young hunters' search for seals began in the north.
116845: Find the young hunters in the north
116846: Follow the young hunters through the ice desert
116848: Qumaq has asked you to give three lamps life. A thick fog has fallen — the essence of a female giant. If all braziers are burning at the same time, the fog should lift, providing better conditions for sledding.
116849: The giant drank so much water, she literally burst open — and so, fog was born! Give the lamps life. Fire the old braziers in the ice, and the fog will lift for sledding!
116853: Qumaq wants you to track down a thief — for the thief's own safety as much as anything else.
116854: The thief ran into the mountains. I am worried for him. He's taken one of our best Umiaks, and many of our most precious things.
116858: The Inuit have asked you to track down a missing elder, who went to find some cranberries that grow on the far side of the mountain. Many Inuit are quite ill with sore throats, so they really need those berries!
116859: Everyone has bad sore throats. The elder went over the mountain for cranberries, but he hasn't returned. I am worried for him!
116867: For two years, Lady Jane Faithful has been preparing to find her husband's expedition, which got lost in the Arctic while looking for the Northwest Passage. She hopes you will agree to become the last and most crucial member of her rescue team, and is offering handsome rewards in exchange. But the journey will not be easy: if you don't want to meet the same fate as Sir John and his crew, you'd best prepare for a difficult expedition.
116871: You may have survived the journey to the Arctic and found Sir John's old camp, but the search for his lost expedition has only just begun. Lady Faithful has suggested establishing a base of operations at the place her husband picked to winter, before continuing the search from there.
116878: It's time to set up camp in the Arctic. As per usual, the first step is to provide some housing for the explorers, and a canteen for them to warm up between shifts.
116880: The Arctic cold is no small challenge. If you don't want your recruits to freeze to death, you'll have to keep them warm. Old Nate has devised a heating system that runs on coal, but watch out — that heat won't travel far!
116883:
Proposed locations for our research station:
Upon a cliff of ice east of here. Pros: Isolated. Cons: Melty.
In a curved depression near the top of a small mountain, northeast of here. Pros: The mountain will shield us from storms. Cons: Signs of human activity — we may be disturbed by the locals.
On the edge of an icy canyon to the north. Pros: I can throw Musgrave into the ravine if he interferes with my research again. Cons: Musgrave might have the same idea.
116884: Pick up and read the note to guess where they built the research center
116900: The log Sir John left in the abandoned camp mentions that the Inuit gave them directions. Perhaps if you found the Inuit, they would be willing to lead you to the lost crew.
116901: Thick ice has frozen the channel to the lost expedition. Lady Faithful has given you funds to equip a crack team of explorers, so they can blast a way through.
116902: Lady Faithful is keen to begin the operation.
116904: The channel the expedition took has now been cleared. Follow the route the expedition ships took deeper into the ancient ice.
116909: If you want to find the lost crew of HMS Hades and Styx, you're going to need airships. For that, you'll need technicians and an airship hangar.
116916: Now that your hangar is finished, you can construct your first airship — although you will need gas to inflate it. Just this once, Old Nate is willing to provide it for you.
116917: Old Nate provided you with enough gas to build your first airship — but if you want more, you'll have to extract it from the islands up north. Good thing you can travel by air now, because steep cliffs render them unreachable from the sea.
116922: Now that you have an airship to soar above the clouds, your search for the lost expedition can finally continue. Lady Faithful asks that you pick up the trail from their last known location: the abandoned HMS Hades and HMS Styx.
116926: Lady Faithful has taken a step back: it is now up to you and Qumaq to scout the vast northern ice cap from above in search of the lost expedition. Your first clues are the icebreakers they left behind, and the eerie tracks that lead away from them...
116961: Find Sir John Faithful's lost expedition to the Northwest Passage (The Passage).
116962: Complete 10 Inuit or arctic residents' quests (The Passage).
116963: Complete all the cultural sets from the Arctic (The Passage).
116964: Don’t build a charcoal kiln in the Arctic until you pass 1,000 technicians (The Passage).
116965: Having passed 500 technicians, turn off any heaters heating residences for 60 minutes (The Passage).
116966: Build one hangar on each of the 4 Arctic plateaus (The Passage).
117081: Pick up the lost cargo: [Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount]
117088: Old Nate recognises the scrap from the HMS Angry Wrath.
117089: Old Nate tells you to keep an eye out for more scrap from other failed expeditions.
117095: Newspaper effects do not affect residents of the Arctic.
117116: We shared stories on the ship. A gruff man said this was his second time sailing the Arctic — the first time around, his crew had to leave much of their equipment behind in order to make it out alive. Do you think it's still out there?
117117: The Arctic may seem barren, but it is no junkyard! Every bit of scrap left behind in the ice throws off the balance of this delicate environment! We can — no — we must collect and recycle as much of it as we can find!
117118: I always kept an eye on the newspapers for reports on the Arctic expeditions. Sadly, there were very few updates on most of them... Such a loss of resources! We should honour those brave explorers, and not let their efforts go to waste!
117175: Their eyes are listless, their faces gaunt and grey — Qumaq was right — the survivors barely look human anymore.
117176: The writings of Sir John Faithful upon his expedition's departure inland from the initial camp at King William Island.
117177: A team of hardened explorers, raring to shift the icy impediment between them and Sir John's expedition.
117178: A fragment of Sir John Faithful's logbook, from a fraught leg of the expedition.
117179: The explorer reminds you to take the scrap to Old Nate.
117180: We can't deliver newspapers all the way to the Arctic!
117211: The lost expedition's odyssey has finally come to an end. All that remains is to bring them safely back home, and collect your final reward.
117212: To start the expedition, go to the World Map and select the Passage Expedition.
117214: Click on the abandoned tents to remove them. This will take a little time.
117215: Pick up the marked object by left-clicking.
117216: You'll find the log in the Items section of your Trading Post.
117217: Sir John's log speaks of the whereabouts of the Inuit people. Read it carefully.
117218: When following a ship, you must stay within range, so as not to lose sight of it.
117220: You can build an airship at your brand new hangar. Use the gas Old Nate provided you with.
117221: Fly over an Arctic plateau with an airship loaded with enough timber and steel to build a Sky Trading Post.
117222: Zoom in to scan the terrain and look for tracks that may lead you to the lost expedition.
117223: Read the notes carefully to get more clues as to what happened to the crew, and where they were headed next.

117225: The charcoal kiln is already warmed up! You don't need to worry about building it within reach of a heater.
117227: Factories and shelters require heat. Make sure the heating system reach them.
117240: Yell "Nanuk" and your huskies might go faster.
117244: Scrap from bygone expeditions that ventured into the ice desert.
117254: Feel down? Tickle yourself with these.
117256: A light in the darkness. Smells.
117304: Stripped to the bare essentials, this new type of airship gondola will grant your zeppelin that extra bit of zip.
117305: Offers accelerated cargo loading and improved weight distribution for your skybound pride and joy.
117306: Island is not reachable by sea
117320: Keen to construct a research station in the far North, and understand recent strange phenomena.
117321: Not the popsicle flavour I'd choose...
117322:
Have a once-Pyrphorian flamethrower close at hand to light up that thing should it return! I spent the afternoon hosing Musgrave's superior collection of cacti with flame. I don't suppose he'll mind now, Musgrave, but he failed my little test. How was I to know if it was the real him?
I hear barking outside, yet all the huskies are dead! Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaah!
117360: Hardly more than a dream traced in the snow, for now. But the foundations of the hangar are ready to be ploughed and consolidated in reality — taking you one step closer to the clouds.
117361: The ice-cold steel structure of the hangar juts above the ground like the stranded carcass of a colossal whale. Yet one mustn't be fooled by the striking morbidness of the image: this whale will give birth to airships!
117362: The vast dome is nearly finished. Once the canvas roofing is stretched over the skeleton and the technical equipment installed, the assembly of airships will commence.

117420: Have you heard the rumours? They say a moose has been spotted near the mines! That would be an incredible addition to my sketchbook...
117421: There is one animal my father never got the opportunity to draw: the great polar bear. It would be the best gift I could ever give him if I found a model.

117463: Ovibos moschatus. Musk ox males emit a strong odor during the seasonal rut, hence the name.
117464: Rangifer tarandus. The largest of the caribou, this forest-dwelling species is extremely sensitive to human disturbance of their habitat.
117465: Pusa hispida. This small, earless seal is one of the pillars of life in the Arctic — known as nattiq by the Inuit.
117466: Ursus maritimus. Nanuk. A hypercarnivore adapted to the Arctic, who navigates sea ice in search of seals.
117467: Pagophila eburnea. This small polar gull has many vocalizations, including a warbling fox-call to warn about predators.
117468: Canis lupus arctos. Born an ashen grey, its coat turns white as it matures.

192828: This folder contains all pools used at the same time for trade pools, expedition pools and for quest reward pools. Please don't change them without keeping that in mind; Don't forget the item unlock; and don't include items that are supposed to be unique rewards for certain moments in the game. They are organized per rarity, per theme, and transversal pools for specific features are in "Additional Pools".

'If I am correct, the devotees gather to disperse the malefic spirit of envy. It would be excellent form for us to join in.' At which remark, the crew begin to look a little hesitant.

Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.

800157: Calico's Rogues Snare a Merchant Ship
800158: A helpless merchant brig is being pillaged by despicable pirates. Its captain is a friend to many of your crew, who are ready to die in order to save him. The pirates answer to Calico Roberts - the last terrible pirate - but the light is dim, and they have not noticed your ship.

As your ship steers into view with the new flag, the pirates do nothing. They fully believe you serve the same master! Your guns fire and surrender is quick. The merchants are grateful and offer considerable compensation!

800165: It's a good fight in which the crew hold their nerve. At first range-finding proves difficult, alerting the pirates to ready their own guns. He silently surveys the vessel for a torturous moment, before declaring 'it all seems above board.' Of course, as soon as he and his soldiers have disembarked, the crew of your ship collapse about in grievous relief.
800208: 'Save your breath, windbag,' says the Inspector, with an air of a man accustomed to weaselling. 'Show me the damn ship, or I shall become vexed!'
800209: 'You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,' the Inspector sneers, pointing to three unlucky sailors. 'Hang them,' he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
800210: 'You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,' the Inspector sneers, and points at your specialist. 'Hang this traitor,' he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
800228: The man spasms, eyes rolling, before finally falling unconscious. His mania had come suddenly, with eight men needed to pacify, and bind him to the mast. Some say he is possessed by daemons and must be done rid of. The officers, less credulous, seek a surer explanation. The only way to silence a worsening quarrel, is to find a solution.
800229: Enlist the aid of the hypnotist
800230: Examine the cause of this wildness in him
800231: Try to calm the crew, and pray the man recovers
800232: Guard him round the clock in his cabin
800233: Ignore the officers and get rid of him before it's too late
800234: The crew are delighted the man has returned to his normal self. The hypnotist used a pendulum to induce him into deep sleep, before imparting subliminally, some choice words. Within days the fellow is happily back at work. All are buoyant that such a severe case was so artfully cured!
800235: It is a superb recovery in the circumstances. The examination uncovers a bluish contusion under the hair. 'We are to act swiftly or he shall die!' says the doctor, as he bores a drill into the man's cranium. Once the blood is drained, the resultant hole is covered with a silver coin, and the head beswaddled with bandages. The man is fully recovered within a few days, and the crew greatly impressed by the actions of the doctor.
800236: The whole examination takes too long, 'though a bluish contusion is found under the hair. 'I must act or he shall soon die!' gulps the doctor, but then proceeds to faff nervously through a medicine bag, until the poor man dies on the operating table. 'You did the best you could,' a colleague offers, but there is a hollowness to it.
800237: The patient grabs the doctor's head and smashes it against the table. The doctor was tapping his knee to check reflex, when the devil cut loose. 'He wants putting out of his misery,' a sailor cries, once the man is wrestled to the deck again. So they cut his throat. Attention turns to the doctor, but he is a doctor no more. Injury has rendered him insensible; an eight-year-old boy trapped in the body of a man!
800238: Hellish horror ensues, as the doctor insists on checking if 'ought is stuck in the throat'. As he prises open the lion's jaws, the daemon creature lurches up into his throat. So frenzied is this vampiric assault, that there is little the crew can do but to raise their pistols to the gruesomeness. When the gunsmoke clears, doctor and patient lie dead, entwined and contorted beneath a bloody dew.
800239: The crew are convinced by the chaplain that god has a plan for this man. They agree to bind him to his bed while the chaplain prays for his fast recovery. After two weeks he still suffers gaps in his memory, and a paralysis of the face, but thanks are given to the lord above that he is otherwise his usual self.
800240: The sailors are partially convinced there is a spiritual explanation for his deranged behaviour, but insist on chaining him to his bed. 'He must have done something terrible in the eyes of God,' they say. Despite all hope for his fast recovery, he dies not two days later, his malady forever a mystery.
800241: The faithless crew will not trust this to God, but can neither agree if the possessed man should be thrown to sea, as desired by the sailors, or permitted a chance to see out his ordeal, as demanded by the officers.
800242: Side with the officers and warn the sailors to cooperate
800243: Convince the officers of the needs of the many
800244: The sailors would not dare mutiny, of course, and return to their stations. At first they fear the bed-ridden man will commit some terrible act while they sleep. But they need not have worried, since he dies of the unexplained malady not two days later.
800245: The sailors are outraged and their response is immediate. In greater numbers they overwhelm and restrain the officers, while the sickly subject of their fury is bound and thrown into the deep. Confidence in the leadership of the expedition is undermined and the possibility of further trouble seems never far away.
800246: No officer can deny the logic of the argument, yet, when the man is bound and thrown overboard they cannot help but show their grief it is for no fault of his own, and that none had knowledge with which to better help him.
800247: 'It's a bally disgrace! You dishonour a gentleman!' say the officers, as the man is bound and thrown overboard, 'such incompetence shall be reported to the highest authority!' Not only is a man lost, but the expedition brought into disrepute.
800248: There was little for the guards to report, bar occasionally 'quelling the mad dog' with liquor. After a fortnight, the poor man recovers with no recollection of anything, and while his hand is partially paralysed, he is still able to perform his usual duties.
800249: The damn guards are found with sacks over their heads. They swear they did not see their attacker, but weakly-tied hands suggest collusion. Of course the patient's bed is vacant, and he seems to be missing, permanently. After that, rumours circulate, and no-one seems to have any trust in anyone else.
800250: The officers react with disgust to your decision to toss him overboard, and state in no uncertain terms that the whole matter will be reported. But the sailors are quite obviously relieved that his demonic presence has been exorcised.
800254: After weeks of hot weather, supplies of drinking water have become dangerously low. It therefore seems a minor miracle when a fellow ship appears on the horizon, for surely they have water to share? But as it draws near, the crew are aghast, for there is no sign of life aboard. 'It is a ghost ship, we must flee before it is too late!' they cry.
800255: Send a diver to check it out
800257: Leave and hope to find an island with drinking water soon
800258: The diver does remarkably to spot the fiends furled in sails, or waiting under barrels to ambush, should your men have boarded. Your ship draws alongside the vessel as if to pass, but then unleashes enough cannon-fire to drown it. The crew are elated, believing they have done the oceans a great service.
800259: Heavens shine upon you, for whatever caused the crew to vacate this ship seems no longer a concern. Better yet, the lord has seen fit to provide the water you seek.
800260: The ship's hold contains an unholy mound of corpses. 'God hath forsaken these men', says the doctor, 'but how?'
800261: The crew are so faithless, that every creaking plank aboard the ghostly ship raises a whimper. So when a banshee howl erupts from below deck, every sailor runs for their life. One poor soul trips in a coil of rigging and cracks their head upon an iron capstan. The death exposes all the more the crew's foolishness.
800262: Have the doctor investigate what happened
800264: 'We are lucky indeed, for malaria cannot reach us now.' says the doctor confidently. This swift diagnosis confirms the crew are pleased to load up the drinking water they have been gasping for.
800265: 'Touch nothing! Get off the ship,' frets the doctor, who believes a dreadful plague has taken the crew of this ill-fated vessel. Perhaps drinking water is itself the cause. The crew are miserable time has been wasted, and that their thirst is still not slaked.
800266: The doctor is inconsolable, 'it is plague. I lanced a bubo, and it ruptured suddenly upon my person!' That the water be contaminated is misery enough, but to have to abandon the good doctor is a disaster! Your expedition drifts glumly on.
800267: No relief at escaping the grotesque mound of corpses, can compensate the terrible thirst of your crew. There are murmurings that no such expedition can succeed if 'gift horses always be looked in the mouth.'
800268: No relief at escaping the disturbingly empty ship, can compensate the terrible thirst of your crew. There are murmurings that no such expedition can succeed if 'gift horses always be looked in the mouth.'
800269: Terrifyingly, the ship takes after yours in pursuit. Who knows what dread hands operate its multifarious controls!
800270: Try to outrun the awful vessel!
800271: Turn and face it, whatever it is!
800272: Your ship manages to escape the ghoulish clutches of that unwholesome adversary, but have no drinking water, or anything else, to show for the ordeal.
800273: Your ship is not agile enough. Men pour into the waves from where enemy cannons punch holes. Seemingly contented with this sacrifice, the dread sentience commanding the vessel calls off its dreadful pursuit.
800274: Pirates! But trickery cannot match the power of a modern seaship! Summarily demolished, a few of them are left clinging to wreckage. They beg to join your cause - unpaid. Such are the dwindling prospects of piracy in this day! The crew will jibe at them, but secretly all must be elated to have acquired such sea-wisdom for free.
800275: A pirate nuisance! Though their scurvy deception gives them advantage, they are like many of their creed, rather jaded. By the time their ship is sunk, it has cost you a few good men. Yet the recovery of precious drinking water in among the flotsam, assuages the grief of your crew.
800276: Bloody pirates! A terrible menace even in this day and age! Your crew are outmanoeuvred, outsmarted, and your ship is reeled-in for boarding. Many are killed in valiant defence of the company, but to no avail. Your vessel is duly ransacked for supplies, before the villains are again on their way.
800280: 'A fearsome predator stalks us!' the cabin-boy whispers. Perhaps he is right, for this resupply has not been as uneventful as hoped. Only the first evening moored in this bay, and a man goes missing - tracks up the beach into jungle. Many wonder how work can be expected to continue...
800286: With the perfect lure placed enticingly in the crook of a tree, there is an inevitability about a capture. Sure enough, yellow eyes pierce the darkness, and a mighty beast pads softly over to the bait. A net is hurriedly cast about it and secured, thus leaving the expedition free to resupply unthreatened.
800287: Your huntmasters are expert, and trace with great care, the soft hollows imprinted by feline paw. Led to a clearing, they correctly judge this to be a lair, where they stand ready with a net. When the cat returns, heaving hot breath, the hunters pounce. With net secure, the expedition is free to resupply unthreatened.
800288: At least one hunter did the right thing, and kept his eyes open while they traced the beast's pawprints. Another was not so wise, and was heard to let out a scream. His comrades were drawn to the spot, and struck the majestic beast down. But not before the damage was done.
800289: Three days pass, and still no word. There is a common feeling something must be done to save those men.
800293: It is only something of a relief when the rescue party return. It's bad news... the hunters are dead. The rescue party described the bright and long-maned beast, and how in a tussle, they slayed it. With the bodies of the hunters buried, the expedition is able to resupply in an atmosphere of respectful silence.
800294: 'Horror! It's picking us off one by one!' bawls a fearful sailor, for now the rescue party too, have failed to return. There is nothing for the disconsolate remainder of the crew to do, but leave this sorry place behind.
800295: Doubtful prayer brings no news of the lost hunters. The men have nowhere to look for guidance, and there is a burdensome feeling that a decision must be made.
800296: Conviction in the lord is of little use here, it seems. Two days later a hunter, whose leg is mangled, limps back into view. After the necessary amputation, he is heard to groan that the others perished. All must leave this savage place.
800297: 'We leave them for dead, when they could be right there now waiting for us!' cries a furious old tar. Like so many others, he is disgusted that good men should give their lives for nothing but impatience!
800298: 'Absurd magic, but it works!' say officers sent to the inland village for help. Having described the beast, they were referred to a witch. She encouraged them to ingest live scorpions, one of each colour; yellow, red and black. This they did reluctantly, but found when they confronted the animal, it took flight. All promptly follow the witch's advice, and sure enough, remain undisturbed for the remainder of the resupply.
800299: 'Our plight means nothing to the locals,' bemoan the officers sent as diplomats. 'Telling them beasts stalk the jungle, is as like alerting a hatter to the presence of hats on his hatstands.'
800300: 'Their deity is desecrated!' urges the officer sent as diplomat. All around the bay, daubed faces appear, bows raised to the expedition camp.
800303: 'A hollow victory', say the men. For the locals lie dead, but the jungle beast stalks on.
800304: Odds against them, the men fight as best they can. Fought back onto the sand, they deflect the rain of arrows with whatever they can lay hands on. A relay is able to return precious equipment to the ship and set sail, but not without a number of casualties, of whom some do not make it.
800305: The onslaught is deadly. Few among your crew have the requisite experience to defend themselves, and so the sand reddens with their blood. Of those who make it as far as the expedition ship, a number succumb to the poison-tip arrows. It is a massacre.
800306: 'Run!' comes the panicked cry. The men drop their work, and tramp desperately through the shallows to the ship. A volley of arrows pierces three, squirting crimson into the clear blue. 'Dead aside, we have lost a great deal more in provisions than we have gained,' laments the quartermaster, as your ship departs that wretched bay.
800307: The ingenious powers of the craftsmen among your crew have fashioned a pitfall for the beast. There is not long to wait before there is a tinkle on the handbell, and all can gather above the trap to see the monster growling at its bottom. The resupply may now happily proceed, knowing that danger is averted.
800308: The beast is too intelligent to fall for makeshift traps. It is clearly evading the pitfall prepared by those supposed to be the expedition's deftest craftsmen. 'Little more we can do,' they shrug.
800309: 'It's a considerable setback,' say senior officers. Fresh water, wood for burning, plants for medicine - it does no good to list what myriad opportunities are missed in bypassing the bay. And all for the sake of fears over one measly wild animal.
800313: 'It's too narrow and shallow this far upriver!' warns the steersman. Escorting Mr. Cardinale to the site of his rainforest opera house now seems all the more preposterous! The great patron of the arts twizzles his moustache in frustration! Apart from braving the difficulty ahead, only traversing a nearby hill might reconnect the expedition with the upper river.
800314: Use your gunboat to navigate the shallows
800315: Have the ship transported over the hill to rejoin the river further up
800316: Attempt to carefully navigate the narrow passage
800317: Decline to proceed any further and return to sea
800318: The design of the gunboat is vital to your success. Being of moderate size, and yet possessing the manoeuvring capabilities of a much smaller ship, the gunboat is able to navigate the awkward river shallows with ease. Mr. Cardinale is delighted that you have delivered him to the site of his proposed Opera House, and promises to talk favourably of each and every man when he returns to civilisation.
800319: 'What a champion performance!' squeals Mr. Cardinale, from the comfort of his cushioned chair. The great ship seems to swim up and over the hill. The long timbers on which it rolls, and corkscrew winches at intervals up the slope work perfectly. 'I shall put in a good word for you all at the club,' promises Cardinale, as the ship splashes down safely on the other side. The men are immensely proud of the miracle they have performed.
800320: Getting a ship over a hill is mad, but it works. 'Is this absolutely necessary?' muses Mr. Cardinale, having watched the crew slip for a week in mud. But the rolling timbers and makeshift winches they have crafted prove adequate, and the ship finally scrapes down the other side, into the upper river. Mr. Cardinale barely offers a word of thanks, perturbed perhaps, by the indignity of it all.
800321: There simply aren't enough materials to conduct such an elaborate enterprise. The crew think with a few extra bits and bobs, dragging the ship up the hill might be possible.
800322: 'I think it's going to give way!' cries the terrified Mr. Cardinale. The feet of your men slip and slide on the mudstrewn slope, as the great weight of the ship plummets it back down the hill. Many try to get out of the way, but are crushed beneath the keel. A hideous accident caused by inadequate materials, that signals the end of Cardinale's operatic ambitions.
800323: Proceed uphill without materials, belief will guide us through
800324: Ask the locals gathered around the scene if they are able to help
800325: The men have the conviction to safely hoist the ship up and over the hill. It is a fatiguing week, but belief in making the impossible possible possesses them. When the ship finally splashes into the water, Mr. Cardinale has barely a Christian word of thanks for the crew. It has taken a long enough after all.
800326: It is all going so well, this mad idea, with winches and cables scarcely sufficient for the task. But exertion eventually tells. As the ship rocks over the crest of the hill, there is not enough to keep it there, and it hurtles wildly down the other side. It is lucky the ship is not swept away in the river current. Still, it sustains significant damage from impact with the trees.
800327: 'I think it's going to give way!' cries the terrified Mr. Cardinale. The feet of your men slip and slide on the slope, as the unholy weight of the ship overcomes the winches, and it plummets back down the hill. Men try to get out of the way, but are crushed beneath the keel. The hideous accident signals the end of Cardinale's operatic ambitions.
800328: The locals are willing to provide help and materials. While it takes the crew time to incorporate the materials into their winch design, the locals are happy to wait. Good relations make the feat of hoisting a ship over a hill less painful than it might have been. The boat finally clatters down into the water of the upper river. All are most grateful to the locals, without whom none of this would have been possible.
800329: A few locals vaguely offer to help, but their lukewarm efforts do little to relieve the exhausted crew. The ridiculous hill-climb takes more than a week. When the ship finally slips into the water over the other side, not even Mr. Cardinale has energy enough to care.
800330: The locals have absolutely no interest in helping you, and fade into the trees. Beleaguered by shouts from Mr. Cardinale, the men meekly follow orders. The mad persistence has disastrous consequences. The ship plummets back down the hill! Many try to get out of the way, but are crushed beneath the keel. The hideous accident signals the end of Cardinale's operatic ambitions.
800331: Competent navigation rescues your ship from the mother of all rivers. Mr. Cardinale is tremulous throughout, believing his dreams may beach like a river dolphin at any time. But over the course of three tricky days, information is relayed quickly enough between wheel and forecastle to avoid any harmful collisions. There is relief all around when the corner is made and the river broadens again.
800332: 'Rapids?!' exhales Mr. Cardinale crossly. Ahead white water churns. There is nothing for it but to push on. As the ship strains against the current, there are dreadful noises from rocks on the keel. The crew wince at each and every thump and screech. Finally, after a week, the river broadens again, and the crew can inspect the damage - it doesn't look good.
800333: It is a heart-breaking experience. Days go by in the effort to lever the ship out of the sandy shallows, where it does not belong. It is battered by rocks and rapids, and leaks like a rusted bucket. Mr. Cardinale kicks up and awful fuss. Finally when it feels like progress is being made, the next bend reveals a harrowing sight - an insurmountable waterfall! Never have the crew felt more hopeless.
800334: Mr. Cardinale is incensed that his grand plans for the rainforest Opera House have been thwarted. Some of the men find his blustering funny, but the officers are horrified that such an influential figure has been rebuffed, and are afraid to show their faces in society ever again.
800337: At the cry of 'mines!', all rush to the prow. Sure enough, several of the conical terrors bob seductively below. 'Who knows how many of these infernal machines have passed us by, or yet await us. A false move, and this sea shall be a lake of fire! What the devil do we do?'
800338: Use dynamite to start a chain reaction
800339: 'The way ahead is clear as the eye can see!' says the delighted officer, folding up his telescope. As the last motes of fire trail down into the waves and fizzle, the crew can but admire such brave use of dynamite. 'Better than fireworks!' says another, 'The men have never been so entertained!'
800341: 'We are masters of the sea!' sing the triumphant crew, as the ship weaves easily beyond the last line of mines. 'Even Odysseus, when faced with Scylla and Charybdis, lost men. We have lost none of our company, and our bonds only strengthen!' Soon, a special bottle is being uncorked, and toasts raised to the continued success of the expedition!
800342: 'What was that noise?' gulps the helmsman, but fortunately a metallic scraping is not the prelude to a mighty boom. As the ship is fitfully steered betwixt the mines, hearts palpitate, and sailors wring sweat from their jerseys. When the all clear is finally given, there is not a sailor who fails to offer up a prayer to their goddess.
800343: While at first plain sailing, the minefield is now gooey with danger. A line of densely-packed mines stand between the ship and freedom. "With a makeshift device, we might be able to clear the path ahead," explains the officer, "either that, or we just try our best to weave through it."
800344: The awfulness has barely begun. Restless waves conceal a thickening of the mines, and the ship's haphazard path makes impact inevitable. 'Brace!' scream port-side, just prior to a portion of men and timber being propelled violently upward. That no further detonations follow is of little relief to a crew who have lost many good sailors, and sustained such significant damage to their ship.
800349: 'She survived! It worked!' calls the lookout, as makeshift grapples trailing behind the little dinghy are able to hook the mines aside. Relief only comes, of course, once the expedition ship is clear of this last line of mines. 'How did we get in such a pickle?' says one. 'At least we're out of it,' says another.
800350: A nervous sailor rows towards the line of mines. The makeshift grappling hooks trailing behind his dinghy are intended to drag mines out of the path of the expedition ship. Unfortunately the sailor is a sacrificial goat. A grapple shatters the horns of a nearby mine, and the boat and its sailor explode in plume. Safe passage means nothing to those from whom a good friend was taken.
800351: The idea is a terrible one from the start. The lengthy poles, comprised of other poles, are unwieldy and inaccurate, even in the hands of a several strong men. The crew's attempt to poke mines away when they draw near is suicide. Two booms come in succession, and a few feeble cheers at escape are drowned by the deafening wails. Few are left to bail water, when so many lie dead or injured.
800352: Go through diplomatic papers in search of any clues
800353: The search is a fruitful one. The well-organised diplomatic library includes a comprehensive folio of papers on nearby mine positions. This enables the navigators to chart a safe course through the waters. The very same paper remarks that the mines were moored during the war, in order to protect a now-disused outpost. You stop by the outpost and pick up anything that looks useful.
800354: The search is worthwhile. After a few hours scouring the diplomatic archives, a paper on nearby mine positions is found. This gives the navigators the difficult task of charting a safe course through the waters. No-one is quite sure if the information given is up-to-the-minute, but when the last line of mines is cleared, all are suitably relieved.
800355: The documents in the ship archives at first seem exact. A map is discovered showing the mine positions. It is only once a course has been plotted, and your ship is sailing at speed on its supposedly safe track, that a magnificent bang has the whole crew scrambling. The speed seemed to soften the mine's devastation, but there is still a nasty hole in the hull. A second glance at the map shows it is rather out-of-date. The reckless blunder has cost no lives, but the significant task of repair greatly wearies the crew.
800356: Optimism makes way for abject terror, as the map of mines that is found and used for navigation turns out to be completely false. Terrible detonations devastate the ship's timbers, and countless lives are lost. 'Misinformation is worse than no information,' an officer laments, as his tears bleed the ink of the erroneous chart, which as it happens, refers to a different stretch of water.
800357: Turn around and try to escape
800358: A few saintly volunteers approach, offering to scout back the way you came and ease your escape. Asked if they aren't afraid of the cone-shaped mines, they reply 'The lord will see us through.'
800360: Tell them to stay on the ship
800361: The volunteers exude calm, as their lone dinghy traces a path much akin to that which got you into this mess. Although their silent vigil transports you to safety, all agree they should never have ended up in a minefield in the first place.
800362: While the path the volunteers cut is a true one, it does not account for the difference in size between the two ships. It only takes a narrow graze to explode one of the mines, and though no lives are lost, the damage to your ship is significant. The crew are dismayed by the situation.
800363: For the godless dinghy, doom seems inevitable the moment it drops and a man slops overboard. This inauspicious beginning foreshadows the disaster to follow. Prayers unheard, steering in the rough current proves impossible. The little boat is last seen careening towards the sinister cones it sought to avoid. 'The terrible loss of life shall remain with me all my days,' says a devastated officer.
800364: It is horrifying that most significant members of the crew are aboard this fragile dinghy. Of course one would not wish a mine to explode any loyal man, but when it bellows up below a collection of your finest, death stings all the more. The crew are understandably devastated at the destruction they have witnessed first-hand. Life feels as if it may never be the same again.
800365: Your faith goes untried in the nervous silence, as the ship escapes the mine trap the same way it entered. All agree they should never have ended up in a minefield in the first place.
800366: Your faith does not go untried. The sinister cones have moved about over time, and no matter how truly the ship follows its original course, it is inevitable a mine will burst into the hull. Luckily when the blast comes, no man dies. Still, the burdensome schedule of repair disheartens the crew.
800367: None of it is of any use. Your godforsaken crew do not realise how the sinister cones move about over time. No matter how true the course, more than one mine shakes the ship's belly as it limps clear. Many lives are lost, and the damage to the ship is severe.
800396: You found a tourist that offers to trade with you.
800441: You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
800448: You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
800454: You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
800460: You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
800468: A matter of the heart. The crew have been enjoying some island hospitality, but many are now refusing to leave. They have fallen in love with the sons and daughters of the local king. Perhaps he can be convinced to allow them to come with you? You can attempt to come to an arrangement, or else wait for him to consult his copper oracle.
800471: Convince the king your crew's affection is genuine
800472: Await the verdict of the copper oracle
800473: Leave without the crew who've fallen in love
800474: The king is not only surprised, but moved to tears by the romantic composers he hears via the gramophone. He insists on a grand banquet to celebrate the union of his children and your crew. Both traditional music and a few cranks of the new-fangled gramophone accompany the beautiful ceremony, and then its bon voyage!
800475: The king is delighted to see his children wed. Delicate understanding of local custom and a smattering of their language allow a message of true love to be conveyed. The king evidently thinks his children in good hands. Feasting, and to the amusement of all, terrible dancing, follows. For his departing children, it shall be the longest, most fascinating honeymoon.
800476: Something is lost in translation. Yet the king smiles benignly, as if your crew still have a chance to prove themselves. 'He suggests a great hunt,' says your diplomat, 'or else we may await arcane judgment.' His eyes flick to a copper oracle on a dais.
800477: The awkward gestures and diagrams in the sand prove highly offensive to the king and his people. Sensing outrage, the crew back away towards the ship. The angry locals fire arrows at their former amours. Fittingly, one is struck in the heart, and bleeds out into the brine. The rest return lovelorn, to their dreary maps and compasses.
800478: Capture the king a prize animal
800479: Face the verdict of the copper oracle
800480: The hunt goes quite well. Beautiful boars inhabit the woods, and though tricky to catch, are little trouble for your experts. Though the king will still not allow you to leave with his children, the feast of boar brings everyone together in the moment. The lovers understand this moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.
800481: The hunt is not perfect. The crew show courage in pursuit of a tiger, which draws the king's admiration. Sadly, they cannot catch it, which leaves the king wondering if your men will be able to provide once married. Thus, he decides not to let his children leave. Some of your crew remain committed to staying behind, and it is with regret you must continue without them.
800482: Your naive hunters fail the test. Forest deer are everywhere, and hunting them hardly seems a challenge. Had your so-named 'hunters' any respect for nature, they'd have realised the sacred deer were not what the king was after. Instead they gather them up greedily. The king makes it perfectly clear your expedition must move on. With heavy hearts, the sailors return to the ship.
800483: The oracle predicts a reassuring fate for all. Those who wish to remain for love will live fulfilling lives, but the same shall be true for those still committed to your expedition. All parties feel a sense of peace. Your voyage shall continue without any resentment towards those it leaves behind.
800484: The copper oracle is disappointingly undecided. The king cannot, in good faith, allow his children to leave to an uncertain destiny. His ultimatum is that your crew become part of his extensive family or else they must leave alone. Though understandable, it is nevertheless regrettable when some decide to stay behind.
800485: The copper oracle predicts that your souls cannot be saved. With your crew rotten to the core, the king makes it clear there can be no union with his children, and that you are no longer welcome. Heart-broken and bearing the burden of sin, the crew return to the triviality of duty.
800486: The copper oracle sees only purity in your crew's hearts. It predicts a bounteous future for the king's children, and so with tearful pride, he gives the couples his blessing. The traditional ceremony is both spiritually uplifting and wholesome.
800487: The copper oracle reveals a little doubt in your crew's hearts. The king interprets that his children will only be happy if they remain on the island., and that some of your sailors are not in love, but merely infatuated. Still, you must lose the fine crew who have formed genuine bonds.
800488: The copper oracle reveals great doubt in your crew's hearts. The king does not for a minute believe that your inconstant crew are as deep in love as they claim. If they cannot demonstrate otherwise, it might be better if your people left.
800489: The copper oracle proclaims your crew's hearts sinful and wicked. Arm-in-arm with their new-found amours, the sailors await some happy answer. But the moment the king's arm is raised, daggers unsheathe, plunging into the hearts of the would-be lovers. Speechless and unharmed, the rest are free to leave the island, pondering the grave cost of faithlessness.
800490: Try to convince the king your crew are worthy
800491: Order the crew to leave at once
800492: Careful diplomacy has him thinking twice. Perhaps there is a way for the crew to prove themselves. A lean champion steps forward. Fighting him may impress the king, or else you can try and outhunt him.
800493: The king is offended by your insolence. Without a word he boards a boat and heads out to sea. Some foolishly follow, believing he can be reasoned with, but they have even less knowledge of local boats than local customs. Their bodies will be dredged from the reef as your tactless expedition struggles on.
800496: You have your champions. One-by-one the suitors fight the king's champion. Those who prevail, it turns out, are permitted to take their lovers to sea. Some fail, but can at least drown their sorrows during the farewell celebration that follows.
800497: It is not a pleasant sight for the faint of heart. Your best champion is put forward, and subsequently knocked about the head for the entirety of the contest. At the end a cloth is needed to conceal the disfigured face. The king expresses his condolences for your loss, but all is fair in love and war.
800498: It is close but the king's champion is outfoxed. By sundown your best hunter has claimed six boars to their five. The king will still not allow you to leave with his children, but the feast of boar brings everyone together in one moment. The lovers understand a moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.
800499: Lacking the skill, your hunters try to cheat. Without knowledge of the island's fauna, they decide to follow the king's hunters in the hope of poaching the animal they are tracking. But they are led a merry dance. Three days pass, and your champion is missing presumed dead. The crew have no choice but to depart, tail between their legs.
