They have quite a headstart, but you might catch them if you give chase. Alternatively, as few harbours nearby will grant them sanctuary, you can try to anticipate their likely heading.
801666: Let them run, and instead try to establish their likely destination.
801668: "There! We have them," your navigator smiles. "See? Here." Their finger traces a route behind Ventura island. "Remarkable how few options they have. Montoya is the only port they might blend in at for fifty leagues." Sure enough, you intercept one of the tiny vessels off Montoya's twinkling bay. It may be no match for your own ship, but to sink them outright risks losing that precious contract to the water.
801671: Crackerjack! The perfect shot. Though a slender target, the mast snaps through, burying its operators in debris, and leaving the boat dead in the water. With the freedom of their ship, your crew find an ingenious-looking machine, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. As it's no longer on board, you're certain it must have changed hands in nearby Montoya, and make a beeline for the port.
801672: Only a partial success, as the fire forces the Pyrphorians to turn to face you. Sensing they might still have a chance in a fight, the Pyrphorians prime what few small dragon cannons they have. Your crew must act quickly.
801673: Miles off! Your novice gunners are so desperate to avoid striking the enemy in any meaningful way, a small, inoffensive patch of sea ends up taking the brunt instead. Sensing their tiny ship is a match for yours after all, the Pyrphorians pump flame from their dragon cannons, and give your ship a good licking. The ensuing panic provides the cover they need to slip away. You'll no doubt pick up their trail again in the port of Montoya, but the fire has caused significant damage that must be repaired first.
801674: Swing over to their ship and get among them
801675: Continue to target the mast and rigging
801676: Woomph! Your brutes descend like gibbons on lianas. The few cultists aboard are ruthlessly dispatched. With the freedom of their ship, your crew find some arcane Pyrphorian devices, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. As it's no longer on board, you're certain it must have changed hands in nearby Montoya, and make a beeline for the port.
801677: What a rabble! Like some arrhythmic jingle of bell-ringers, your thugs mistime their swings, falling into the channel between the two vessels. The Pyrphorians make their escape, but you know where they're headed. If your crew manage to recover both themselves and their dignity, you'll make a beeline for the port of Montoya.
801678: It works this time. With a shorter range to your target, your competent cannoneers have no trouble picking out the mast. It buries the enemy in debris, and leaves the sail-less boat adrift. With the freedom of their ship, your crew find some arcane Pyrphorian devices, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. Knowing it can only have changed hands in nearby Montoya, you make a beeline for the port.
801679: The Pyrphorian ship is agile. "Never seen an enemy move like that," explains one of your cannoneers, as if to avoid some weeping confession of his inexperience. Sensing they may be a match after all, the Pyrphorians use what firepower they have to give your ship a fair lick of flame. The ensuing panic provides the cover they need to slip away. You'll no doubt pick up their trail again in the port of Montoya, but the fire has caused damage that must be repaired first.
801681: Your crew lick their lips. You thought they seemed the type to enjoy tussles at close quarters, and so it proves. Cloaks drop all around, and with them dead the ship is yours. Your crew find an ingenious-looking machine aboard, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. Knowing it can only have changed hands in nearby Montoya, you make a beeline for port.
801682: Your sailors cannot disguise what they intend. As your ship readies to join theirs at the hip, the Pyrphorians yank night palls away to reveal a line of signature dragon guns. They will burn anyone who tries to come near...
801683: Snipe the cannon operators one by one
801685: The cowled figures fall like beetles swept from a window ledge. Your marksmen pause to survey the scene, "A fearful desire, these Pyrphorians have, to die for their cause..." says one wistfully. Picking through their ship reveals some arcane Pyrphorian devices, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. Knowing it can only have changed hands in nearby Montoya, you make a beeline for the port.
801686: The shot seems to pass through them, as if beneath their mask and cloak, their bodies are incorporeal, or perhaps your marksmen are drunk. Either way, it allows the Pyrphorians to turn and catch a strong westerly squall. They are halfway to the bay of Montoya before your sailors can reposition. You'll have to rely on picking up their trail when you get there.
801687: Train your main guns on their cannons
801688: Destructive, but effective. A shot explodes onto the Pyrphorian deck, and the weighty flame cannons drop through the boards. With the freedom of the ship, your crew find some arcane Pyrphorian devices, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. Knowing it can only have changed hands in nearby Montoya, you make a beeline for the port.
801689: Your fool cannoneers sank them! Exactly what they weren't supposed to do. Several miserable hours are spent combing the soggy wreckage, with no sign of the contract. "You won't find it," a bloody-mouthed Pyrphorian grins, but his dying taunt is a clue. He implies the contract changed hands before you intercepted the ship. Being the only haven for miles around, you set a course for the port of Montoya.
801690: Your soldiers lack initiative, and it is the Pyrphorians who swing aboard your ship, brandishing torches and firing elegant pocket pistols. Though their zeal cannot be matched, they are outnumbered. By the time they are subdued, they have pinned two, and burned many others. The accomplices in their boat are already halfway to Montoya. Once your groaning survivors have been gauzed-up, you might still find them there.
801691: "Hmmn..." your navigator mumbles awkwardly, realising he has proposed almost every one of the myriad small harbours in the region. Someone coughs. Perhaps all these officers have been summoned to the cabin merely to share in his humiliation? "We've lost them then...", a skeptic pipes up, addressing the elephant in the room. "So what now?! Search every harbour?! Solicit a friendly local power for help?!!"
801692: Check every nearby harbour in the hope of finding them
801693: The clouds finally part over Montoya. Your crew had been about to give up, until by chance, one of them caught sight of a ship. Moored in a secluded corner of the bay, it is the empty, but unmistakable property of the shadowy Pyrphorians you pursued. The contract must still be somewhere here in Montoya.
801694: Needles and haystacks. You exhaust all feasible harbours. Not only is there no sign of your quarry, there is no method of knowing whether they have been and gone from a place, or if they were never there at all. The sea seems godless, wide and deep, and the crew long for it to swallow them up. Instead, however, they must return to Miss Hannah Goode, to explain their failure.
801695: Appeal to nearby local authorities for information
801696: You're made to wait in line. Your diplomats may have done well to remember this local crest as one loyal to the crown, but you are not the only envoys present. Daiquiris, bananas and soft furnishings are small compensation for the time lost. Despite these formalities, the prefect transpires to be loyal. He intimates that Montoya is the only nearby place he has knowledge of that the Pyrphorians have their claws into. You cross your fingers, and head there yourself.
801697: "They must have been in league with the Pyrphorians!" wails your duped diplomat. Having failed to detect local complicity— rooted either in fear or allegiance — your diplomat insists you sail south along the coast. Your expedition continues diligently for three days in that direction without sighting a single human settlement. "Since you're so fine with words," says the lieutenant to the diplomat in question, "perhaps you should explain our failure to Miss. Hannah Goode!"
801698: Trust your lookouts to keep you in range
801699: The lookout never loses them, despite the vessel being nearly out of sight. As its small grey outline rounds an island, the lookout gestures excitedly to starboard. He's seen the golden thread of an inlet which would let you cut the nose off the cape, and intercept the Pyrphorians on the other side.
801700: Take a shortcut via the inlet
801701: You emerge right on top of them! Swinging masterfully through the stone jaws that gate the inlet, your navigators traverse a fantasy lagoon. Bursting beyond it into the bay, the ambush is received with complete surprise. With the freedom of the Pyrphorian ship, your crew find an ingenious-looking machine, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. As it's no longer on board, you're certain it must have changed hands in nearby Montoya, and make a beeline for the port.
801702: It's clear now why the Pyrphorians did not use the inlet themselves. Perhaps they were more willing to admit they didn't have the skill to navigate it without risking their ship. The inlet chokes, and a tooth-like incisor of rock rakes the boards from your hull. Limping out on the other side, you've made up the distance enough to see the Pyrphorians are headed to the port of Montoya. Your crew are very glad, since your ship is now in dire need of repair.
801703: Maintain course, following them around the island
801704: The Pyrphorians realise they must make port or be caught. As you round the cape, you see they're headed for the nearby settlement of Montoya. "Though we may not have caught them by sea," says your navigator, "they may have given away much more by leading us here; the only such haven for miles around."
801705: The lookout loses them. Complacency sets in, when at first you appear to be catching them, but upon rounding a cape, you find they have vanished! Bright white settlements cluster the sound like a fairy circle, and it seems they could have docked in any one of them. "We've lost them!" a skeptic pipes up, "so what now?! Stick a pin in the map?! Solicit a friendly local power for help?!!"
801706: Study the map to guess their most likely docking point
801707: The navigator is as sure of himself as he can be in these circumstances. "If I were Pyrphorian, God help me, I would head for Montoya." his finger circles the large settlement, "It has a large marina where my devilish vessel might be easily concealed." Upon searching Montoya harbour, they indeed find the Pyrphorian ship in a secluded corner of mangrove. That being all well and good, they must hope now they've not lost too much time.
801708: The navigator is as much as a failure as the lookout. Your ship makes a cat's cradle of the sound, as the navigator drags you hopelessly from one port to the next, almost at random. "Since you're so fine with directions," says the lieutenant to the diplomat in question, "perhaps you should explain where we went off course to Miss. Hannah Goode!"
801709: Appeal to nearby local authorities for information
801710: You're made to wait in line. Your diplomats may have done well to remember this local crest as one loyal to the crown, but you are not the only envoys present. Daiquiris, bananas and soft furnishings are small compensation for the time lost. Despite these formalities, the prefect transpires to be loyal. He intimates that Montoya is the only nearby place he has knowledge of that the Pyrphorians have their claws into. You cross your fingers, and head there yourself.
801711: "They must have been in league with the Pyrphorians!" wails your duped diplomat. Having failed to detect local complicity — rooted either in fear or allegiance — your diplomat insists you sail south along the coast. Your expedition continues diligently for three days in that direction without sighting a single human settlement. "Since you're so fine with words," says the lieutenant to the diplomat in question, "perhaps you should explain our failure to Miss. Hannah Goode!"
801712: That contract and those Pyrphorians must be here in Montoya, but where? The city sprawls before you under a pastel blue sky, the distinctive white walls and terracotta of Imperial La Corona glowing softly along the narrow estuary where the Mixcoatl meets the ocean. Yet, tranquil it is not. Anxiety is written on every passing face. They must surely know who you are and what you seek, but finding one brave enough to help is a different matter. You can ask around, or instead rely on your own eyes to find clues.
801715: Ask the local Montoyans if they know anything
801716: Your attaché hits it off with the harbourmaster, presenting you (not entirely falsely) as a fellow port official sympathetic to the Pyrphorian problem in the region. "I am sick of it," says the Montoyan, "whenever they come here, it's a nightmare for us! If you're willing to take action, it will be my pleasure to assist." Out on the sun-baked rooftop, he points upriver. "There, at the casona." A large verdant ranch wavers in the distance, the sanctuary of the Pyrphorians.
801717: The only one who may be willing to help you is a Great Plainsman. The softly-spoken giant is hauling thick rope at the dock. "I would be putting my life at risk," he says gravely, looking over his shoulder. He seems to know something.
801718: The Great Plainsman looks nervously over your goods
801721: "That should be enough to get me out of here," he says, inspecting the merchandise. "They've taken the big ranch - they're using it for their gatherings. You'd better be ready if you're hoping to break in, though. See all these people? There's a reason they're afraid." You head for the ranch on the outskirts of Montoya, where darkness awaits.
801722: "No!" he says, unwilling to risk his life for such scant reward. He glances around, sweeping back his long dark hair. It seems increasingly unlikely he will co-operate.
801723: He raises his hands, impressed, while remaining wary. "Perhaps you'll be the ones to finally unseat them." he says, pointing upriver, "They've taken the big ranch. They're using it for their gatherings. When you go there, expect trouble." He looks your soldiers up and down again, "Even if you do seem well prepared."
801724: "Seen enough of that in my lifetime," he says with quiet defiance. Your soldiers hang their heads— with the Pyrphorians here, Montoyans hardly need you stirring up more trouble. "If all you have to offer is violence, take it to those who deserve it," he says, gesturing at a decrepit-looking warehouse towards the end of the quay. Then he disappears, without so much as a farewell.
801725: "Your envoy is right," he says, "I can cover my tracks well enough." He nods upriver. "They've taken the big ranch - they're using it for their gatherings. You'd better be ready if you're hoping to break in, though. See all these people? There's a reason they're afraid." You head for the ranch on the outskirts of Montoya, where darkness awaits.
801726: He sighs deeply and rolls his eyes. "If you can't convince me, good luck convincing them to stop what they've begun," he says, gesturing at a decrepit-looking warehouse at the end of the quay. Then he disappears, without so much as a farewell.
801727: Your attaché's weepy plea is better received than anyone who had to hear it could have expected. "Of course we will help you stand against this terrible evil!" A local man says cheerfully, leading you to the end of the pier, where a rather decrepit warehouse stands. "This is it. We're all counting on you!" he whispers encouragingly at the door, before hurrying away.
801728: Smash down the warehouse door and charge in
801729: Of course, the Pyrphorians are ready and waiting. The warehouse appears to be a workshop for the production of devotional sculptures, its tables now flipped into barricades. Bullets ting through the many hundred stone representations of the goddess Pyr, as bodies drop on both sides. Eventually, the cultists prove too few. Having honored the dead, you conduct a search. There is no contract, but a fiery oculus stares up from the floor - it is a Pyrphorian paper tract, an invitation to a rally at the Casado estate.
801730: Your feeble bunch finally edge open the heavy door, only to find the building deserted. That it is owned by the Pyrphorians is clear. Carmine drapes smother the windows, and your people find themselves picking over the cult's instruments, whose purpose is unsettlingly opaque. "What's this oily liquid on the floor," someone says, just as the door slams shut, followed by the hasty rattle of padlock and keys. The Pyrphorian fire will burn bright and long at the quayside this night. Only one of your crew returns home.
801731: Find some way to sneak inside
801732: Your crew stalk noiselessly around the back. Scaling the wall, they find an open window obscured by a heavy carmine drape. Peering beyond it, they see a workshop for the production of devotional sculptures, its tables now flipped into barricades. With the cultists' attentions fixed on the main door, you're able to ambush them before it turns into a gunfight - but that doesn't stop two of your own being shot dead. Having honored the dead, your survivors conduct a search. There is no contract, but a fiery oculus stares up from the floor - it is a Pyrphorian paper tract, an invitation to a rally at the Casado estate.
801733: They thought they'd been as quiet as church mice, but rounding the corner at the back of the warehouse, your crew has a nasty shock. Up on the balcony above, where you might have thought to gain entry to the warehouse, stands a single Pyrphorian clad in heavy garb; in his hands, a long brass pipe, from which erupts a searing cone of fire. Your people spread and dive for the sea, and the Pyrphorians torch your ship. Only one of your crew returns home.
801734: Fan through the city, looking for clues
801735: Your scouts pick up the scent immediately. "We recognised them as the fugitives from the boat we pursued, and followed them through Montoya to its outskirts. Up in the valley, there's a sizeable house on a large estate. They must have taken the contract there." You set off at once.
801736: It seems the Pyrphorians have split. One you trace as far as the church, the other to a house of ill-repute— alternate refuges of the typical criminal. In neither case are the Pyrphorians still in evidence - you'll have to ask one of the respective proprietors instead.
801737: Go to the church and ask the Priest for help
801738: None better than the priest, hidden in shadow, witness to every confession, to guide you. "Yes, the rogues were here, but they are gone now. I am powerless to stop them, just like everybody else." He tells of a darkness that grips at the Montoyan community, their suffering pouring through his doors— a last refuge for the holy. "Many speak of a ranch a little way up the valley, and a beacon, some infernal eye, that holds their wicked congregation rapt," he says. You realise that if the contract is anywhere, it's probably there.
801739: Your crew must trust the man of God. After all, he seems devoted to helping you cleanse Montoya of its heresy. "No, I have not seen them," he begins, "but many of my flock have confessed their fears as of late — their lost faith." He smiles blithely, and leads you from the church to a decrepit warehouse on the dock. "If you too wish to rid yourself of your demons, I encourage you to begin here. Now forgive me, for I cannot abide violence," he says, taking his leave. You can try to break the warehouse door, or you can sneak in around the back.
801740: Go to the den of ill-repute and ask the Madam for help
801741: The Madam is only too happy to help following such charming propitiations. "Yes, the devils were here. They always are." She leads you through a lanterned garden of red dahlia, and points you up the valley to a ranch. "The sort of eye you seek is up there, at the casona," she clutches her wrist suddenly, "searing, burning — the Oculus." Lifting her hand, she reveals a grotesque brand on her skin. Mildly troubled, you set out for the ranch.
801742: The Madam refuses to help without payment. Time is money, and your mumbling mummers are wasting it.
801743: Spend some time in the establishment
801744: All are commendably well-behaved. Your sailors make surprisingly good companions, all paying what they owe. "Now that I have some evidence as to your good character," says the Madam, "I will help you." She leads you through a lanterned garden of red dahlia, and points you up the valley to a ranch. "The sort of eye you seek is up there, at the casona," she clutches her wrist suddenly, "searing, burning — the Oculus." Lifting her hand, she reveals a grotesque brand on her skin. Thanking her for her hospitality, you set out for the ranch.
801745: After an hour, your sailors are all over the place, singing and carousing, with one refusing to pay for services rendered. "Get them out!" screams the Madam. "But what of the information you promised?", "Out!". You have created enough of a scene. Fortunately, two boys waiting outside cheerily agree to help you for a bit of coin. They lead your band to a warehouse from which they claim eerie sounds emanate at night - in their words, like "stakes being driven through the hearts of vampyrs." The door to the warehouse looks breakable.
801747: "Alright, alright," she says bitterly, "Yes, the devils were here. They always are." She leads you through a lanterned garden of red dahlia, and points you up the valley to a ranch. "The sort of eye you seek is up there, at the casona," she clutches her wrist suddenly, "searing, burning - the Oculus." Lifting her hand, she reveals a brand on her skin. Feeling vaguely guilty for adding to the poor woman's woes, you set out for the ranch.
801748: She becomes strangely compliant, as if she is used to empty aggression. "This way," she says with forced sensuality. She takes you back over your own steps to the dock, and gestures a silked sleeve (from which no hand protrudes) to a decrepit-looking warehouse. "There. I must leave you now." The warehouse door looks breakable.
801749: There is no sign of the Pyrphorians, at least not that any of your twits see. Giving up their search, they begin stopping locals in the street. Most shake them off and walk on in a hurry, but they finally seem to strike lucky when two boys cheerily agree to help for a bit of coin. They lead your band to a warehouse from which they claim eerie sounds emanate at night- in their words, like "stakes being driven through the hearts of vampyrs." The door to the warehouse looks breakable.
801750: A little recompense always calms the nerves
801753: The Prosperity contract must be here. The Casona looks quite modern, with its white walls and pleasant gables. There is even an adjoining orangery, extending naturally towards the neat parterres of the sweet-smelling garden. An arc of white gravel serves as a drive, with long lines of equally white picket fence bordering the acreage in a typically colonial style. Indeed, were it not for the unusual height of this perimeter, and the shelters abutting it at regular intervals — armed guards no doubt stationed in each — it would appear much as any other estate. You consider your plan of entry.
801754: Play it bold, launching an assault on the house
801755: The guards at the main gate are efficiently dispatched, and their keys are taken. Your brigade flood into the ranch in formation, taking cover behind hedgerow and shrubbery, as the scattered enemy attempts to muster. Sure enough, the robes soon begin to flow, and the petit pistols are out.
801757:
The Pyrphorian defence is short-lived, and you lose no-one. Leaving the dying Pyrphorians to bask in their last light, you enter the house by the front door.
Once inside, your party meets with no resistance - only dread. The vestibule is a large open room, with stairs on either side. A series of Pre-Raphaelite panels depicting Pyr, the fire mother, adorn the walls. In one, she stands beneath a dark and cosmic sky, disciples at her feet, each holding a braid of her flaming hair. The most striking feature of the room, however, is the dome in the centre. At first, from below, it appears convex, but it's painted in every detail as a human eye. The Oculus. A pinprick of sunlight falls from its pupil to an ominous platform, thick with ash. You cannot find that contract soon enough.
801758:
Not as easy as your brigade presumes. There is strong resistance from the enemy, who in spite of their religious attire, are well-armed. You lose good people on the way to the front door.

Some are masked, others hired hands equipped with bandoliers. Even the gardeners have downed tools and pulled pistols. This is going to be rougher than you thought.
801763: Draw the enemy out, so you can flank them
801764:
A marathon battle style. It works, and the guards are defeated. A few sailors are injured, but now the road to the house is open.
The only question that remains now is: which room to look for?
801765:
Your strategy is too clever for your forces, who despite outnumbering the Pyrphorians three-to-one, are still only marginal victors. With a war at stake, you must hurry on to the house.

The officer commands no such following, and charges alone to an early grave. After that it is a hard fight, but you scrape through it. You hurry through the violated garden to the house.

801769: Play it sneaky - have your best person go in alone
801770: Your able scout climbs over the fence, darting nimbly between flowerbeds, and under the broad umbrella of a royal poinciana, its blossoms red as blood. The kitchen door on the east side is unguarded, but locked. What will you have your scout do next?
801771: Knock through the glass with a sword hilt to turn the handle
801772:
A hole punched with minimal fuss, and the door is open.

801812: Your infiltrator has the place to themself. For a library, there are very few books - and no sign of that contract under P for Prosperity, S for Sarmento, or anywhere else. The mahogany shelves are mostly home to objet d'art; cast iron animals never before seen, ornate weaponry, marble votives to Pyr, and a perfect diamond, gleaming dully. May as well pocket it, before moving on.
801815: Rejoice! The contract is right here, hidden beneath the hinged cover of the lectern. Hannah will be delighted - with this in your possession, a war may be prevented, and the small trouble it has taken to obtain it will be proven worthwhile. Indeed, there is a further windfall within the lectern - a fine silver ring, which your infiltrator may as well pocket before they make their escape.

Hannah will be delighted - with this in your possession, a war may be prevented, and the small trouble it has taken to obtain it will be proven worthwhile. As such, you would think it the most likely place for some important documents, but of that contract there is no sign! In the corner, however, is the largest egg anyone has ever seen. It could be valuable - may as well have the men lift it before continuing your search.

801888: Rejoice! The contract is right here, beneath the hinged cover of the lectern. Hannah will be so relieved - with this in your possession, a war may be prevented, and the extraordinary trouble it has taken to obtain it will be proven worthwhile.
801894: Rejoice! The contract is right here on the mahogany desk. Hannah will be so relieved - with this in your possession, a war may be prevented, and the extraordinary trouble it has taken to obtain it will be proven worthwhile.
801899: You finally have your hands on the Prosperity contract! Now there's a chance of clearing your father's name, and in doing so, preventing the outbreak of war between Isabel Sarmento and the Queen.
801904: Discouraged, the crew are forced to return to Isabel's island. "We lost them", apologises the captain. But a few days later, Isabel receives a letter from one of her scouting parties, "Pyrphorian vessel spotted entering Montoya harbour." With renewed hope, the crew prepare to leave at once. The contract, and those Pyrphorians must be here in Montoya, but where? The city sprawls before you under a pastel blue sky, the distinctive white walls and terracotta of Imperial La Corona glowing softly along the narrow estuary where the Mixcoatl meets the ocean. Yet, tranquil it is not. Anxiety is written in every passing face. They must surely know who you are and what you seek, but finding one brave enough to help is a different matter. You can ask around, or instead rely on your own eyes to find clues.
801943: The sole survivor succeeds in getting back to Isabel's island. In his panic, he explains that the rest didn't make it, and describes how he traced the enemy back to an estate outside Montoya. The crew are assembled at once. They arrive to find the Casona looks quite modern, with white walls and pleasant gables. The Prosperity contract must be here. An adjoining orangery extends naturally towards the neat parterres of a sweet-smelling garden. An arc of white gravel serves as a drive, with long lines of equally white picket fence bordering the acreage in typical colonial style. Indeed, were it not for the unusual height of this perimeter, and the shelters abutting it at regular intervals — armed guards no doubt stationed in each — it would appear much as any other estate. You consider your plan of entry.
802002: Water in the hull! The overloaded ship could only go so far with this many supplies in its belly. A series of strong waves sends the crates flying, and the boat's stomach soon explodes. Cracks pierce the hull where the cargo hit, and trickles of water pop one after the other throughout the storage space.
802003: Use the electric water pump to allow proper repairs
802004: Improvise a water pump to allow immediate repairs
802005: Seal the damaged section and repair it at the next harbour
802006: Specific situations call for specific solutions: your preparation was on point. The electric pump roars and swallows water much faster that it can infiltrate the ship, allowing the sailors to repair the damage with ease.
802007: Your crafty crew has a solution for everything. Using communication tubes as the pump's body, and spare metal sheets as paddles, the sailors manage to assemble what could pass for a proper water pump. It takes a good dozen men to make it work, but they buy enough time for proper repairs.
802008: This joke of a pump looks like it came from the Dark Ages. As the sailors battle to have their own idea of a pump prevail over the others, they assemble a monster that does nothing more than blow bubbles. One of the cracks in the hull bursts in a spray of water, silencing the machine as the ship starts to flood.
802010: Seal the overflowing section, regardless of what - or who - might still be inside
802011: Make a decision! Who knows what'll happen if you don't!
802012: The ship rises in the water, but at what cost? The sailors watch their supplies drift away from the vessel, their hearts lingering after the lost items, until the officers remind them of the urgency of the repairs.
802013: There's nothing more to be done. The ship slowly sinks, pulled deeper into the water with each new fracture in its hull. Both cargo and crew are drenched by the leaks, and the ship vomits their remains when it crashes onto the shore. The survivors contemplate the wreckage in despair, before trying to make repairs.
802014: Both cargo and crew are doomed to drown in the leakage. The sailors close the hull's doors on their comrades, hushing their screams. However, there's no avoiding reopening the hull when time comes for repairs: the water flows out, carrying bodies transfixed with expressions of suffocation, terror, and betrayal.
802015: The drowned cargo cannot be salvaged. When the ship finally finds a harbour, its hull sits so far below the waterline your crew fears the boat will sink. Although such fears are unfounded, the leaks ruined a good part of your stored food, and the repairs feel like they should have be done much earlier.
802016: Throw supplies overboard to try and lift the crack above the waterline
802021: These hoodlums are asking for it. To each harbour its own ill-famed tavern, and this one is no exception. While your crew enjoys a beer at the counter, the tavern's door slams open, the bartender stiffens and the volume of conversations dwindles: the newcomers are regulars of the bad kind. One of the scruffy men elbows your doctor and gasps as the alcohol splashes on his unkempt clothes. He immediately grabs your sailor by the collar, and demands an apology.
802022: They want to fight? Let them come!
802023: Offer them a drink to ease the tension
802024: This is a waste of time - simply apologise
802025: Your crew crushes them. The collar-grabbed doctor slaps away the hand of the hoodlum, seizes his sleeve and pulls him over his shoulder, sending him crashing into a table. With a roar, the other thugs pounce on your sailors, who greet them with jabs to the chin and sternum, downing the attackers with no more than two hits per man - the seconds for the pleasure of good fighting form. The tavern applauds the action, and the bartender offers a round to celebrate a well deserved beating.
802026: The crew overestimated themselves. As he calls for the other sailors to help, the doctor gets his head smashed into the counter. His crewmates scream for revenge, and look like toddlers agitating their little arms to try and hit the big bad guys. The thugs are not in the mood to play along, and one of them stabs a bawling sailor in the liver to make them shut up. They slowly die as the thugs depart, leaving the tavern in a stupor.
802027: The language of alcohol is universal. The thugs take you up on your offer, and eye the sailors' purses as they pass the money around to pay for the beers. As the first round arrives, one of the hoodlums speaks up and announces that they will have a drinking contest with the crew. The idea is one-sided, and weirdly different from their previous aggressive attitude.
802028: Bribing them with alcohol doesn't seem to work. Your crew invites the men to sit and share a beer, on them, to try and bring the tension down. The thug doesn't let go of the doctor, and points at the aligned liquors behind the bartender. A glass of all of these, he says, and a bottle of your best whatever. That's way more than they can drink - and way more than your sailors can afford.
802029: Show them the drinking ability of seafarers
802030: Drug their drinks to avoid the confrontation
802031: They call that cat piss strong? There's no question regarding who wins the drinking contest: your crew are still standing and enjoying the beers long after the thugs have hit the ground, curled into whatever their stomach rejected. The pungent smell of vomit and cheap ale does not deter the sailors, who casually finish their steins, pay for them, and drag the hoodlums to the closest man of law.
802032: What kind of liquid fire do they make this with? The crew are used to strong drinks and exotic ales, but the tavern's special mixture of bourbon, sugar and Ricard is way past what they can handle. The thugs are accustomed to this local horror and barely wobble, while your sailors pass out one after the other. When they wake up, obviously, their purses are missing.
802033: War anaesthetics are remarkably useful against small-time thugs. After a few rounds spent boasting their virile resistance to any kind of liquor, the crew notice the drop in attention of their opponents, and their doctor seizes the opportunity, lacing the incoming mugs with just the right dosage of chloroform. The snoring hoodlums are delivered to the local authorities, who enjoy the unexpected present.
802034: The dosage doesn't put the thugs to sleep: it kills them. The doctor sidles among the thugs, lacing their drinks and snickering in expectation. Soon the effects appear: the gang shows drowsiness, then nausea, before losing control of their movements and tumbling against the counter, their faces taking on a waxy yellow color. The crew can do nothing as the hoodlums break into seizures and foam at the mouth. They win the drinking contest by default, as murderers of their opponents.
802035: If it's a fight they want, they'll get one
802037: The crew are humiliated. They empty their purses trying to pay for the excessive demands of the thugs. Ale. Stew. Liquors. Meats. When sunrise pushes the hoodlums to leave the tavern, the sailors are stuck with cooking, dishwashing and dust-wiping until the bartender considers their debt paid.
802038: Your sailors apologise through gritted teeth. Pleased by their groveling, the thugs don't pester them anymore, yet the heavy stares of the other clients push your crew to leave the tavern. Next time, they'll show them. Next time.
802041: Clear skies, calm seas, and mutiny! The tension has been building. The everyday strains of an expedition — the rationing of supplies, a lack of recognition from the officers — it has all become too much for the lower-ranks to take. They are refusing to take further orders, and have united behind a charismatic spokesperson. It won't take much to push them to a full-blooded revolt!
802042: Arrange a meeting with the leader of the mutiny
802044: Make an example of the ringleader
802046: They soon reach an understanding. After all, the demands made by the mutineers are perfectly understandable. The officers address each of the criticisms of the running of the ship, agreeing where possible to make adjustments — and where they find it's not possible, they take the time to explain exactly why things must stay the way they are. Everyone seems most satisfied with such a fair and democratic resolution.
802047: The threat of mutiny is gone, for now. The negotiations begin well, but ultimately remain unresolved, with the first mate too stubborn to make compromises for his inferiors, and the mutineers seemingly unable to see the bigger picture. After a long and tiresome debate, the mutineers agree to disagree, and grudgingly begin taking orders again.
802048: Their leader insists you meet on his turf. "The officers will join us among our squalid bunks, or there'll be no meeting," he says with more than a hint of threat.
802049: Agree to meet in the sailors' quarters
802050: That's enough disobedience — arrest the chaplain
802051: The leader of the mutineers listens to reason. That an officer is willing to meet on the lower decks already shows progress has been made, and the humility he then proceeds to show, while listening to the many gripes and grumbles of the crewmen, is enough to defuse the situation — even if nothing has really changed at all...
802052: The meeting goes nowhere. It is clear the problem lies with their leader. He is a force of nature, too incendiary for any of your officers to handle. With each new compromise offered by your representative, he makes further, more unreasonable demands. Something must be done, and fast.
802053: Your representative is utterly tactless. It is late, he has had too much gin, and he barges into the sailors' quarters barking insults and commands. The crew toss aside their paperbacks and swing down from their hammocks, laying into him with their fists. Perhaps they don't intend to kill him, but nevertheless, that's what they achieve. To settle the matter, the captain agrees to keep their crime a secret, so long as there's no more talk of mutiny.
802057: The doctor agrees to be an accomplice, and his complicity proves vital. Dispensing with his moral objections, your medic produces a poison that causes rapid respiratory failure. A man known to be loyal to the captain secretly administers it, and within a few days the chief firebrand of the mutineers is dead. "Cancer of the lung," says the doctor, "most probably caused by stress." No-one suspects a thing, but the officers must keep a terrible secret.
802058: It is obvious you tried to poison him. The doctor refuses to help, objecting, "It's despicable — and besides, I know nothing of poisons." Instead, you're forced to rely on the help of the ship's cook. The "wine" he concocts is discoloured, and obviously reeks of death, but the poor fellow is too drunk to notice. Unfortunately for you, the doctor chooses to issue an emetic, and saves the firebrand from his untimely demise. "The bastards tried to kill him!" scream the mutineers, as they converge upon the captain's cabin.
802059: In a final attempt to keep order, offer a bribe
802064: They take the bribe, but their loyalty cannot be bought. The trust between the commanding officers and the crew has been shattered. Since there appears no single culprit, it is agreed that all senior officers be put on probation so that any member of the crew may hold them to account for their actions henceforth. Needless to say, the general mood among the officers is low.
802065: Blood is the only payment they will take. Weakened by the poisoned wine, the leader of the rebels appears on a crutch. His followers part in taciturn awe, as he hobbles forward. "Name your scapegoat," he says. One of the junior officers draws the short straw. "Cut out his eyes!" And with two gruesome oyster scoops, the hierarchy aboard your ship is turned upside down. The captain has no choice now but to grant several of the rebels positions of authority aboard ship.
802066: It's a bloody end, but your officers can fight. Their academy training stands them in good stead as the dissident rabble charges. The sailors, equipped with hooks, nailboards and anything else they can find, are no match for your sabre-slashing redcoats. Although the mutiny is over, and its leader, too ill to fight, is safely in the brig, it's unlikely all those radical ideas have simply died with those who had held them.
802067: The officers show themselves unworthy of power. Without loyalty, pride, or even discipline, the redcoat defenders are broken by the rabid horde. The leader of the mutineers, still groggy, makes an example of one of the officers, forcing him to drink the same deadly wine he was given. The captain has no choice but to grant the rebels positions of authority aboard ship. It will be a rocky ride from hereon.
802068: The leader comes quietly, perhaps because soldiers loyal to the expedition have knocked and asked politely — it's more dignified that way. He is on his own now. Guards are stationed all along the route to the brig, separating him from his followers. Without their leader to organise and motivate them, the threat of mutiny becomes little more than a grumble.
802069: The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. When a fracas sparks into life, they are vicious. The officers jab their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things look grim for this voyage.
802070: The mutineers leave the expedition. The captain and the officers, having failed to provide a solution, cannot hold them to their contracts. Equally, as the senior ranks have refused to negotiate, the leader of the mutineers is now honour bound to take some formal action. An uncomfortable week of silence passes before you make port, and a large portion of the crew leaves as soon as you dock, taking food and other supplies with them.
802071: The leader comes quietly, perhaps because soldiers loyal to the expedition have knocked and asked politely — it's more dignified that way. He is on his own now. Guards are stationed all along the route to the brig, separating him from his followers. Without their leader to organise and motivate them, the threat of mutiny becomes little more than a grumble.
802072: The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. In fact, when the inevitable fracas whirls into action, they are vicious. The officers thrust their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things will never be the same again.
802076: A pragmatic solution. The amount offered to the man to buy his obedience is enough for him to ignore the incongruity of a monetary settlement — a bribe, as it's more often known. What's more, he's willing to spread the lie that change is afoot. It's not long before the storm of mutiny has passed overhead.
802077: He refuses, insisting you negotiate on his turf. "Give us what we ask, or this mob'll turn, I guarantee it," he threatens.
802078: The budding mutiny is crushed. The first lieutenant and two loyalists are all it takes to seize the ringleader and present him before the captain for judgement. The man is condemned to a marooning on the next island they encounter. The swift arrest and punishment impresses the sailors, and renews their respect for their superiors.
802079: The loyalists find it difficult to act against their friends. "Go on then, arrest them!" blares an officer, when they show a moment's hesitation. The ringleader is eventually captured, made a scapegoat and marooned at the next port, but weakness has been shown. A few little cracks have started to appear...
802080: The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. In fact, when the inevitable fracas whirls into action, they are vicious. The officers thrust their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things will never be the same again.
802081: The mutineers leave the expedition. The captain and the officers, having failed to provide a solution, cannot hold them to their contracts. Equally, as the senior ranks have refused to negotiate, the leader of the mutineers is now honour bound to take some formal action. An uncomfortable week of silence passes before you make port, and a large portion of the crew leaves as soon as you dock, taking food and other supplies with them.
802084: Sailor under the mast! Weeks of harsh weather have taken their toll on the ship, and the violent gusts of wind this morning have toppled the mizzenmast. For a moment, the ropes tying it to the other masts hold it in place, but there's only so much weight they can take: they break with a snap, letting the mizzenmast plummet on the deck. A sailor now wails, his leg caught under a pole twice his size.
802085: Cover the leg with a mix of soap and water, and pull it away
802086: Cut the leg with a bone saw
802087: Lift the mast with a makeshift lever
802088: The sailor is easily pulled from under the mast. The foamy water allows the crushed leg to slither away from the debris, and the limb emerges covered in rainbow bubbles and bloody splinters. The man will live - and maybe, with a miracle or two, his leg will mend.
802089: An extreme but commendable choice. The sailor is given rum to drink and a cloth to bite before he is held in place, and his leg bound with a tight tourniquet. The doctor's labour is gruesome, and the man can feel the grinding cuts as they tear through him, and he screams through the cloth as he howls and he roars - and yet the doctor stays composed and focused. When the leg is finally cut and the sailor dragged away, the crew feels reassured that they are in capable hands.
802090: Butchery. The doctor's hands tremble more than his victim does, and the saw draws zigzags through his patient's flesh, each cut unable to connect with the previous ones. The trapped sailor's screams become whimpers, then silence. The doctor has to be stopped before he can ruin any more of the unfortunate corpse, and his blood-clad figure sends a warning to whoever might need his help in future.
802091: The man is freed. Using one of the partners broken by the mast, the crew fits sturdy pieces of timber between the deck and the fallen mast, adding plank after plank in the opening, before gradually raising the mast with ropes and pulleys tied to the mainmast. They manage to lift the mast long enough to free the sailor, and the doctor immediately tends to his crushed leg.
802092: The vague idea of a lever never becomes real. The sailors try to lift the mizzenmast by rolling logs underneath, but the huge wooden pole is far too heavy for its rolling movements to be controlled. The mast lurches forward and rolls from the sailor's leg to his chest, pushing his insides out. The view stays with the sailors for days before they can finally reach a decent harbour, get rid of the broken mast, and clean up the grisly mess underneath.
802095: A ship in need of rescue! The vast floating tapestries of algae in these windless waters have long been thought impassable. Just when you thought your own vessel had managed to avoid the yellow-orange plants, you see another ship stuck fast! They must also have seen you, as their alarm begins to sound. With no proper rescue equipment aboard, your own ship risks becoming entangled if you get too close. Should you try to help?
802096: A steamship should have nothing to fear here
802097: Harpoon them and tug them away
802099: Your steamer glides effortlessly through. The crew lean from the rails to peer at the sargassum colony, which is thick with sealife like crabs and tropical fish. The algae parts easily before your ship. The absence of wind presents no difficulty as it would for a sailboat, and indeed, as you tug them into open water, the crew of the ship in distress explain it was not the algae, but the calm that had stalled them. They are delighted to have been discovered, and several of them offer to join your expedition.
802100: A good shot, but there is too little wind to tug them clear. Having signalled your intention, the gunner sends the harpoon crunching into the other ship's hull. A fine shot, considering it was at the limit of the harpoon's range. However, the calm prohibits them pulling the ship out of the brown mass of algae, so the crew consider their next steps.
802101: Panicked sailors toss themselves into the algae, as your stray harpoon crashes wildly through the lower deck, and seawater rushes in through the breach. She's going down! "We brought them to this," yells one of your officers, "we have a responsibility to do something!"
802103: Inspire them to traverse the rope
802104: The breeches buoy guarantees a safe rescue. The crew transform a lifebuoy into a harness, and attach it to runners which allow it to zip between the two ships once the harpoon rope is drawn taut. The stranded sailors take it in turns to enjoy this rather daring form of escape. Having been lifted from the doldrums, they are keen to assist however they may for the remainder of the expedition.
802105: The breeches buoy shears off into the water just as the first sailor climbs onto the contraption, leaving it dangling perilously from the rope between the two ships. Desperate for rescue, the crew of the stranded boat decide to swim for it instead. After thrashing the distance, the mariners eventually slop aboard, their bodies jaundiced with algae. "Five years we've been stuck here," one stammers angrily. They're going to be quite a burden on your expedition.
802106: A surge of belief animates the stranded sailors. "You are saved!" cries your lookout, "your ordeal is over!" Under the encouragement of your lieutenants, the other crew grab the rope, and with the desperate strength of hope, they cross the distance to reach your ship. Your crew's goodwill has shone through, and the grateful survivors join your expedition without a second thought.
802107: They take no strength from your crew's silent prayer. If only someone had offered a few more words of encouragement — anything positive at all. First to cross is an old man so thin, you could fold him up and tuck him in a drawer. Clutching the fibrous rope is challenge enough for his frail wrists, and after a brief struggle, he drops off. His crewmates jump in with him, and commence a desperate thrash through the brown sargassum. The few that make it to your ship will only be a burden on your expedition.
802108: Send your best swimmers to the rescue
802110: Your swimmers are strong and fit enough, but the malnourished crew of the sinking ship need all the help they can get. The algae weighs like a lion's mane on your heroes, as they relay the castaways on-by-one. Once all are accounted for, they lie on the burning deck, panting. This whole episode has been exhausting.
802111: The rescue is a tragedy. Your men paddle like puppies in the densely-packed sargassum — it's hard to understand quite how sailors could be so lacking in practice. Gasping, they reach desperately towards the castaways they should be rescuing, as if for support, only for the undertow of the sinking ship to pull them under. This was all your fault.
802112: "We did what we could..." the lieutenant trails off, "...and we couldn't do much!" answers your steersman darkly. There is so little wind here, it takes an eternity to pass the sinking boat by. Hands reach desperately towards you, but the pull of their sinking ship soon drags them under the surface. It will take an awful lot to lift your crew out of the doldrums.
802113: "Don't leave! We've been here for ten years!" Reads the message in semaphore. There's so little wind here, it takes an eternity to pass the stranded boat by. A drift of shame. Your crew, as yellow-bellied as this sea of sargassum, will need a lot to lift them out of the doldrums.
802116: Tremors, ash rain, and an oddly bright night: it's an eruption! The island was too lush and bountiful to be harmless. The lava responsible for the fertile ground creeps from the mouth of the waking volcano, and towards the jungle where a party of your men had erected camp for the night.
802117: Go back to the ship despite the darkness.
802118: Find shelter against the incoming lava
802119: The ship is quickly found. The burning lights of the volcano illuminate the jungle, and a handful of seasoned explorers lead the rest of the sailors back to the ship, zigzagging between shadows and fleeing animals. The vessel departs as the island is engulfed by flames, a vision as terrible as it is magnificent.
802120: The sailors are swallowed by the jungle's maze. Dense trees, moving shadows, screeching animals and the crew itself, whose silhouettes are deformed by the scorching heat - too many visions allow panic to spread among the men, who cannot recognise the path, and never make it back to the ship.
802121: Shelter! The crew finds a decrepit stone chapel, the remains of a colonialist power, and deems it better refuge than their cloth-made tents. An officer estimates that the lava will be on them soon: there's no choice but to spend the night here.
802122: Your crew are lost and perplexed. Even your most committed explorers cannot wrap their heads around the complexity of the jungle, which changes with every newly burnt tree. It seems that every path might end in lava-devoured dead ends.
802125: Pray for the chapel to hold
802126: Dig trenches in the holy ground
802127: The chapel miraculously stands its ground. Lava rolls against its walls and forks around the white stone, melting its paint and parching its plaster. Nestled on the only facade left untouched by the flow, the chapel's wooden door seems like the most fragile object the sailors have ever seen. When day comes, they are safe and elated, and all kiss the blessed door before leaving.
802128: Their faith is nothing but hypocrisy in need. The crew remembers old prayers from their worshipping days, but the years have eroded both their memory and their beliefs. They can only watch as the lava packs against the chapel's stained glass and breaks through. The spray of molten stone and broken glass scars all of them but kills none: a bite to remind them of their lack of dedication.
802129: The trenches are dug with military efficiency. Despite the darkness and the imminent danger, the sailors manage to dig deep trenches in no time, and the pits redirect the lava as it flows down the hill. The sailors bunker down in the chapel as the lava runs around the outside, illuminating the stained glass, leaving them to rejoice in the warm comfort of their shelter.
802130: Too much pressure and too little grit. The sailors can dig little more than scattered and knee-deep pits, which have a negligible impact on the lava's course. As the crew scurries inside the chapel, so to does the lava, its smoke burning throats and forever robbing the men of their voices.
802131: Follow a random animal and trust its instincts
802132: Pick a random path and trust your instincts
802133: The animals run to the beach, and your crew follows. Tracking down the herd of shrill, squealing, screeching critters could be done with eyes closed, and the sailors are led to the shore where they had beached. The ship departs in a hurry, leaving the animals to die in the ruthless volcano fire.
802134: Your hunters find no pattern in the animals' frenzy. The sailors run in a display of panic and poor judgment, mimicking the animals' desperate behavior. The crew still on the ship can only watch in horror as the island's greatest predator burns all its prey, be they beast or human.
802135: Fear is the most reliable instinct. The sailors scamper through the jungle, chasing after their lava-lit shadows. They stumble upon the beach by pure miracle, and hop on the ship with molten tongues on their heels. The ship departs with a slightly charred hull, but a safe crew.
802136: Fear is a treacherous adviser. Seeing that the only unburnt path is up, the sailors climb the jungle's trees in an attempt to escape the lava flow. Ground, then bark, then branches, then humans: everything burns. In the distance, the ship's remaining crew stay transfixed as they witness the volcano island devouring itself.
802139: "They steal your children?" The air hangs heavy around the sailors as their question withers in the hut. Their hosts consider the explorers, half-hopeful, half-guilty from the certitude that non-paying jobs are not the ones your crew enjoys. One child has to be offered with each new moon, an elder explains as she gestures towards the nearby river, or else bandits raid the surrounding settlements. Tomorrow, the bandits' steamboat will come to claim this village's due.
802140: Board the bandits' steamer with your gunboat
802141: Shadow the kidnappers back to their hideout with a river skiff
802142: Stay on your ship and open fire when the steamboat appears
802143: Ignore the bandits and go on your way
802144: Your assault is swift, and without a single casualty. The kidnappers offer no resistance, as their carcass of a craft faces your own fresh-from-the-factory gunboat. They reluctantly lead you to their hideout - a sweatshop with no employees other than the stolen kids. Your crew sets the hideout afire, heads back to the village, and returns the children to their exultant parents. Though they can offer no reward but tears and smiles, your crew basks in the warmth of this priceless payment.
802145: Your crew navigates through the mangrove with aplomb. The unusual environment doesn't manage to stop their steady rowing, and the sailors soon reach an outpost marking the entrance of the bandits' camp. Sobbing children are taken from the kidnappers' steamboat, and dragged towards a distant barn. Half a dozen armed men guard the building.
802146: The terrain is not one your crew are used to. They get stuck in the mangrove roots, and their swearing can be heard all the way to the coast. When they manage to get free, the bandits' steamboat is waiting, its railings lined with guns.
802147: Rather than bandits, the crew finds their leftovers. The bayou's fog makes for a maze your sailors cannot navigate, causing them to lose their quarry. Disturbingly, while trying to find their bearings, your crew ends up making a discovery more harrowing than they could ever imagine: a pit filled both with torn shoes, and their torn young makers. The image stays with them until they try to describe it to the villagers and break down, unable to depict the young faces and their blank eyes. They leave, disgusted by their inability to end this savagery.
802148: Attack the bandits before they reach the barn
802149: Hide amongst the trees and wait for nightfall
802150: The bandits don't know what hit them. Using the element of surprise to their advantage, your sailors break into the camp and stifle the children's escorts before they can call for help. They hush the kids, and squat behind what few bushes offer protection, monitoring the other bandits. The attack wasn't noticed.
802151: The sailors are unfit for a swift assault. Their unchoreographed clumsiness and dissonant roars drives their opponents back not because of their strength, but because of the unconventional display. After an instant of bafflement, the kidnappers shout for others to join them, and the whole gang soon surrounds your crew. They part to let their leader, a beast of a man, face the puny intruders.
802152: Go all out on the bandits and save the remaining children
802153: Acknowledge the danger, and leave with the children you've already saved
802154: The sailors and kids create a breathtaking chaos. The crew shoots and skewers, while the children kick and bite their former oppressors, calling for others to do the same. A deluge of shrieking kids and young adults emerge from the barn and attack the guards, thrilled by your crew's display of strength. The band of unlikely fighters seize the bandits' steamboat, helping themselves to its supplies, before triumphantly returning to the coast.
802155: Audacity does not make up for their lack of numbers. The crew manages to take down five guards before the noise attracts more armed bandits, and the sailors are driven back to their boat before they can liberate any more children. They flee to the village, and share what they've discovered with the villagers, glad to have freed some kids, but all too aware that many more remain captive.
802156: The decision to run is not a simple one. The sailors recognize how dangerous the assault could be, and retreat to the village along with the few children they've saved. They share what they've discovered with the villagers - and maybe another day, with a subtler approach, more men, and more planning... things could be different. As the ship leaves, the crew focuses more on the good they did, rather than what they could have done.
802159: Your sailors' cause fuels their victory. Driven by their will to save the children, your sailors do not waver in front of the bandits' leader, all muscles and swords with rage in his eyes. It takes six fighters to face the man, piling up on him in a torrent of dust and groans until he finally stops rampaging. Disheartened by this defeat, and their leader's meaningless pride, the remaining kidnappers are brought to their knees, and the children are freed. The crew returns to the village triumphant!
802160: The mastodon tramples your sailors. The rescuers lack resistance, and are wiped out by the bandits' leader, their corpses sent flying among the children who can do nothing but watch in horror. In an ultimate act of hatred, a young girl is sent back to her village to retell the carnage, and warn future intruders against trying to rescue the children again.
802161: No sailor is harmed, no child is saved. The crew manage to run back to the village, avoiding the multiple gunshots fired by the kidnappers. That no sailor was wounded is a miracle, but it's hard to celebrate much when the rescue team failed to rescue a single child.
802162: The crew becomes one with the trees. Unseen and unheard, the sailors bury themselves in the forest, and observe their future targets. An opportunity arises when a group of bandits leave their posts to bathe in the river: splashing and talking, they don't hear your men approach.
802163: The sailors are not attuned to the notion of stealth. They argue about the best place to hide, and end up lining up behind what could be the thinnest trees in the entire forest, their bulging shapes attracting more than a little unwanted attention from the kidnappers. Their leader, more beast than man, advances to inspect the intruders, and laughs at the puny men.
802164: Steal their clothes to disguise yourselves as bandits
802165: Capture the men and use them as hostages
802166: Your sailors use their disguises to orchestrate the children's escape. Dressed in bandits' rough coats and sashes, the crew infiltrates the barn-turned-sweat-shop, where the children are forced to work. One by one, they lead the kids out of the camp and into their skiff, each child carrying stolen supplies. When the boat finally leaves, the camp is left without fuel, food, or ammunition. It will be some time before the bandits can do any more harm.
802167: The poorly-disguised intruders are identified and given chase. When asked by an actual bandit about their shift, one of your undercover sailors tries to answer: they fumble and bumble until the bandit grabs them and shouts, "intruders!". They make a run for it with the others, leaving both kidnappers and children behind.
802168: A flawless move, from start to finish. After swiftly capturing the naked bandits, the sailors advance, only to discover the camp's true nature: a child-powered sweatshop. It's soon obvious that the bandits' leader is the only one who doesn't care for the hostages, and the man is forcibly exchanged by his crew in return for the promise that your sailors will never set foot in there again. The rescuers return to the village with children on their shoulders, a culprit to be judged, and goods to be shared.
802169: The naked men overpower your fighters. The element of surprise fails to compensate for your crew's lack of strength, and they're easily repelled by the bathing bandits. Instead of killing them, the kidnappers order the sailors to strip, and send them on their way so everyone can see them for what they are - rescuers who were unable to rescue anyone, and who were humiliated in the process.
802172: The crew are puny indeed, and they are butchered. The bandits' leader needs no help in fighting your rescuers, who spend more time trying to avoid being hit than actually fighting back. They flee the camp, scatter into the woods, and are hunted down like game. The few sailors who make it back to the coast are so disoriented, they can't even remember the location of the kidnappers' camp, making the deaths of their companions pointless.
802173: Bluff and pretend backup is on its way
802176: Your bluff works! The kidnappers have a heated discussion before handing over what few children they have onboard, unnerved by the menace your crew just invented. The sailors retreat to the village and return the children to their families, still amazed by their deception, but upset they could save so few.
802177: They do not buy your bluff. Holding your crew at gunpoint, the bandits casually wait for the reinforcements to show up - but they never arrive. To teach your crew a lesson, the kidnappers grab one of the kids onboard, and cut his tongue before throwing it into your raft: a lesson to you liars. Your sailors withdraw to the village, regretting having only made things worse.
802181: A pricey but worthy trade. Trying to hide their distaste for treating children like goods, your sailors bring the kids onboard. They are in a state of shock, but they look physically sound.
802183: The children are safe with you, punish their abductors
802184: The children will be safer with their parents, let the kidnappers leave
802186: Your retribution is ruthless. The kidnappers are still counting up the goods you bought the children with when the crew attacks, and its assault is brutal. The steamboat is set aflame, and the bandits die by fire or bullet. The crew returns the kids to the safety of their homes, but the children now see them as no different from their captors: beasts, driven by violent instincts.
802187: Your sailors are overpowered. The kidnappers have fought much harder battles against much lesser men, and your crew's attack is dismissed with scorn. The bandits could easily have retrieved the children, but their strange sense of honor makes them consider that goods bought are goods acquired. The crew are sent back to the village with the kids, both looking equally dishevelled and aghast.
802188: A pity to let the culprits escape so easily. The sailors return the children to their respective families, but the kids' joy fails to hide how many more could have been saved given a little extra effort.
802189: You don't meet the bandits' expectations. To teach your crew a lesson, the kidnappers grab one of the kids onboard and cut his thumb, tossing it into your raft: a lesson for the penniless. Your sailors withdraw to the village, regretting having only made things worse.
802190: There's only so much your sailors can do. They back away under the menace of the bandits' guns, doing their best not to trigger an attack, and row back to the coast. The parents of the abducted children thank them for their effort, but their strangled hopes make their voices break. The sailors leave knowing they could have done better.
802191: A masterful shot! Using one of your precious spiral-muzzled cannons, the crew fires a single shot which pierces straight through the steamboat's engines. The boat gradually stops puffing and drifts to your own ship, where sailors can pick off the bandits, and retrieve the three stolen children.
802192: Poor use of your firepower. The sailors handling the cannons are just as important as the weapons themselves. As your crew aren't quite as well-oiled as the machinery, they fail to adjust the quantity of powder being used, firing the artillery to its maximum range without any kind of aiming. They might as well have lit signal fires. The bandits' boat makes a brutal turn and retreats into the bayou at full speed.
802193: Both bandits and captives are killed. The villagers watch in horror as your ship fires its cannons at the small steamboat as soon as it is in sight, annihilating the frail vessel and all life onboard. Mothers and fathers rush to the water, screaming and crying as tiny bodies slowly emerge. If your crew had a greater control over themselves and the ship, maybe they wouldn't have had to bear the weight of these children's deaths.
802194: Scare the kidnappers into revealing the position of their hideout
802196: Enough risks for today: return the children and be on your way
802197: Your seafarers coerce the river-dwellers into speaking the truth. There is a world of knowledge and pain into your men's eyes, and the bandits are overwhelmed before a single word is spoken. Their hideout is easy prey for your crew, which storms through the den and triumphantly returns the children to their parents, along with the bandits' possessions and supplies.
802198: The intention is there, but not the result. The bandits recognize your sailors for what they are: sharp-shooters, but weaklings when it comes to close-range confrontation. The crew's threats mean nothing to them. Knowing that these men are the only ones who know where the rest of the children are being held, your crew hands them over to the villagers along with the kids they found, and leave with a feeling of defeat.
802199: Thoughts of the remaining captives follow your crew. The villagers are thrilled to have the handful of children returned to them and profusely thank their saviors, making the crew's remorse all the worse. The sailors are happy for them, but they know they could have done more.
802200: Not all sailors share your lack of compassion. Some men and women refuse to leave, and the officers have no choice but to let them do as they please lest they lose even more of the crew's trust. Many sailors argue that staying to help was the right choice, but the ship has already set sail when they voice their opinion.
802201: Shadow the kidnappers back to their hideout with a river skiff
802204: The splendid warriors are all women. Exploring this deserted settlement — which appears to have been the scene of a revolt — seemed a good opportunity for some looting, but your crew aren't the only ones to have had the idea. As they pass the barricades of barrels, tables and chairs, they happen upon a group of warriors, with not a man among them. Indeed, the long-trousered women assume a defensive formation so fluently, it's possible they are more than human.
802205: Let a woman do the talking
802208: She fascinates the warriors, almost as much as they fascinate her. "Many stray into our territories, but rarely does a woman lead them," says the tallest of the goddesses. Neither she nor the others make any further mention of these territories, how far they span, or if their people dwell in towns and cities. Your crew are invited to share in what they have found, however. As the women lope into the trees, eyes ever watchful, you wonder how they will repurpose all they have harvested from these ruins. It is your belief they may have stumbled into this chaos, from a distant, more noble age.
802209: They too share a love of exploration and discovery! Though they know nothing of your language, your envoy takes great pleasure in unravelling his sea chart. Curiosity soon loosens them from their formation, as they crowd around him, sitting on their shields to get a better view. He describes the ship in gestures, and when he gets to the sails, for some reason they fall about with laughter. One of them snatches the map, and makes a suggestion as to where you might think of going next. It could be a shortcut!
802210: The behaviour of your diplomat is disgusting. Instead of trying to communicate your good intentions, the belching toad circles them, looking them up and down as if to appraise their value. When he places a greasy hand on one of the warrior's cheeks, another woman breaks from the pack and plants her lance in his thigh.
802211: Respond to their violence in kind
802213: Firing a few shots skyward is enough. The warriors have only shields and jagged lances, coming as they do from some nobler age. Yet the way they fearfully scurry away suggests they are no strangers to firearms. It feels like a missed opportunity to have got to know them better. All that's left is to tend to the sorry diplomat, whose leg has a very severe bleed.
802214: They are too fast. The distance between your small scouting party and the warriors is made up in moments, as the lithe women dive and roll, and thrust their lances. All your men are killed. The warriors spare your women, however, giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
802215: The warriors seem interested, but watchful
802218: Your exotic supplies intrigue the warriors. Their curiosity overtakes their anger, and seeing how fascinated they are by the crew's maps, the sailors guess that the women might share in their taste for exploration. Sadly, it appears too late to earn the warriors' trust, and they depart looking cautiously over their shoulders. You must tend to the sorry diplomat before you leave, as the bleed from his leg looks severe.
802219: The warriors take great offence. One of them spits on the jacket of an officer. He responds by moving to draw his weapon, but the women are too fast. The lithe warriors dive and roll, and thrust their lances. Every man in your small scouting party loses their lives. The women are spared, however; the warriors giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
802220: Your crew's deference pleases the warriors. Surprised by the sailors' genuflection, the women giggle and lower their guard, lifting your explorers' chins with the tips of their lances. They may not speak your language, but their body language is unequivocal — they are fellow adventurers, and wish to celebrate your meeting. A huge bonfire is made from the wooden barricades, and all enjoy their boozy punch and haunches of venison — which the women insist on eating raw. The wild party lasts long into the night.
802221: Not everyone in your party shows respect. Some are snickering about something, and the warrior women presume it concerns them. They spit at the men, who reach hot-bloodedly for their weapons.
802224: This pleases them, since out of everything, they are always most fond of a good fight. Your men are honourable and choose to fight hand-to-hand. It is a noble and even contest, punctuated by the metallic rasp of sword and spear, ending in stalemate. Both combatants have suffered injuries, and the two sides part with greater respect for their foes. Still, their wounds will need looking after...
802225: They are too fast. The distance between your small scouting party and the warriors is made up in moments, as the lithe women dive and roll, and thrust their lances. All your men are killed. The warriors spare your women, however, giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
802226: The sailors, especially the men, feel humiliated. "Those warrior women were strident," says one, "I had absolutely no idea how I should respond to such provocation. They wanted us to draw our swords, which of course would have been wholly inappropriate!" The women, on the other hand, can't help but dream of escaping this suffocating ship, to take up a lance and shield of their own.
802229: A boulder-blocked entrance and a booby-trapped corridor: typical Mesoan temple. After a fall down a slide and a crash into uncharted caves, your team of explorers jokes about the situation in an attempt to forget its deathly aspect. They know what people say of Mesoan mazes: the deeper you go, the shinier it gets.
802230: Follow the suggested route and progress through the traps
802231: Create your own path and push the boulder away
802232: The obvious traps are easily evaded. The sailors contort themselves to avoid sharp stones and plated triggers, flowing through the corridor with the ease of seasoned explorers or cutpurses. They quickly reach the pocket of the temple: a vast chasm crossed by a meager bridge with no handrails. Could this be a trial of courage?
802234: You pass the trial! As they wave their arms to keep their balance, your sailors brush against ropes suspended around the bridge, hidden by a clever camouflage of paint and shadow play. They grasp the ropes to steady their footing, and a distant mechanism clicks. A rumbling door opens on the other side of the chasm, revealing the exit - and, on its threshold, a shiny artifact.
802235: Nothing rewards your sailors' recklessness. It's unclear whether the bridge is shaking because of its own frailty, or because of your explorers' quivering legs. Soon the crew are on their knees, creeping across the moldy planks and begging for their mothers. They reach the other side without a scratch, save for their wounded pride, and find a tunnel which leads them outside after some more crawling.
802237: The climb is child's play. Rock walls provide a much steadier footing than wind-flogged masts.
