After racing from guide to guide through the depths of the mountain range, the crew find themselves devoid of a chaperone: the guide supposed to take them on the last leg hasn't shown up at the time you agreed. Forget what initial goal you had in mind - getting off the snow-topped peak is the only priority now.
802611: Traverse the mountain on your own
802613: Your navigators make do without a guide. They take note of landmarks as they progress, relying on their compasses to follow a single direction, staying put during the night despite their dwindling supplies. At long last, they find a stream of melted snow, and follow it downhill to the foot of the mountain. The crew survived, but it was a tough effort.
802614: A guide would have been helpful. Your sailors navigate the mountain paths to the best of their ability, but they aren't skilled enough for the task at hand. The narrow roads disappear beneath the mist of the snow and branch out around the skeletal trees, forcing your crew to spread out. When the explorers reach a decent camping ground and count their numbers, five of them are missing.
802618: Go forward, leaving marks for the lost sailors to follow
802619: Go back and look for the missing sailors
802620: The foot of the mountain, at last. The crew progress step by step, testing the frozen snow for gaps while leaving piles of stones for the lost sailors to follow. Building the landmarks takes time, but it helps avoid any backtracking. The main group is soon joined by the missing sailors, who are disgruntled at having been left behind, despite the crew's best efforts to guide them. Soon their ordeal is over, however, as they reach the end of the mountain range in silence, left speechless with relief.
802621: The explorers get more lost with each passing day. They venture deep into the mountain and quickly abandon the idea of leaving marks for the lost sailors, too concerned for their own survival. The frost solidifies their clothes, steals their toes and rots their food.
802622: Follow a stream of melted snow running downhill
802623: Force your way through the mounds of powder snow
802624: Prioritise your supplies and look for food
802625: Your sailors manage to follow the stream to the foot of the mountain. The stream flows in and out of the frozen ground, playing hide and seek with the desperate crew. They are not the only ones using the trickle as a guide: just before reaching the plains below the mountain, they meet with the missing sailors, who are quenching their burning thirst in the meagre snow stream. It's unclear which of the two teams is the most pitiful, but all are alive.
802626: Where did they come from? Where should they go? The melting snow splits into a web of entangled streams, which buries under the ground and resurfaces without any apparent logic. The crew are taken by the illusion that the forest around them is flat, and can no longer tell if they are climbing or descending. They split like the streams themselves, to each sailor their trickle - but like the streams, not all of them find the foot of the mountain.
802627: The sailors draw strength from their last resources. They ignore the colossal distance they have to cross, and focus on small milestones instead. Two steps to that tree. Three steps to that rock. The snow parts as they advance, drawing dark trenches which run across the pure white mantle, and which eventually - finally - reach the foot of the mountain. The crew stumble and fall in relief when they realise they made it out alive.
802628: The sailors are too weakened by the cold. They dig through the powder snow, only for it to collapse in again without revealing any safe path. Their endurance crippled by the frost, they abandon the task and try to focus on less demanding options.
802629: The crew extend their stay in the cold to gather supplies. Game is scarce, and hunting takes time. However, the food makes for a decent meal, and the smell of roasted hare fills the sailors' stomachs almost as well as the meat itself. The light from the fire spreads through the forest at night, and beckons the missing sailors. Reunited, the crew avoid talking about abandoning their companions, and they leave the mountain in silence.
802630: Your hunters fall prey to the mountain. Animals' tracks sprinkle the fresh snow, but their owners are invisible, hidden in holes and burrows. The hunters are unused to such terrain. As they progress through the forest, discussing where snares could be most efficient, the frozen ground suddenly breaks beneath them, and a handful of sailors fall into a deep fault.
802631: The missing sailors are found, and with them an exit. The idea of losing their companions pushes the hunters to persevere. Broken twigs, brushed moss, mud splashes: everything is a hint. They follow the trail to a crossing and find the lost sailors, who welcome them heartily: better yet, they've found a beaten path which leads straight to the foot of the mountain! That they believed in the others and waited for them is a reward in and of itself.
802632: The fresh snow hides the dangers underneath. A powdery white frosting covers everything in sight, and the skies melt into the ground, disguising the horizon. The hunters advance on instinct alone, unable to spot any hints of their previous passage. They find the missing sailors only by encountering the same fate: the frozen ground breaks under their weight. The thin crust of ice hid a fault! Three of the lost men are down there - and two hunters just joined them.
802633: Pull the sailors from the fault, at the risk of falling
802637: The rescue comes at the price of their remaining strength. It takes ten sailors to get one man out of the fault: three to pull, six to hold and one to keep an eye on the trembling layer of ice. The snow weighs them down, pushing when they pull, hissing when they call out. When the last sailor is hauled from the rift, both the rescuers and rescued are broken. They drag themselves downhill. and manage to leave the clutch of the mountain.
802638: The ordeal is much bigger than your sailors. They launch ropes into the rift, but the slippery walls of ice cannot be climbed. The rescuers attempt to haul the others up, and they plant their feet into the ground, pulling, heaving and panting, their physical reserves long drained by the cold. As they fall to their knees and break their nails on the frozen hemp, the rift cracks, and the mountain opens its mouth wide. The crewmates it swallows are never seen again.
802639: Salvation at the price of their humanity. Ignoring the begging screams of their companions, the sailors make a large detour to avoid falling into the frozen rift. As they find a beaten path heading downhill, a sailor catches up to the group, panting: he admits to having thrown some pickaxes and ropes down the fault. The crew congratulate him for his selflessness, and pretend his good deed is enough to ease their conscience.
802640: The path is easy to recognize, but it is tortuous and unforgiving. The crew fight against the elements, hurrying through the mountain passages with haste, lest their tracks disappear and leave them without hints to follow. When they finally escape the mountain range, they cannot remember how many nights they spent walking, and how many days they spent starving.
802643: An overweight ship is easy prey for stormy waves. The oil merchants your crew met at the last harbour paid good money for their cargo to be stored aboard your ship, but the weight isn't really something your vessel can handle. At the first signs of tempest winds and cutting waves, the unusual ballast makes your ship heel furiously.
802645: Improvise a sea anchor on the surface of the water
802646: Safe. The cast-iron shank of the anchor plunges into the shifting waves with a large splash, the amount of chain being just right for it to take a good hold of the seabed. The ship wobbles, washed by the winds and the waves, but manages to stay put. The sailors simply wait for the storm to pass, and hope the extra load will not cause any more problems.
802647: A miss - the crew should go hide in the lower decks. The anchor is released, its chain unravelling by itself more than it is controlled, and the large iron cross reaches the bottom with too much play to properly grip the sea floor. As it becomes apparent the anchor won't be of any help, the lieutenants order the crew to descend to the bottom decks of the swinging ship - but the oil merchants refuse to leave the apparent safety of their upper cabins.
802648: Take the time to present this solution as the best
802649: Drug them to avoid losing any more time
802650: The lost time was necessary. Your lieutenants carefully convince the merchants, detailing all available options one by one, despite the increasingly high pressure from the waves, and the rocking of the ship. Their stoicism more than their arguments convinces the merchants to follow the orders, and they join the rest of the crew on the lower deck until the storm comes to pass.
802651: A waste of time.Pressed by the urgency of the situation and unable to get their thoughts in order, your lieutenants cannot properly convince the merchants. As they begin to lose their nerve, the ship swerves and slams into the shore. Whistling winds invade the perforated hull, and water seeps in its wake.
802652: Repair the hole while the water is still pouring
802653: Move the ballast to lift the hole above sea level
802654: Your crew are used to making repairs in poor conditions. Ignoring the swinging floor, the sailors focus on the hull, their legs deep in the pouring water. Drenched supplies lap around their legs as they fight to plug the hole. The seal will not last long, but it should hold until the next harbour.
802655: Your crew's speed cannot match the water's. Overwhelmed by the current, and unable to prioritise their tasks or even shape a plan for the repairs, the sailors quickly abandon the idea of patching up the hull. They flee to the upper deck, and brace themselves as the ship crashes on the shore. The repairs take weeks.
802656: The forced instability protects the ship. Your sailors huff and puff as they push the large sacks of basalt stones across the belly of the ship, progressively tipping the vessel's balance until its pierced flank leans away from the water. The ship is carefully led to the shore, where the crew can finally start repairs.
802657: A ludicrous plan. Your sailors wheeze and gasp as they try to pull the basalt sacks, but their efforts are not enough to make the ballast budge. The ship remains level, allowing more and more water in, as it sinks under the intrusion. Several sailors drown, trapped between the deck's roof and the swirling currents, and their bodies cannot be evacuated before the storm calms down.
802658: Safe and drunk. The merchants accept the liquid courage and drink its laced contents, falling asleep before they can finish their bottle. They're dragged to the lower deck along with the rest of the crew and whatever supplies the sailors could carry, their combined weight counterbalancing the pounding of the waves. The storm soon calms down, leaving the crew to deal with the hangover of their passengers.
802659: Too weak. The drinks your sailors offer the merchants in an attempt to soothe their anger are far too poorly made to have any kind of impact on them. As they continue to struggle against your crew, a vivid growl resonates through the ship. You came too close to shore, and the reefs have pierced your hull! Water starts to pour into the lower decks.
802660: The sea anchor works as intended. Your sailors quickly cable up a weighty assemblage, and after fastening it securely, let it drop into the waves. It pulls against the water to increase the ship's drag, gaining it enough stability to keep its broadside away from the waves. The crew, relieved, can wait for the storm to pass.
802661: The sea anchor sinks as soon as it touches the water. The sailors tack together some extra sails to try and assemble a sea anchor, but the ballooning cloths snap as soon as they're thrown into the waves. As the ship is pushed towards the shore, the backwash gets more and more ample, until a rogue wave of ludicrous proportions rises above the sea. The merchant passengers beg your crew to save them!
802664: Throw the oil cargo overboard to calm the seas
802665: Fearless. Despite the battering gale and clobbering currents, your crew manage to keep the ship straight, as you face the rogue wave head on. The wave crashes into your vessel with all its rage and natural power, but the straight bow cuts its fury in two, and the ship avoids most of the damage - a rock among the waters. When the storm calms down, your crew focus on the repairs, and consider how exceptional their survival was.
802666: Too audacious. The gusts of wind fill your sails, and the frantic currents pull at your hull. Your crew are far too untrained to keep control over the ship. Entailed by the sea's passion, the ship leaps and falls, dancing until the shore catches it and stops its mad waltz. The vessel's carcass finally remains still, as water and bodies flow from its bent silhouette.
802669: The water's anger dies out! Moving the merchants aside with ease and dismissing their plea, your sailors heave the oil barrels over the railings, and let their contents spill around the ship. The oil hugs the water and rolls over the waves, dissolving the wind's grip, and slowing the water's movement. The threat of the waves is no more, but the merchants' trust and cargo were lost in the process.
802670: Their greed overcomes your strength. The sailors first try to reason, and then try to force the merchants into giving up their precious oil, but your crew are weak in both body and spirit, while the merchants built their fortunes on hard-headedness. Long after the ship has been hit, crushed, and stranded, the merchants's cadavers are found lying on the shore's pebbles, still clutching their barrels of cargo.
802673: Local authorities come aboard looking for the fugitive you've taken in. A man in rags offered you his services in a port, saying he'd do any odd job for some food and the chance to join your crew. The captain agreed to take him on. He soon grew on your sailors, working hard and filling in wherever needed. But above all he has proved a man of principle — a champion of the vulnerable — and as such, the crew have learned to respect his silence on the matter of his past.
802676: They'll have to fight you for him
802677: Offer to pay the fugitive's bail
802679: Your crew stick stoically to the same story. "This man," the officials say, holding up a picture of their new friend, "have you seen him?" "Oh no, no," your sailors reply. Still, the officials conduct a cursory search, but the man of many talents has no difficulty in hiding from them. When they've gone, there is a hearty cheer. "Glad to have you with us!" bellows the captain. You have a new recruit!
802680: Your attempt at deception fails. The officer in charge lies that your ship has never docked at the port in question, yet the officials present a logbook stating conclusively that it did. This only serves to further rouse suspicion that he is somewhere on board.
802683: Hidden in plain sight! Sensing how thorough the inspection is going to be, there's only one possible bolthole for your runaway. "Get in the lifeboat, and keep your head down," the crewman whispers, while his pursuers are being detained on some pretence in the captain's cabin. To complete the plan, the lifeboat is then winched above the eyeline, where sure enough, the authorities never think to look. Not wanting to cause further trouble, he insists on leaving at the next port.
802684: "There he is! Seize him!" The fugitive is still trying to make himself comfortable among a pyramid of barrels when his pursuers appear. They tackle him and clap him in chains.
802687: They don't give in easily. Your sailors wait until the officials pass them by before knocking them to the floor, and confiscating their weapons. A shrill whistle sounds from the other ship, and armed men in smart navy uniforms pour up the boarding plank onto your deck. There follows a heavy skirmish, but your sailors gain the upper hand. The authorities surrender and retreat. Though grateful, your fugitive wishes to avoid causing further injury by his presence, and insists on leaving at the next port.
802688: The fugitive dies, along with his pursuers. When your men try to lay hands on the port officials, they put a pistol to the fugitive's head. "Try to stop us, and he gets it," they say. When your men try to be clever, they blow the fugitive's head off, then do the same to one of your men, before they themselves can be subdued. The dead prisoner was very popular aboard ship, and your crew wonder if things could possibly have turned out worse.
802689: Your crew offer no resistance. They part before the two officials as they frogmarch the fugitive over the gangplank to their vessel. He tries to express his thanks to your crew for their efforts, but the official growls "no more of your activism", and slaps him sharply across the chops. The prisoner was very popular aboard your ship, and your crew believe more should have been done to defend him.
802690: Your threat is impressive indeed. Rows of dark, iron mouths poke from their hatches, ready to fire at point blank range! "You must be mad!" says one official, as they skip back across the gangplank to their own ship, suddenly most anxious to leave! Your fugitive is thankful, but does not wish to endanger your expedition further, and waves a warm goodbye at the next port.
802691: Your men hesitate at the order, because they can see the neighbouring ship is not one to be trifled with. Eyeing your sailors as they not-so-secretly prepare for battle, one of the officials sounds his shrill whistle, and a troop of navy-uniformed soldiers rush up from below deck. They fully intend to board you.
802693: Let them board ship and take the man
802694: They don't give in easily. A second shrill whistle sounds from the other ship, and the navy-uniformed brigade pour up the boarding plank and onto your deck, where your men sit ready for them. There follows a heavy skirmish. Some are injured, but your forces prevail. The authorities surrender and depart. Though grateful, your fugitive wishes to avoid causing further injury by his presence, and insists on alighting at the next port.
802695: There's no time. Your men, still concerned with preparing for the sea battle, are thrown into disarray. "To deck, men! To deck!" is the cry, as they dive for their guns and rush to the deck, only to be cut down, one-by-one by the men in blue. "Fools!" smirks the official, as the fugitive is trussed in chains, "To think so many died for this worthless streak of spittle... Take him away!"
802696: You have a new recruit! "You're welcome to him!" says the more senior of the two officials brightly, "We had no idea he was so important to you." His colleague glances at him nervously, before wrinkling up a fake smile of his own. It's obvious they only chose to call off their pursuit because your vessel is far more powerful than theirs. With your ship free to continue, the former fugitive raises a glass. "Thank you all," he says, "here's to a triumphant expedition, and beyond!"
802697: The officials seem undaunted. "Oh, I think we have little to fear from a ship as ill-equipped yours. Still, from your hostility, it's clear you're hiding the man we seek." They signal back to their own vessel to ready arms. "Now... think carefully. Do you really want to refuse to give him up?"
802700: It's a point blank exchange, in which your ship manages to get the first shot, disabling half the men opposite. As such, the return fire is not so crippling as it might have been— although significant repairs will still be needed. As the two ships drift apart, the officials are left in helpless, comic isolation on your ship's deck. Someone gives them a good old shove overboard, forcing the other ship to return to rescue them. Your crew make their escape. "I will burden you no further," says the fugitive wearily, "please, allow me to alight at the next opportunity."
802701: It only serves to demonstrate your crew's incompetence, because they are still not ready! The vessel belonging to the local authority fires first — and at such close range, the effect is devastating. Half your gunners lie maimed, and your ship is shredded through. You wave the white flag. The fugitive leaves with the officials of his own free will — after all, he has better chances of survival almost anywhere else!
802702: Your crew offer no resistance. They part before the two officials as they frogmarch the fugitive over the gangplank to their vessel. He tries to express his thanks to your crew for their efforts, but the official growls "no more of your activism", and slaps him sharply across the chops. The prisoner was very popular aboard your ship, and your crew believe more should have been done to defend him.
802703: The fugitive wears a look of stoic resignation, as his terms of release are discussed.
802706: You have a new recruit! "I will repay your trust in me tenfold!" says the talented fellow, as the local authority departs with their payment. He raises a beaker of navy rum, "Thank you all! Here's to a triumphant expedition, and beyond!"
802707: You can't afford him. Seeing that your men are still reluctant to let the fugitive go, the order is given to lower the footbridges, and a troop of navy-uniformed soldiers file into line, ready to board your ship.
802708: The fugitive does not resist. With a look of stoic resignation, the man offers the officials his hands to be shackled. He turns back one last time before he goes, to say "Thank you for everything," — dignified until the very last. The crew shall miss his company greatly.
802711: Castaways request your help, but where could they be? Shark-baiting is a common distraction for your sailors, but their latest catch provided much more entertainment than expected. In its belly was a bottle, and in the bottle were three sheets of paper, each a copy of the same message in different languages. Piecing together the documents to make up for their weathered content, the crew can make out a call for help and a latitude, but nothing more.
802712: Examine the entrails of the shark for clues
802713: Map the islands matching the partial coordinates
802714: There's no time to spare for such things
802715: The stomach of the shark reveals its travels. Glittering corals, exotic scales, and characteristic fish bones - your doctors finish their inspection of the shark's entrails and confirm your destination: to the Southern coral barriers! When the ship reaches the correct latitude, several islands litter the horizon. The crew hesitates to come any closer. The water is shallower than usual, and filled with sharp coral reefs.
802718: Navigate closer to the islands and their reefs
802719: Stay away and have the look-out search for castaways
802720: Your ship avoids the deadly reefs and finds the castaways! The vessel groans as it swims through the clear waters, the deepest corals reflecting its shadow as it narrowly avoids them. It takes a short while to find the castaways, entrenched among the dunes of a secluded beach, sprouting from it with squeals of joy and disbelief. Their captain offers his unalienable loyalty, and your crew gladly welcomes the newcomers.
802721: The ship cannot pass the underwater barrier. Despite your navigator's efforts, the ship bumps against the coral reef - the manoeuvre is too complex and too risky for her. The crew are forced to turn their backs on the paradisiacal islands. Whether the castaways were real, and whether they were indeed stranded here, they will never know.
802722: Found them! Your look-out shows their brilliance when they spot the thin smoke line of a campfire in the distance. A dinghy is sent to retrieve the castaways, and comes back filled to the brim with men with overgrown beards, torn clothes, and awed expressions. Their captain pledges himself to your crew. Once shaved and washed, the castaways prove themselves to be excellent sailors - and even better companions.
802723: The look-out draws a blank. Scanning the islands from afar is a difficult exercise, made even harder by the lack of experience. The crew soon realises that it will never find anyone from such a distance. Reluctant to risk the ship's integrity over the mere possibility of the castaways' existence, your sailors choose to leave and forget.
802724: The homemade autopsy is a mess. The shark's entrails are cut along with their contents, and spilled over the deck is a nauseous mass of gore and artefacts of unknown origin. The doctor cannot make sense of the anarchy he's created.
802725: Interpret the patterns in the shark's entrails
802727: Relentless faith guides the most deserving. In the spilled guts of the shark, your navigators see the shapes of islands, your doctors see the patterns of life forms, and your boatswain sees the promise of rewards. Driven by an inner force beyond simple greed, the crew sails past coral reefs and insidious currents, and finds the island on which the castaways had been waiting for rescue. Their relief is glorious, and their captain promises to serve your crew!
802728: There is nothing to find but deceit. Your cooper burns some sage among the remains of the shark, and sniffs the lumpy smoke. If forces do talk to him, they might have been beyond what he could handle: he suddenly pounces on the closest sailor, crushing her throat between his hands. Three more fall before his frenzy drives him overboard with an otherworldly scream. The castaways are cursed, and the sailors mourn their comrades for the rest of the trip.
802729: Shark, bottle and messages are thrown overboard. Several sailors protest against the rash decision - they'd have preferred to exhaust all options before giving up, or at least kept the messages to share them at the next harbour. The imagined blame and grief of the castaways haunts them for a while.
802730: The search defines a specific area. Many islands match the latitude, but far fewer could be mapped on an actual shipping route. By deducing where the castaways' ship might have gone, your navigators identify a handful of islands which could host the castaways. After two weeks of smooth sailing, your ship reaches the area: a necklace of islands linked by strands of deadly coral reef.
802731: Your navigator is overwhelmed by the mass of possibilities. Unable to agree on a proper searching method, yet alone define a list of reasonable possibilities, they abandon their task and admit the crew might as well try to work out the contents of the entrails. It's said as a joke, however, some sailors consider the idea.
802732: The bottle and its messages are thrown back into the sea. The crew's regrets drift away with the bottle, and the castaways are soon forgotten.
802735: Your chaplain is going overboard with his preaching. Blaming the expedition's mishaps and misfortunes on the supposed heresy of the ship's officers, the man of faith manages to rouse the gradual distrust and anger of the sailors. His preaching is now part of the crew's daily routine. His words find an echo in the mouths of the sailors, and your lieutenants can see their authority slipping away.
802736: Demonstrate that his doubts are fuelled by a mental illness
802737: Discredit him in a direct confrontation
802738: Simply punish him, without taking measures against his ideas
802739: The man of faith belongs in an asylum. Your doctor interrupts the chaplain's daily sermon and accuses him of megalomania, listing the traits of the madness: desire for attention, a craving for control, and an overwhelming urge to rouse the paranoia of others in order to match one's own. The portrait is a perfect depiction of the chaplain, and, despite their former affection for the man, the sailors agree that he should be sedated with laudanum for the rest of the trip.
802740: The doctor only proves his own paranoia. Your doctor interrupts the chaplain's daily sermon with a loud declaration, stating that the man of faith is, in fact, a soul tormented by a mental illness. With all eyes on him, your doctor utters a list of personal opinions rather than medical facts, and the chaplain welcomes his doubts with benevolence. His influence flourishes, and your lieutenants have to make do with him for the rest of the trip.
802741: Your diplomat has a greater way with words. She silently enters the lower deck during the chaplain's daily preaching, and waits in a corner of a room. When the man of faith finally loses his nerve and asks her what she wants, she lists two hours worth of the chaplain's arguments and, without pause, offers counterpoints for each of them. The humiliation is magnificent, and the chaplain's babbling defence convinces the crew of his puerility. They lose interest.
802742: Your diplomat was not ready to face the chaplain. She confronts the preacher before the crew, and flaunts her interpretation of the chaplain's mistakes, stating how wrong he is without taking into account the weeks of argument he'd built with his followers. Her diatribe convinces none but herself, and the chaplain simply remarks that her anger is proof of his being right. Your lieutenants have to make do with his whims for the rest of the trip.
802743: Not the most diplomatic solution, but it works. Trusted sailors interrupt the chaplain during his daily preaching and drag him to the upper deck, where your first mate welcomes the man of faith with a devoted flogging. The display of violence mostly proves the preacher's point, but the menace of the officers' ire is greater than the crew's distrust in them. The trip resumes in a climate of tension.
802746: Pirates! The torn black flag bearing a skull and crossbones is a shock to those on your expedition who thought they were a dying breed. The weather-worn ship emerges from the mist with prepared to plunder. Astride her bow stands her colourful captain, axe raised; along her rails, the spectral silhouette of her starving crew, hungry to feed.
802748: Have an officer make a rousing speech
802749: You swivel on a sixpence, ready to blow them away! Quickly setting sails to curb momentum, your ship turns in the shallowest possible arc for a vessel this size — a manoeuvre only a tactician well-accustomed to risk would attempt. Meanwhile, some of the crew have improvised a few grenades, should you want to make use of them...
802750: The turn is not sharp enough. There was nothing wrong with the idea, but whatever tactical advantage your ship may have had is lost with the rather cautious turning circle it plots, out of which the ship emerges a slow-moving target.
802753: The pirates are sunk before they have chance to do any damage at all! Your ship's guns target the most mould-ridden flank of the corsairs' ship, smashing it through. The antique vessel collapses in on itself, and your sailors enjoy the resulting plunder almost as if they themselves had been the pesky picaroons.
802754: It's a disappointing salvo. Despite being in a strong position, your cannons are miscalibrated, and end up firing short. The pirates know they cannot win this with their outmoded gunnery, and between shots they draw in close, latching onto your ship with their boarding hooks.
802757: Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The rowdy band charge aboard only to find your resolute crew arranged in a classical shield wall, with percussion cap pistols poking out of what few gaps remain. Although your crew sustain fairly gruesome injuries from pirate axes, all but one survive. That young lad is given a funeral, unlike the poor dead pirates.
802758: You're lucky they don't leave with your ship! Some of your sailors are equipped with old flintlocks, whose inaccuracy permits the enemy to engage at close quarters. The swordplay proceeds so terribly on your side that a section of pirates are able to reach the lower deck, and pilfer all they find. Satisfied, their captain bays "fall back!" and the scourge are gone, leaving your crew to count the dead.
802759: "Take all you want, but please, don't hurt us!" your officer pleads. The pirate captain grins, revealing a jumbled set of shark teeth, before proceeding to strip the chap of his ear. "Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.
802760: The pirates weren't expecting such a crafty attack. "I was saving these for a special occasion," your weaponsmith burps. The 'special brew' he's concocted consists of a bottle filled with powder, a hemp fuse, and a nail surprise. There's a shimmering sound as they explode, and when the smoke clears, your crew frisk the punctured bodies littering the deck, singing "Rollicking band of pirates, we!"
802761: Ineffective to say the least. The improvised grenades are duff fireworks, and when landing on the pirate deck, they fail to discharge. There is no time to apportion blame, for the tide of battle has swung again in favour of the pirates, who have hooked the two ships together for boarding.
802764: You make the best of a poor position. At the last moment, your maverick navigators cut inside the approaching pirates, who had been hoping to board you. Your crew have the breathing space now to act!
802765: The navigators fail to recover from the initial setback. Your helmsman has no tricks left up his sleeves, and cannot pick up speed to outrun the approaching pirates. They intend to board you!
802768: After a long exchange, the pirates are sunk! Damage is done to both ships, before finally your men "cross the T" by releasing a full broadside into their prow. Immediately, the enemy ship is guzzling water. Any plunder floating above the wreck can serve as compensation for the minor damage you've received.
802769: It is a damaging encounter. The rotted exterior of the pirate vessel invites cannon fire, but their movements are too clever, never exposing their flanks to a broadside. Keen to corner them, your officers overcommit, and in doing so, leave themselves open to a devastating barrage. The pirates take the chance to flee — which is fortunate, because your ship is almost dead in the water.
802770: Your crew go beserk for the fight. Most of the ramshackle pirate crew fall in the first bloodthirsty charge, while your raiders suffer only one or two casualties. While the pirates bleed out, your men deprive them of any ill-gotten plunder they have. You then scupper the barque, and watch as it disappears, black flags and all, to meet Davy Jones.
802771: Your crew don't seem too keen. Perhaps they know they won't stand a chance going hand-to-hand with seasoned pirates. As the two ships adjoin, it's the pirates who make the charge. Almost immediately, a pirate swings an axe and lops off a head. Horrified, your steersman hurriedly spins your ship away, with fighters on both sides falling into the resulting chasm. Your depleted crew flees at full speed.
802774: It is a saddening scene. To see this many brave fighters put to the sword is regrettable. Fortunately, the losses are largely on the other side; the pirates' antique weaponry ever more a disadvantage in the modern age. When the last scrawny dog is dead, you set their ship alight like a funeral barque. Your own sailors, still twitching from the skirmish, pour themselves long jars of rum, and remember the fallen.
802775: You are no match for the pirates. The attackers pour in like beetles from all sides, a many-legged brood washing over your forces like some unstoppable plague, crushing all resistance. "I know it's a good'un, but we ain't taking the ship..." the pirate captain is heard to utter by a few survivors, who were cowering behind a locked door, "...just everything on it!" When the sound of looting and cheering has died away, the survivors emerge to find the expedition ship stripped of pretty well everything it had.
802776: Should have waved the white flag sooner. Your weapons drop and the pirate captain saunters aboard. She is tall and surprisingly aged, dressed in the dashing clothes of a bygone era, "For our trouble, we'll have some of yer crew for slaves," she growls, "all of 'em left of this line." She swishes her cutlass and portions off several of your crew as her playthings. After that, she turns more amicable, as her horde loot your ship. As they leave, she drops a feathered glove to show her gratitude.
802777: "Take all you want, but please, don't hurt us!" your officer pleads. The pirate captain grins, revealing a jumbled set of shark teeth, and proceeds to strip the chap of his ear. "Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.
802778: Your men are resolute following the speech. Your acting lieutenant points his sabre to the sky, defying the heavens themselves. "If I, born with gas lighting, heated water, and a silver spoon in mouth..." with each fresh admission a cheer goes up, "If I can enjoy chopping through these mangy pirates, then you lot will bloody well be in heaven!" There is a raucous cheer as the men prepare for their orders.
802779: There's neither spirit nor courage to be roused. Your crew instead seem transfixed by the approaching spectre of doom. Even as the horde board, the defenders' minds seem elsewhere, hypnotised perhaps by the tall and angular captain with greying hair and a wizened visage, who stalks the deck juicing your sailors. Once the pirates have taken everything they desire, they leave just as mysteriously as they appeared.
802782: It is indeed a heroic charge. Led by the acting lieutenant, your sailors hurtle down the boarding bridges and storm the pirate ship, leaving a mangled trail in their wake. The black flag is ripped from the mast, and the pirate's booty is plundered. Unexpectedly, however, your lieutenant then impishly permits the survivors to go free — "Come now, be humble in thy victory! For how dull would the world be without these old pirate salts!"
802783: Pirates are always ready for a skirmish! Having delayed boarding until they were properly armed and ready, your men fail to make use of their conviction. On seeing the pirate planks fall first, your lieutenant backtracks, urging caution in the face of the oncoming horde!
802784: Stay put and pick them off
802786: You only take a few losses between reloads, when wild pirates set upon the soldiery with cutlasses and handaxes. Suddenly there is a cry from the pirate ship. The pirate captain has been hit! Clutching her chest, she is borne away below deck on the shoulders of her shipmates. The pirates immediately withdraw so that they may attend to their queen.
802787: The first round of rifle fire misses, and there is no time to prepare a second before the horde are on top of your crew, binding the strongest first, and maiming those who resist. When the hurly-burly's over, the pirates prop your bound survivors against each other as they trawl the ship for goodies, before they wish you "fair winds" and depart, cackling with glee.
802788: Your men don't hesitate having come this far. There is a din as the two packs collide, like rugby players, over the divide between the boats. Blood surges over the wooden boards, as men fall on both sides. Finally, the pirates are driven back, at which point they retract their boarding planks and raise their sails to the breeze, spinning away to prey on victims less chewy.
802789: Your men hesitate a second too long, and the pirates have made up the distance between the ships. Now they've been allowed on board, they have the upper hand, and are soon on top of your crew, binding them and maiming those who resist. When the hurly-burly's done, the pirates prop your bound survivors against each other as they trawl the ship for goodies, before wishing you "fair winds" and departing, cackling with glee.
802790: The pirates are sunk before they have a chance to do any damage at all! Your ship's guns target the most mould-ridden flank of the corsairs' ship, smashing it through. The antique vessel collapses in on itself, and your sailors enjoy the resulting plunder almost as if they themselves had been the pesky picaroons.

"Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.
802796: Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The rowdy band charge aboard only to find your resolute crew arranged in a classical shield wall, with percussion cap pistols poking out of what few gaps remain. Although your crew sustain fairly gruesome injuries from pirate axes, all but one survive. That young lad is given a funeral, unlike the dead pirates.
802797: You're lucky they don't leave with your ship! Some of your sailors are equipped with old flintlocks, whose inaccuracy permits the enemy to engage at close quarters. The swordplay proceeds so terribly on your side that a section of pirates are able to reach the lower deck, and pilfer all they find. Satisfied, their captain bays "fall back!" and the scourge are gone, leaving your crew to count the dead.
802800: Behind bars! The prolonged stay of your ship in this harbour is not what you intended. Obscure laws were breached, and your whole crew has found themselves arrested under the pretence that the region's borders, whose nature remains unknown, were not respected. Heavily armed foreigners lead your crew through the sinuous roads of their city and into the local jail; after passing by a row of freshly hanged criminals, the sailors are locked up. Only two guards keep watch, their heads bobbing with fatigue. Are they underestimating your crew?
802803: Prepare your defence for the upcoming trial
802804: Just two guards is not enough to contain your science. The doctor brings out a sachet of vials and packets, and produces leathery pouches filled with white powders, some matte, some glittering like sugar. He mixes a bit of this one and a bit of that one, gauging measures with the eye of the seasoned practitioner, then calls to the guards. When the unsuspecting wardens are close enough, the doctor blows the mixture in their face. The men drop dead!
802805: The doctor showcases his ignorance. He produces a pouch of arsenic before calling the guards. When the jailers are close enough, the doctor is ready to blow the powder in their face - however, his lack of knowledge of the poison's properties backfires. The soft inhalation of the doctor is enough to bring the highly volatile poison to his lips, and he leaps back, coughing and wheezing. The guards immediately understand this was attempted murder.
802806: Disguise yourselves as guards and escort the rest of the crew
802807: Avoid drawing any attention and sneak outside
802808: The escape is flawless. Two of your sailors don the guards' uniforms and drag the rest of the chained crew through the prison. When they are stopped at the exit, they mimic the local accent, briefly explain the liberation, and kick one of the chained sailors for good measure. The legitimate wardens buy the lie! It takes an even greater effort to refrain from laughing before reaching the ship and leaving the port.
802809: An attempt way beyond their ability. Two sailors put on the guards' uniforms and lead the crew through the prison, until some legitimate guards stop them and enquire about the strange cortège. The disguised men's fidgety attitude and suspiciously foreign accent is enough to convince the wardens to check their original cell: the guards' bodies are found, and with them comes the heavy charge of murder. The following day, the trial is held.
802812: Offer to pay a fine, however high it might be
802813: Plead that they were just following orders, and have the crew repudiate Her Majesty
802814: The judges give your captain a stern look
802817: The price is high, but fair. Most of the expedition's budget is squandered in the brutal fine, and though the crew are cleared of their charges, they find themselves forced to ration their supplies for the rest of the trip. The doctor and his accursed ideas are blamed, and the man is turned into a scapegoat: his rations are regularly stolen, damaging his health and abilities - and, worse, the crew blatantly avoid his treatments.
802818: Who would accept such a meager payment? Murder is not a subject to be triffled with, and the foreign court makes its opinion clear: your crew will pay in the hardest way possible. To show they value life more than your sailors, the judges impose a non-lethal punishment, devising a program of forced labour and precise observation to ensure the sailors suffer as much as possible without dying. Months of hell follow before the crew can leave.
802819: That lie is believable, but it doesn't erase your crew's crimes. The foreign judges put aside any idea of the death sentence, and focus instead on finding a punishment befitting the crime. The crew are arranged into a procession, and made to cross the city in chains while chanting the ill-will of their Queen. Their patriotism tainted, the sailors never dare to speak her name again.
802820: Who would believe such an obvious lie? Why would their Queen ask for such a menial task as poisoning overseas guards? To match the crime, the crew's lieutenants are forced to drink hemlock solutions, before being trapped in a single cell with the rest of the crew. The lieutenants gag and wheeze for days in agony, their skin puffing and their muscles stiffening in impossible positions, until their breathing itself is locked into place. Only then are the sailors allowed to leave.
802821: The perfect crime! Despite their numbers, your sailors manage to sneak through the prison and into the streets, where they become shadows under the moonless night. Led by your most competent hunters, they creep through the back alleys and back yards, until their obscurity returns them to their ship. Feeling like the protagonists of an adventure novel, and revelling in the sentiment, they leave the harbour in the gliding vessel - all lights off, and no sound made.
802822: They are caught! Your sailors' lack of discretion is awkward, and it's only a matter of minutes before a patrol spots them. Without any prepared disguise or lie, they're instantly arrested - and worse, the bodies of the poisoned guards are found on the way back to their cell. The next morning, they're judged not just for their meager trespassing, but for actual murder.
802823: A nice display of craftsmanship. The crew digs a tunnel with skill, taking care to reinforce the structure and analyse the soil's nature as they progress. They avoid the most friable sections of the city's ground and emerge on the coast, exactly as calculated. Your ship's not too far, but a frigate stands guard. However, its lights are off, and the guards onboard might be sleeping rather than actually keeping watch.
802825: A dead end. The crew can handle basic digging, but their progress is reluctant, slowed by the constant fear of being buried in the makeshift tunnel. At the first obstacle they encounter - a large foundation pillar which blocks the way - the sailors hurriedly agree that there is nothing more that can be done with the tunnel. They return to their cell, relieved.
802826: Buried alive. The sailors have but a vague idea of how to dig an escape tunnel. They grind the earth with their bare hands, the pungent soil getting stuck under their nails and lining their clothes, hair, skin. As air comes to lack, so too does their judgement, and the crew push forward, blind to the crumbling rock. The tunnel collapses in on them, and what few sailors were still outside are judged and released without sentence - the death of their companions is deemed punishment enough.
802828: Bombard the frigate as you leave
802829: Swift as a whisper. Your sailors embark on the ship and deploy its sails in an excruciatingly slow manner, timing their flapping and clinking with the melody of the backwash. The vessel creaks softly and lets the sea take it, drifting away from the harbour with delicate movements of to and fro. Soon, the city is but a point on the horizon, and the sailors allow themselves to explode in a clamour of celebration.
802831: Ridiculously visible. Your sailors tiptoe past the guarding frigate with their shadows stretching across the whole deck, their stressed whispers ringing through the night. As a testimony to their poor hunting skill, it takes a barrel in their cheeks for them to realize they have been spotted. The next morning, the judges' verdict takes into account the escape attempt and condemns half of your crew to a month of forced labour.
802832: Offer to pay a fine instead
802833: Force your crew into complying with the unreasonable demand
802834: The judges give your captain a stern look
802837: Bribery is a reasonable option. The payment offered satisfies the judges, who agree to let your sailors go. The crew mutter about the absurd trial and its even more absurd resolution, but their relief shows.
802838: Not enough. The judges scoff at your attempt to bribe them with a so-called fine, and advise your crew to try a higher amount next time. To show they're not so cheap, they extend your crew's penalty to two months of forced labour, and place the sailors under the tightest surveillance. The two months are a mixture of menial and unrewarding tasks, and frequent and unwarranted whipping.
802839: The crew comply. Following their superiors' orders, the sailors accept the judges' penalty and fulfil their obligations to the best of their abilities. One month of forced labour seems harsh, though, even for the local population, who supports the crew's effort and vouch for their liberation. The crew earn an early release, and are left tired but touched by the unexpected appreciation.
802840: The crew refuse to comply. The insistence of your first mate cannot convince the sailors to sacrifice themselves for the good of the crew, and the heated debate that follows is cut short by the judges. If your crew cannot decide who to send into forced labour, all of them will go! Forced to submit, the crew invest their strength into one month of meaningless tasks and incessant bickering among themselves.
802841: An explosive escape! The crew feels whole again aboard their ship, and they now have the tools to face their opponents. The loaded canons fire a volley of precise blasts at the foreign frigate and its harbour, setting the whole coast aflame. Your ship sails away with the blaze in its back, a vision of grandiose might which fills the sailors with pride.
802842: A failed attempt. The sailors lack the skills required to load their cannons under the cover of night. Misguided movements and poor knowledge of the armament makes the canons overflow with powder. When they're fired, the weapons explode and take their gunner with them, offering a loud indication of the escapees' position. The crew are seized and sent back to their cell. At dawn, the judges sentence half the crew to a month of forced labour.
802844: An epic trial! At their first chance to speak, your crew engage in an extensive and thrilling retelling of their adventures, captivating the audience and the judges. They climb and rock benches to mimic past naval battles, engage the public by asking them timely and suspenseful questions, and modify their tales according to the audience's whims. Their trespassing is made part of the story, and as they retell the trial itself, the judges insist on letting them go. They leave as heroes!
802849: Your defence doesn't move the judges. The trial follows obscure local laws, and their meandering unravelling goes beyond what your diplomat is used to. Her words stumble upon the judges' traps, and her lack of understanding of the legal subtleties of the situation is obvious to anyone. To the dismay of your crew, the judges' verdict is harsh: one month of public labour for at least half of your sailors.
802851: Your diplomat is beyond awkward. At the trial, she interrupts the judges to insist on meaningless details, pointing out not your crew's innocence, but rather the reasons why their guilt is, to quote her directly, "not that bad". Her lack of professionalism and conviction is irritating, and the judges interrupt the hearing with a hasty judgement just to stop her. Your crew are coerced into one full month of forced labour, a disproportionate and disheartening sentence.
802853: Cornered by a fearsome Pyrphorian vessel! Your expedition has reached South America at last, and the crew are looking forward to some well-earned rest. Night has fallen, and your ship is already in the tranquil bay when the look out screams "behind us!". There, looming in the darkness, gleams a dragon of iron, its nostrils livid with fire. "It's the vessel that killed Mr. Goode! But this one must be twice as large! We are at their mercy!" However, the bay is hidden from the bright gaze of the moon, and it is possible the dragon has not yet spotted you. If you choose to show yourself, you cannot expect to be a match for the dragon - only to somehow hinder it long enough to flee.
802855: Your aim is true, but the dragon is gathering its hot breath. To engage the hulking vessel is a humbling experience — the size, the power, the feet-thick armoured hull that your ordnance seems to only bounce limply off. The crew seem defeated, until they realise their precise fire at the dragon's stern, while showing no external sign of damage, appears to have caused a problem in the engine room. As a response, masked figures rush to prime the beastly mouth — a great cannon of fire! You must act quickly.
802856: Maintain your fire on the weakened engine
802857: Your crew cheer the cannoneers, and one good hit to the same spot does the trick! There are loud rasping noises before the ironclad's engines fall silent, and the great monstrosity drifts to a gentle halt. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. You set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, confident it will keep you well-hidden.
802858: Your aim isn't quite as good this time. Your shots roll over the solid iron deck like balls of ivory on a bagatelle board, barely making a dent. The iron dragon's mouth yawns wide above your little boat, and from it, the first plume of fire melts the men at the taffrail. The two hulls are close enough for boarding, but there are just too many of the rogues. Your only options are to cause confusion by throwing some of your stink-pot grenados, or to target the flaming cannon itself.
802859: Aim to disable the dreaded cannon
802860: The shot finds its mark. A canister of gas fueling their weapon whistles free of its housing, and blows fire spasmodically about the deck. Some of the mystery of the enemy disappears in that instant, as the cowled crows fight to regain control. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they begin repairs to the ship.
802861: The shot is good, but it takes too long to line up. Your ship is too close to the dragon's mouth when it's hit, and the eruption of flaming debris is most violent! Your own ship and men are on the receiving end, taking damage and suffering casualties. Luckily, there is chaos enough aboard the Pyrphorian ship for your crew to hightail it out of the bay. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. 802868: The shot only seems to rile the dragon — or its operators, at least. The dragon unleashes a second arc of fire, costing another man his life - but perhaps worse for your crew, it also costs you the power of evasion. You'll have to send a team of saboteurs to destroy that cannon before it can be reloaded, or else try to even the odds by slowing the great dragon.
802869: Send a team to sabotage the fiery cannon
802870: Your soldiers leap across like olympians as the two ships pass close by.The Pyrphorians above the iron deck are few. Holes are blown in the gleeful masks of their welcome party, and your men fight their way to the cannon, dispatching its operators with ease before disconnecting the fuel tank and tossing it overboard. More masks come from below, and your men dive into the water. "If not now, we'll take you later," the thwarted enemy cry, as most of your brave saboteurs clamber back aboard, and your ship speeds away. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they bury the dead, and begin repairs to the ship.

802897: "What was that noise?" gulps the helmsman, but fortunately a metallic scraping is not the prelude to a mighty boom. As the ship is fitfully steered betwixt the mines, hearts palpitate, and sailors wring sweat from their jerseys. When the all clear is finally given, there is not a sailor who fails to offer up a prayer to their goddess.
802898: The awfulness has barely begun. Restless waves conceal a thickening of the mines, and the ship's haphazard path makes impact inevitable. "Brace!" comes a scream from port-side, just prior to a shower of men and timber being propelled violently upward. That no further detonations follow is of little relief to a crew who've lost a good many sailors, and sustained such significant damage to their ship.
802901: The crevasse swallowed your sailors. Attempting to cross the mountain pass was a risk, and your crew paid the price for their desire to test the odds. The rocky path turned to frozen snow, then to the still body of a glacier, its ominous presence plaguing the air with the smell of winter. Night swelled faster than anticipated, and it didn't take long for the less cautious explorers to discover the frailty of ice mantles.
802902: Build a snow anchor to descend into the crevasse
802903: Look for another way into the crevasse
802905: The snow anchor is a reliable solution. Your explorers rope themselves together, passing a safety line of sturdy hemp around their waists, through the mounds of packed snow, and into the hands of selected athletes. They control the rope as the rescue team expertly climbs down. The fallen sailors are in poor condition, and the feeble light and jagged walls do not hint at an easy rescue.
802906: The snow anchor fails your sailors terribly. For most of your crew, a snow anchor is but a vague concept. The rescuers bind themselves to a frail heap of packed snow, and descend into the crevasse one by one. One, two, three men slide along the walls of ice, their weight pulling on the cracking anchor. When the fourth jumps into the rift, the anchor falls with him, and with it the very edge of the ice - burying the crevasse and sealing it forever.
802907: Bind their broken limbs with splints and help them climb
802908: Bind the wounded to the safety rope and pull them up
802909: The best course of action for a most hazardous situation. The splints are not only immobilizing the wounded limbs of the fallen sailors, they're supporting them too, and with the help of their rescuers, they manage to climb to a high enough portion of the ice wall for the others to pull them up. Even the wounded, despite their shaking bodies and frozen injuries, find the strength to join the following cheer.
802910: The splints are torture devices. The splints are well assembled, but the sailors' lack of anatomical knowledge sees them simply binding the splints "wherever", as the wooden aids force the wounded into unnatural movements and postures. When the men are finally pulled up, they're in even more of a dire state than after their fall.
802913: The men are brought to safety! Your sailors bind the wounded with a clever construction of marine knots, providing support to the fallen sailors while spreading their weight across the safety rope. Pulling them up is so easy, the injured can even spare a laugh while swinging across the ice wall. The successful teamwork has brought your sailors closer together than ever, and it's a group of brothers and sisters which brings the wounded back to the ship.
802914: This will never work. The wounded are bound to the safety rope in the roughest way possible, their injuries pressed against the coarse hemp till the fibres are coloured red. Despite the need to leave quickly, there's no way the men can be pulled up without worsening their state. Your sailors need help. Will the crew still on the ship notice their prolonged absence?
802915: Send scouts in the night to find help
802916: Camp and hunt for food while waiting for rescue
802917: Help at last. Your scouts navigate the night-filled glacier with care, marking their route with etchings in the ice. They bring back sailors and an actual pulley, allowing them to rescue the wounded without causing any more harm. The injured men are in a poor state, and will probably suffer from this trial in the long term, but for now they simply savour their survival.
802918: The rescue team also faces the trials of the glacier. Of the two scouts sent, only one comes back, and with him a team of sailors frozen by their numerous detours and hours spent getting lost in the mountain. The pulley they bring is the perfect solution for rescuing the fallen men. The wounded are many, both among the victims and their rescuers, yet none complain: they are alive, if missing a limb or two.
802919: Sufficient supplies are found. Your hunters are much better at crafting snares than rescue harnesses, and they gather game on a regular enough basis that the team can survive until help finally arrives. The diet of bony rabbits wasn't enough to keep your sailors in perfect health, but a couple weeks of care and proper food should put them back on their feet.
802920: The rescue team finds their comrades famished and wasted. Your hunters couldn't find sufficient game in the unforgiving mountain, and the diet of molten ice aggravated the wounded's condition past what they could humanely endure. The sailors stagger back to the ship, leaving two dead behind.
802921: A way in! Following the glacier and identifying its contours by the bumps and gaps of its snow cape, your sailors find a spot of crunchy and brittle ice which covers the entrance of a steep slope leading into the crevasse. The wounded men lie at the bottom, doing their best to muffle their whimpers of pain.
802922: An alternate entrance is found after a long while. Alternate is a euphemism: the sailors went deep into the entrails of the glacier, and instead of finding a way into the crevasse, they discerned a fault in the thin ice wall. Breaking it allowed them inside, but their delayed arrival, rather than soothing the fallen men, instead triggers their ire: couldn't they have come faster? Don't they see their freezing limbs? Don't they know the fright they caused?
802923: The glacier forbids your sailors from finding their way through it. The twisting paths of the frozen structure are too much for the crew, who encountered enough trouble following the main marked glacier route. They're forced to abandon their quest, and must instead go back to the broken mantle and its crevasse. The cold steadily bites and weakens them, and they soon take the same purple tint as the men they are trying to save.
802926: Carry the wounded up the slope

The morning greets them in a glorious scene of dumbfounded relief.
802931: It works, but at what cost? The wounded are pulled more than they are carried, their rescuers lacking both the physical and mental strength required to treat the injured with the care and delicacy they need. When the last man is pulled from the slope, a gruesome noise announces that parts of him have decided to stay in the tunnel. The body is abandoned as the crew hurries back to the ship, disgruntled.

A just dosage of tranquillisers tones down their panic while keeping them conscious, and the wounded let themselves be guided out of the crevasse and back to the ship. When the drugs and the cold wear off, they realise how oblivious they were to the real extent of their injuries.
802935: Their artificial calm lasts eternally. The dosage of tranquillisers is a bit on the nose, and doesn't even take into account the weakened state of the patients. Their panic calms down at an alarming speed, and their consciousness lapses, followed by a sleep so deep it takes away both their breath, and their heartbeat. At least they died peacefully.

The injured stifle their insults and try to live to their companions' expectations, holding their whimpers until they're back on the ship. Their wounds are a nasty sight, but their pride is beaming.

Your sailors try to motivate the wounded through accurate descriptions of their fate, pointing at their darkened limbs and prophesying their coming fall. The injured enter a state of pure terror, screaming continuously and unable to hear themselves, crawling away from the news bearers and deeper into the chasm, until the snow dampens their screams and the sound of their final fall.

802939: Put the wounded out of their misery before leaving
802940: Your sailors' best efforts cannot compensate for the loss of time. The crew's physical ability is excellent, but the cold makes no exceptions when it comes to eating flesh. The wounded are pulled up, and the fangs of ice tear their feet and legs away, the crevasse keeping the trophies as fees for the men's freedom. They're brought back to the ship, but can never truly take part in the expedition again.
802941: A terrible initiative. Several sailors slip into the crevasse, pushing and pulling the wounded up the frozen walls at the cost of what little energy they have. Their panting draws lines of mist around them, and their faint clouds of breath thicken, and thicken, and suddenly evaporate. There is no more saving to be done for the injured and their rescuers.
802942: Heartbreaking. Could they have resolved this in any other way? Your sailors try to ignore the question while they point their guns at their companions, men too frozen now to realize what's about to happen. They die silently, and the absence of protest weighs heavier than any voiced reproach on the would-be rescuers.
802943: They had it coming. This is not your crew's first encounter with the dangers of the wild, yet they persisted in being foolhardy and ignored the basic rules of mountain hiking. Let their fate be a lesson for the other idiots.
802945: "I'll mark her on the map with an S!" says local man Ramón, whom Sir Archibald sent to accompany you. "Why not an X?", says the captain with an air of disappointment. "Sarmento!" says Ramón, his eyes sparkling with life, "Finding her is the key to everything". Having travelled for many days along the New World coast, it is now time to decide how you will travel on from here. Ahead, a broad brown rivermouth invites you upstream, its perils waiting unseen beyond its bends. "Perhaps a route over land will be more forgiving?", says the navigator hopefully. One look at the dark and foreboding line of trees would suggest nothing could be further from the truth. "But which is the lesser of two evils, Admiral?"
802947: The Pyrphorian dragon is back on your tail! It seems hard to believe at first, but the distant chugging of an engine, and the black smudge of smoke above the ragged line of claw-foot mangroves are unmistakable. Your men, who had settled long enough to admire a proliferation of yellow flowers on the southern bank, suddenly find themselves at the mercy of twin horrors! Beyond the next bend are a set of devious rapids frothing down towards you, and with the Pyrphorian dragon fast approaching, time is in short supply. There is a very narrow breach at one side, through which a vessel capably navigated may just about fit. Alternatively, blasting the high cliffs could block the Pyrphorian's way.
802948: Fill the sails and power up the rapids
802949: Your navigator picks up plenty of speed, which is remarkable, since there seems to be little wind on the river today. The line of approach is good too, squeezing your ship between the two craggiest protuberances of rock, as your vessel rides up several tiers of the rapids with little more than a bump. Though a steamer might be better suited to the task, the iron dragon makes no attempt to pursue. Your captain is quick to praise the great skill of your navigator, rather than face the troubling possibility that the Pyrphorians know of a greater danger to come. The river has taken you as far as it can, and you must decide whether to continue across a marsh of uncertain depth, or as Ramón suggests, to head through a nearby network of caves.
802951: Your men know those aren't logs bobbing in the marsh, and decide to wade well clear of the lurking black caiman, who from their chubby bellies appear to have had success in these waters. After a few cheerful hours of tramping, you reach a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
802952: A wader is too occuped with the myth of fifty-foot anaconda, to see the real danger. As a result of his failed attempts to catch the slightest of breezes, the line of approach is also poor, and two of the craggiest protuberances of rock make themselves known. There is a sharp splintering sound as your poor ship's hull suffers what it was never built for, riding up and over the tiered divisions of white water pools. Your damaged hull begins to flood, and though you see the iron dragon turn tail and puff downstream, you must now decide whether to fix or forsake your ship.
802957: Disembark and search for Isabel on foot

But there is another presence here too, which eventually makes itself known. "You do not belong here," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. Exhausted by the lack of progress, they're taking a moment to recline on a sandy stretch of the river bank when they hear a clicking sound. 802963: Fire at the cliff between you and the Pyrphorians
802964: The cannonfire has precisely the desired effect. With a bellowing crack, the high cliff spills several hundred tonnes of orange sandstone into the river. Having contemplated this new obstacle, the iron dragon turns, and disappears back downstream. With the rapids ahead, you are forced to admit the river has taken you as far as it can. You must decide whether to continue across a marsh of uncertain depth, or as Ramón suggests, through a nearby network of caves.
802965: Too little rock falls in time.The small shower of sandstone does not deter the Pyrphorians, and you are left with no choice but to try to sail up the rapids. There is a sharp splintering sound as your poor ship's hull suffers what it was never built for, riding up and over the tiered divisions of white water pools. Your ship begins to flood, and though you see the iron dragon turn tail and puff downstream, you must now decide whether to fix or forsake your ship.
802967: An expedition party leaves the ship in capable hands, and sets out into the vast green beyond. It is hard to relate to the enchantment that falls upon these adventurers, to whom this alien world is entirely new, from the whoop and squawk of feathers to the gleeful chattering of capuchin. An ocelot scarpers, a serpent slumbers; a parade of ants bear all the burdens of their kingdom along their leafy conduits, their royal quest in parallel to your own. After several hours of happy tramping, you reach a steep but narrow ravine. If the map suggests some natural bridge across, you do not see it, and the breach in the earth stretches out of sight in both directions. Either you go down and back up with ropes, or try to construct a simple bridge.
802969: They have no problem finding a tall enough tree. It is soon felled and hollowed, at least to provide some protection from a fall, and ropes are used to secure it at either end. It's a tidy job, and your expedition passes over it in relative comfort. On the other side, it's not long before Ramón, Sir Archibald's man, alerts you to some prints that have disturbed the red earth. Human ones. Perhaps these lead right to Isabel Sarmento? But that would mean deviating from the route on the map, and the day is beginning to grow dark.
802971: It proves a good decision. After a cheerful stretch, you reach a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
802972: Your men don't quite have the expertise to travel on in the darkness, which, apart from the wide eyes that peer out at you from the canopy, is absolute. Your company build a great bonfire for comfort, and wait for morning light - but there is another presence here too, which only now decides to make itself known. "You do not belong here," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
802974: Your beagle follows the faint tracks keenly. After a few cheerful hours of tramping, you reach a seemingly unremarkable clearing. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs. "Or so you might hope!" calls a voice from the trees. Any old man and his dog could follow them," says your tracker. "Exactly!" calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
802976: Finding a big enough tree is not the problem. Your men fell the tree and lower it over the chasm, using ropes to secure it at either end. "It looks a little bit wobbly!" says Ramón, Sir Archibald's man. He's right, of course, since there's nothing to cling to but the fragile bark, and several of your expedition come very close to falling, before one eventually loses their footing. "Don't look! She's gone!" Ramón calls out. Resuming their trek, morale is low until someone spots a human bootprint on the forest floor. Perhaps these lead right to Isabel Sarmento? But that would mean deviating from the route on the map, and the day is beginning to grow dark.
