802983: Co-ordinate your way down and back up
802984: Their communication is excellent. The correct knots are used for the guy ropes, and with the experience of soldiering among you the descent is painless. At the bottom, you skip over a small creek babbling towards the mother river, before commencing a successful climb up the other side. Back on track, it is not long before Ramón, Sir Archibald's man, alerts you to prints that have disturbed the red earth. Human ones. Perhaps these lead right to Isabel Sarmento? But that would mean deviating from the route on the map, and the day is beginning to grow dark.
802985: Their communication is appalling. The abseil down is messy, but fortune prevails. Not so on the way back up, when a poor sailor's knot slips, and the jangle of guy ropes sends one of the front-running climbers plunging into the crevasse. "He's gone. Don't look!" cries Ramón. Sir Archibald's man is wise indeed, for the rest manage the climb. Resuming their trek, morale is low until someone spots a human bootprint on the forest floor. Perhaps these lead right to Isabel Sarmento? But that would mean deviating from the route on the map, and it the day is beginning to grow dark.
802991: Climb the mast and detach the frozen sails
802992: Stay inside and hope the supplies last
802993: The ship can safely withstand the blizzard. Several sailors of impressive build climb your masts to unhook and detach the heavy sails, and despite the slippery wood and tightly frozen ropes, they manage to free the masts of the dangerous weight. The barren poles stand tall against the receding storm. Morning light soon pierces the clouds - a good omen to salute your crew's efforts, and accompany their celebration.
802994: The task is far from easy. Your sailors have good strength, and are used to climbing the masts, but they lack either luck or skill when it comes to speed. Before they can reach the foremast, the foresail breaks out of its bounds and flaps wildly against the weakened mast, while the other sails continue to foster stalactites of increasing length and weight. The foremast emits a shrilling sound of protest.
802995: A resounding failure. Your sailors clearly don't have the ability to climb the masts, whether in this storm or in clear weather - how could they even be allowed on a ship? As they bicker over their deficiency, the main mast beckons their attention: its base is entirely frozen, and the wood screams against the invading cold.
802996: Aim at the ties holding the rogue sail
802997: Fire all guns and shake off the ice
802998: "We are here on behalf of Her Majesty the Queen!"
802999: "I am the child of Samuel Goode."
803001: "You think I care about your stupid empire?!" curses Isabel, beckoning to two guards to tightly restrain you. "No sooner had we gained independence from La Corona, than we receive an offer too-good-to-be-true from an envoy of your Queen. An 'amazing prospect, Prosperity', he said - and at first it was." Isabel grunts and slams her boot knife into a barrel, from which wine spurts out. "Now that island, our last hope of freedom, is overrun with these masks, these... twisted people, and their fire!" She rushes at you, and forces your lips open for a better answer...
803002: "My father was Samuel Goode. I am here to stop the Pyrphorians!"
803003: "My father was Samuel Goode. I am here to take Prosperity back!"
803004: Isabel slowly releases her grip. She stabs her boot knife back into the wine barrel, plugging the hole. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. I heard reports they tried to stop you with an iron dragon." She exhales nervously. "I did not believe it. And yet, you've risked your life to come here..." Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
803005: Isabel's eyes flash with anger. "So! They call your father a traitor for selling it to us, the 'pesky rebels', and now you've come here to 'do the right thing' and take it back?! Your father should have thought of that before he sold it. A deal is a deal!" It is a confession that the deal has not, in any respect, been a good one. She picks up the barrel and pours wine over your head, "Maybe I'll take all my rage out on you!"
803006: "Even if it was my father, the Pyrphorians must have forced him to sell!"
803007: "Admit it, you conspired with the Pyrphorians to buy it!"
803008: Isabel puts the barrel down, stabbing her boot knife in to plug the hole. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. I heard reports they tried to stop you with an iron dragon." She exhales nervously. "I did not believe it. And yet, you've risked your life to come here..." Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
803009: "I don't need to take insults from an imperialist pig," Isabel rages, tossing the barrel aside and raising her boot knife. Better say the right thing this time...
803010: "Can't you see, the Pyrphorians are evil!"
803011: The rogue sail is taken down! Precise shots take out its ties without so much as scratching the foremast, and the sail is sent to disappear into the storm. The lack of the sail's furious whipping seems to be enough for the mast to hold its ground. When the blizzard recedes, your ship is lacking a sail, but nothing more.
803012: Isabel sighs, and puts her knife down. She rests her hands on the window ledge, to gaze across the turquoise waters. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. I heard reports they tried to stop you with an iron dragon." She exhales nervously. "I did not believe it. And yet, you've risked your life to come here..." Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
803013: Alas, your mast is not spared. Your sailors shoot at the ties of the foresail, but the task is too meticulous for them: they shoot at the ropes, the poles, and the mast itself. The raging sail is swallowed by the storm, while the foremast collapses and crushes the starboard. In a final irony, the storm soon calms down, letting your crew see how a lack of meddling would have caused less damage.
803014: The stalactites are dealt with. In a bold act of defiance towards logic and prudence, your artillery men fire their cannons to send precisely gauged vibrations throughout your ship. The foremast protests but resists, while the pikes of ice parasitising its sails break and rain on the deck in a cacophony of tingling sounds. Your maimed ship has but to wait for the blizzard to run out of breath now.
803015: Reckless, and proportionately paid. Gauging the difference between power which might break the stalactites only, and power which might also break the mast is beyond the understanding of most humans, your artillery men included. The tremor of the cannons shakes the whole ship, provoking the crashing fall of the foremast. Ironically, the blizzard reacts by calming down, leaving the sailors to their broken ship.
803016: Strengthen the mast with chains and planks
803017: Isabel's eyes flash with anger. "So! They call your father a traitor for selling it to us, the 'pesky rebels', and now you've come here to 'do the right thing' and take it back?! Your father should have thought of that before he sold it. A deal is a deal!" It is a confession that the deal has not, in any respect, been a good one. She picks up the barrel and pours wine over your head, "Maybe I'll take all my rage out on you!"
803018: Isabel sighs. She rests her hands on the window ledge, to gaze across the turquoise waters. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. I heard reports they tried to stop you with an iron dragon." She exhales nervously. "I did not believe it. And yet, you've risked your life to come here..." Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
803019: Boil seawater to gather ice-melting salt
803020: A straightforward, if rough solution. Planks and poles are erected around the masts, and bound by ropes and chains in the hope that the swaying barricade will prevent the masts from breaking. Despite its movement, the construction is sturdy, and actually accompanies the masts as they move in the wind, giving them a welcome support. When the blizzard leaves, your ship is plucked naked, but its masts still stand.
803021: The trigger of catastrophy. Your sailors tie planks and poles around the masts, pulling chains around them as tightly as they can, oblivious to the carpentry laws that apply to the movement of towering objects. The masts try to break free of their man-made prisons, and soon do, crashing onto the deck one after the other. As if chased by the hysteria below, the blizzard flees, lettings its sunrays fall on the barren carcass of your ship.
803022: Somehow, it works. Your sailors take the time to slowly distil seawater in order to avoid improper condensation. The salt is acquired faster than anticipated, and spread over the base of the main mast, forcing the ice back to its liquid form. The blizzard keeps filling the sails until it runs out of breath and recedes, but the furious weather was enough to greatly maim the ship. There will be extensive repairs.
803023: There was no chance of success. To gather salt, your sailors keep away from the wind and bury below the deck to light a fire under a pot of seawater. Their condenser is poorly handled, and causes the water to fall back into the pot, leaving the crew to believe the fire isn't burning hard enough. They fan the flames. Hell rises. The blizzard is fed gusts of murky smoke, and spits it back out before receding, revealing the half-burnt carcass of your ship.
803024: Prudence and faith pay off. Your sailors huddle together in the lower deck, resisting the temptation to go check the masts and their frozen sails. Time trickles away as the storm recedes, and when the blizzard is no more than a light drizzle, the sun emerges to illuminate your ship. It's perfectly unscathed, and slowly drifts towards the coast, where a harbour is already in sight.
803025: Your sailors' feeble trust is not enough to fuel their patience. The storm lingers, and with each new gust of raging wind the main mast complains and moans, until the distinct sounds of breaking wood resonate through the ship. That's enough waiting! Several sailors rush to the upper deck in the hope of either strengthening or defrosting the mast.
803026: Sails frozen, food rotten, and a ship on the brink of breaking. It's a blizzard! All notion of time and direction has long been lost: a never-ending tempest of snow surrounds the ship, blurring the limits between night and day, or sky and sea. Stalactites have imprisoned your sails, binding them to the masts and making them creak under the unexpected weight. Your crew fear they might break, but should anyone venture outside while violent winds whip the upper deck?
803032: Try to break the prisoners out
803037: The fine is duly paid. Of course, your crew boil as the militia counts the payment and divides it up between them, all while flapping without remorse about the noble old art of bribery. Yet your sailors take comfort that they have been allowed to leave safe and sound, and mark the harbour on the map with the noble intention of forewarning other seafarers of the ruse.
803038: No fine, no prisoners. The militia make it clear: your crew members will not be freed unless their ludicrous demands are met.
803039: You secure an early release! Your men return to the ship and wait for nightfall. At the sight of a signal flare, the prisoners anticipate your course of action and place a lit candle by the bars of each window. After careful calibration of the cannons, a second flare goes up signalling the imminent blast. The candles extinguish in acknowledgement before the ship's guns sound. The cliff wall of the fortress crumbles away! Taking their chances, the prisoners launch themselves into the water below, just as your ship passes by. Tales of the daring rescue will be going around for years.
803040: You make a mess of the fortress — and the poor people inside. The cannon fire impacts the cliff, but your artillerymen have not taken enough care in their calculations. The fortress walls crumble easily enough, but the occupants of the cells are either killed in the blast, or plunge to their deaths on the rocks below. As your expedition makes a hasty exit, the crew try to come to terms with what they have done.
803041: "I think that's the last we shall ever see of them," lament the sailors that night, as the anchor is raised and the westerly breeze tears them away from the unforgiving fortress. As they depart, candles appear at the bars of each cell, signifying — in the imagination of your crew at least — a unanimous verdict of reproach.
803042: Unfair imprisonment! While enjoying some well-deserved shore leave, a local militia seizes a dozen members of your expedition without explanation. They are taken to a fortress that's been hollowed into the sandstone cliffs that dominate the harbour. The charges against your crew prove spurious to say the least, and when a hefty sum is demanded in exchange for their release, the militia's intentions become all too plain.
803045: This man is severely ill! A group of sailors bang on the door to the doctor's cabin. They carry a feverish friend, who between two moments of altered sleep mutters about a burning radiance and closes his eyes to protect himself from the deck's half-light. The doctor's inspection could reveal more symptoms, but shouldn't the crazed patient be secluded instead?
803046: Inspect the man at the risk of contamination
803048: The symptoms speak for themselves. The man's neck is stiff, his breathing distraught, his cheeks paralysed. As the doctor explains to the rest of the crew the details of meningitis, the lying patient suddenly trembles, taken by a seizure of such intensity that his whole body arches upwards, bent in a pyramidal pose of impossible tension. He screams out the name of your doctor before falling down, dead.
803049: Your doctor is at a loss. Fear of the light sounds like an ailment belonging to the realm of the Lord, and the man of science is too blinded by his fright to notice the change in his patient. In a fit of unforeseen anger, the sick man leaps on his healer and attempts to claw his eyes out, before being restrained by the surrounding sailors. What madness is this?
803050: This was the delirium of a dying man
803051: This was the accusation of a victim
803055: There is no truth but the voice of science. The accusation was the plea of a sick fool. Your doctor knows what ravages meningitis can do to the mind of its victims, and his collected account of symptoms convinces your crew of your doctor's innocence and acute knowledge. He is free to inspect the men on board, and identifies several others who carry the symptoms. The sick are promptly isolated and disembarked at the next harbour, and your expedition emerges unscathed.
803056: The doctor's truth isn't convincing. He fumbles through his explanations, as his limited knowledge of the dead man's illness begins to show. Even if the doctor did seem to correctly identify the ailment, he fails to justify the impressive death the crew just witnessed. Doubts linger as the expedition goes on, and the doctor spends the rest of trip isolated in a quarantine of defiance and distrust.
803057: Heavenly truths hide in the last wishes of a man. The doctor is pressed for answers and asked to swear his innocence before the Lord: a feat too great, and a lie to heavy for him to bear. He confesses to having poisoned the sailor with mercury over a dispute of faith against facts - ironically, the doctor's own fear of the Light made him confess his sins. He is hanged, and your crew find relief in the punishment of the murderer.
803058: Isn't this judgement too hasty? The doctor is immediately accused of having murdered the sick sailor, but he isn't enough of a believer to confess before the cross. He is nevertheless hanged for his supposed crimes. Relief tints the mood of your crew, but many know the punishment was hasty and unjust.
803059: Observe the evolution of the lunatic's symptoms
803060: Confine the madman in the hold
803061: Rabies, no doubt - confine him! The man's unnatural fury keeps growing under the observation of the doctor, who finally discerns familiar patterns in his patient's behaviour. His massive salivation and rejection of any form of drink leaves little room for doubt: he has rabies. The sailors confine him into the hold without remorse, and wait for the illness to steal his life.
803062: The symptoms culminate in death. The roped patient wriggles, drooling, screeching and screaming for the lights to be gone, until a seizure of astonishing magnitude takes him, leaving his cadaver frozen in an impossible position. The doctor realises, far too late, that he might have been facing a case of rabies. Around him, the crew grow restless: what if this failure of a scientist was still wrong?
803063: Find evidence on the dead man's body
803064: Find evidence in the dead man's belongings
803065: The flesh carries proof. In the thigh of the dead man, your doctor discerns burn marks unlike any other, appended over a festering wound. This is the work of a priest, who applied a heated key of Saint Hubert over the bite of a rabid dog - in the hope, visibly misplaced, that the Saint would cure the ailment. The sailor had known of his fate, but chose to endanger his companions regardless. He deserved death.
803066: Your crew has had enough of the doctor's incapability. The man of science probes the body, tearing its clothes to reveal bruised skin and vulnerable flesh - a sight which convinces the sailors that they have seen the boundaries of his skill. The doctor is seized and roped alongside the cadaver he was desecrating, being left to ponder his calling in the depths of the hull. At the next harbour, your crew grimly realise that the doctor's wrinkled mass will never do harm nor good again.
803067: Undisputable evidence points to a grim story. The inspection of the dead man's belongings lands no result, but your sailors know better than to consider this failure as final. They extend their search to his sleeping quarters, and within the loose planks of an amateurish repair, they find their proof: a key of Saint Hubert, a vital artefact for any believer suspecting the menace of rabies. The sailor knew of his ailment and chose to hide it. This truth pains your crew, but the closure brings relief.
803068: No proof, no trust. Your sailors are no good at sleuthing, especially under pressure, and they find no proof pointing to the nature of the dead man's illness. Suspicion rises as the doctor orders the immediate burial at sea of the cadaver. Long after the cloth-wrapped body was thrown into the sea, the cadaver of the dead man is found hidden in the hull. There is little doubt as to who was thrown overboard in its place.
803069: Your sailors will have nothing to do with this lunacy. Sending the sick man to the depths of the hold is a cruel choice, but it lowers the risk of any otherworldly contamination. His howls bedevil the ship until his voice becomes whisper, then silence. His body is buried at sea in a hurried parody of ceremony, as the sailors avoid discussing his unknown illness.
803070: The sick die alone. Afraid of the man's state and the contagion he could potentially spread, your sailors lock him up in an empty cabin. He offers no resistance, and during the following days, his presence is reduced to sporadic whimpers and the occasional monologue. When the voice finally dies out, the sailors carefully wrap his body in cloth and bury him at sea, both relieved and sorry that they let him die a dog's death.
803077: Break the floe with your cannons
803080: Scurvy. While inspecting the mouths of the stranded sailors, your doctor's fingers go straight through their gums as if they were made of paper, and the teeth below quit their lodging with a shake and a pull. The ill men admit to having already buried two of their own at sea. More will follow if they do not eat fresh food soon.
803081: The unknown illness might attack your crew. Your doctor cannot pierce the mystery of the strangers' ailment: their ghost-like bodies fascinate as much as they terrify. Too scared to properly inspect their cadaverous skin, he hurriedly affirms that any sort of prolonged contact with them would put your own sailors in danger. Your ship whisks your crew away from the imaginary threat, leaving the strangers to die.
803082: Part with a large portion of your supplies
803083: Hunt the floe for fresh meat
803084: The starved sailors eye your food with envy
803087: Your loss will help their survival, no doubt. The donated supplies are enough for the strangers to hold out until rescue comes. Your crew promises to look for the nearest harbour and call for help there - a promise which they are likely to keep, forced as they will be to resupply in order to avoid their own starvation.
803088: There are not enough supplies for both your crew and theirs. Your sailors stop rummaging through their cargo, and must deny the stranded men their hope of renewed supplies. The poor souls are too weak to vent their anger, but their empty looks and cursing whispers follow your crew long after the ghost ship has been swallowed by the horizon.
803089: The icy domain gives a profuse bounty. Your fishermen forsake the idea of exploring the floe, knowing that the local game hides underwater. Adapting to the hostile environment, they catch enough seals to feed the whole crew, and the feast, even if it doesn't miraculously heal the sick, seems to at least replenish their spirit. They encourage your crew to use your ship's cannons to break the ice encasing their ship - despite the risk of damaging their hull.
803090: The hunters can't find enough food. Your sailors manage to track, find and trap a few seals, but the bounty's not enough to feed a whole crew of ailing men. It might be enough for them to hold out until a rescue mission arrives, however - if there were less of them, or if they followed a strict rationing discipline.
803091: The floe is barren. Unable to catch any game on the frozen ice and the surrounding hills of snow, despite the numerous tracks sprinkling the area, your hunters come back empty-handed and ashamed. The stranded sailors appreciate the effort, but their eyes grow duller still. They're still desperate for any kind of help.
803093: Promise to call in help and leave
803094: The ship is freed! Your artillery men take hold of the stranded ship's cannons, ordering the crew to coordinate their frozen artillery with your ship's own firepower. The combined shots from both vessels trace the contours of the ice, breaking it with successive volleys until the floe parts and lets go, much to the appreciation of both crews. One of the sailors who helped fire the icy cannons even offers to join your voyage, having been taken in by your crew's kindness and brilliant skills.
803095: Your shots break the ice, along with their hull. Shooting a cannonball through an exact thickness of ice without going any further requires a degree of control that your artillery man doesn't have. The blast pierces through the floe with a resounding crack, but the splinters projected by the impact are both ice and wood. The stranded sailors are thankful for your help - and the water did cushion most of your cannonball's power - but your crew still feels guilt at seeing their ship hobble away.
803096: Your crew promises to send help. They leave the stranded men after telling them of steam-powered icebreakers and expeditions versed in the art of rescuing people such as them, and the tales seem to satisfy their angst. Your sailors hope that the next harbour will indeed provide such saviours.
803097: Invite as many as you can on board
803099: They are desperate for help, and accept your proposal. Your diplomat pressures the strangers more than she reassures them, and her pragmatic approach to the problem manages to convince them. About a third of the sick embark upon your ship, whereas the remaining sailors huddle together to share the meagre food that was hunted for them. Going back and forth between the closest harbour and the trapped ship drains both your crew and your time, but the rescued men are indefinitely grateful.
803100: Your diplomat cannot convince anyone to stay behind. Rather than depicting the reasons behind your crew's decision, she bluntly announces the number of strangers allowed on board, and sparks an immediate frenzy. The skeletal men rise on trembling legs, their limbs pulled forward by the puppet strings of hunger, rushing into each other until most strings are cut. The culled crew climbs aboard your ship, and their soulless presence plagues the rest of the expedition.
803101: The system is strict, but it allows them to hold their ground. One of your officers, and two of your biggest, most impressive sailors go down below deck on the stranded ship to distribute food portions, and teach the men about the merits and secrets of disciplined rationing. The crew nod their understanding, silent as your ship sails away. Hopefully they will follow your advice, and most will still be alive when a rescue ship comes to their aid.
803102: Your frail discipline falls apart. One of your officers and a handful of escorting sailors order the starved men to ration the meat, lest they suffer from even more famine while your ship goes to look for help. Their lack of presence and conviction has no impact on the sailors, who throw themselves on the supplies and transform into beasts; frail animals who lack the strength to rip each other apart despite their will to do so. Your ship leaves in a hurry, leaving the fools to their madness.
803103: A job carried out with few hitches. Making sure that they don't damage the ship itself, your sailors fire cannonball after cannonball, taking the time to appraise and readjust their aim with each new shot. The ship's hull is grazed by the first shots, and soon the floe parts before the vessel, the ice blocks gliding against each other with menacing cracks. The trapped crew profusely thank yours! Your sailors revel in their selfless act, trying to ignore the emaciated faces and feeble voices.
803104: A reckless failure. Your sailors have no notion of subtlety, and even less understanding of their own firepower. The very first cannonball crashes straight through the ice, shooting beneath the waves and into the trapped hull below. Frozen foam explodes and stains the floe with streaks of grey, which all point at the gaping hole in the wooden frame. The stranded crew tremble back and forth to secure the leak, and refuse any more help.
803106: They can take care of themselves, leave
803107: Can we spare enough supplies for them?
803110: The best that could have been done. The strangers accept your sailors' offer with reluctance, eyeing the leakage they caused more than the food that they offer. The compensation is enough to put your own crew in need of rationing, but it does not absolve their mistakes. Your ship leaves with promises to call for help at the next harbour, eager to leave the judging stares.
803111: The situation turns as bad as it could get. Enraged by your retraction, the stranded crew flings resounding insults at your crew, followed by splinters from the broken hull, then the crates they'd prepared to store your offering, and finally, actual men. Fuelled by their ire and moving despite their cadaverous state, the assailants fire at will, oblivious to the retort of your crew. When the wraiths finally give in to death, your officers start to count the bodies.
803112: Your crew leave the stranded men to fend for themselves. There's no mistaking the leak for a negligible issue: if the skeletal state of the sailors is any indication, they'll never have the strength to fix their ship. Allowing them to keep their pride might have been the granting of a last wish.
803113: The strangers are left to their grim fate. One of your sailors crystallises your crew's fears by signing himself as the trapped ship disappears into the distance. The wraiths onboard were so close to death, they had already taken its guise.
803115: A ship trapped in the floe! While navigating the treacherous Northern seas, your expedition happens upon frozen waters, whose masses spread over the horizon and plant their roots deep below the surface. Their dominion has imprisoned a ship much like yours. Skin parched, voice torn, eyes buried deep in their skulls, the stranded sailors sacrifice their last bits of strength to beg for help.
803275: "A-Anyone home...?" Seeking refuge from a thunderstorm, your people dash for the tumbledown castle. A flash of lightning illuminates its stark towers, barred windows and the solemn stone gryphons either side of the gate. As the last of your party crosses the threshold, an iron portcullis drops and clangs shut behind them! Despite their best efforts, your men cannot seem to lift it. The castle and its courtyard appear empty, but there is a sense that someone — or something — has been expecting you.
803276: Cry out that you come in peace
803277: The officer refuses to give in to his fear, but calls out steadily "We mean no harm! We only seek refuge from the storm!" As if by magic, the castle's great door creaks open. Your men accept the invitation to shelter, but with palpably less enthusiasm than would be customary on a night such as this. Inside, a once-opulent dining hall greets them, its few flickering candles burned down to a nub. But the attention of the crew is frozen upon the head of the long table, where a vaporous woman appears to be hovering several feet in the air!
803278: Refuse to believe it is real
803280: The ghostly dinner guest shatters! It was just a pane of glass, angled to reflect an old mannequin! "Please!" A dimunitive and smartly-dressed man emerges from the shadows, hands aloft, "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this is my latest invention!" Relief turns to wonder as they marvel at the life-like mannequin he's created for the illusion. "Permit me to make it up to you!" he beams, flipping a switch that fills the hall with electric light. "Geoffery," he calls up to the rafters, "inform the cooks we have guests tonight!"
803281: Horror! The bullet passes through flesh and blood!" "Patricia...! Patricia!!" wails the illusionist, as he rushes from the wings to be beside the actress — his dying wife. "Oh, lord! Whatever have you done, sirs!" A moment later, she dies in his arms. That your soldiers were duped by a bit of make-up and a costume doesn't say much for their judgement. The expedition leaves the poor man and his tragic theatre set, and departs into the rain, which seems to fall harder and louder than ever before.
803282: The first mate's tremulous voice returns no answer but its own echo, somehow distorted and corrupted by the castle walls. Could it be that whatever now inhabits this place, no longer has the power to speak? Or perhaps it is merely biding its time...
803284: There's a way out over the walls! Strangely, no ladder or stairs are found leading up to the high battlements, but the upper part of the keep appears attached. Through a maze of shadowy rooms and hallways, lit only by the occasional flash, the crew discovers a staircase to the third floor. From there they emerge onto the wall, and descend the dark and lush ivy on its exterior, welcoming the feel of the pouring rain from which they had so recently sought to hide.
803285: This castle was clearly designed to keep people in. Strangely, no ladder or stairs are found leading up to the high battlements, but the upper part of the keep appears attached. After what feels like hours wandering the labyrinthine corridors of the keep, a peculiar door swings open. It appears to lead to a master bedroom. A soft, plaintive song rises from within, where a young woman is found at her mirror. She sits combing her hair, her bridal dress soiled and torn, and her face impossibly pale.
803286: Refuse to believe she is real
803287: Faith steadies the soldier's hand as he approaches the bride, but then he stops abruptly. "You should see your faces!" cackles a diminutive and smartly-dressed man, emerging from the shadows. Suddenly the room fills with electric light. "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this little beauty is my proudest invention." He winks and twists the bride's head one-hundred and eighty degrees. The automaton is so lifelike, it chills your men even now. They do not take well to learning the illusionist has been toying with them, and leave early the following morning, still very upset.
803288: Their faith cannot prepare them for this. Her head suddenly spins on its axis, her face not young and pale as in the mirror, but shrunken and grey — a thousand-years old! — its empty eye sockets seething with a colony of larvae! The sailors run, rushing through the dark, dark halls, trampling the rickety stairs, and out into the rain. Finding the portcullis raised, they rush for the beyond; a lifetime of insomnia.
803290: The phantom bride shatters! It was just a sheet of glass, angled to reflect a mannequin in a hidden alcove! A small man storms in from the shadows. "Who do you think you are, destroying my precious illusion?" he screams. "Have you any idea how much effort — not to mention expense — I'd invested in this pure sheet of glass, and the lifelike skin of the mannequin you've just pierced with your bullets! Get away from this place — away!" Your people trudge out into the rain.
803291: Horror! The bullet passes through flesh and blood! "Patricia...! Patricia!!" wails the illusionist, as he rushes from the wings to be beside the actress — his dying wife. "Oh, lord! Whatever have you done, sirs!" A moment later, she dies in his arms. That your soldiers were duped by a bit of make-up and a costume doesn't say much for their judgement. The expedition leaves the poor man and his tragic theatre set, and departs into the rain, which seems to fall harder and louder than ever before.
803292: Try again to force the gates
803293: Success! Unable to resist the sailors' immense strength, the portcullis raises just the fraction needed to get everyone underneath. It takes good teamwork on the far side to get the last stragglers under, and the crew emerge shelterless, but free of this nightmarish place.
803294: It's useless. Everyone tries their best, but they simply don't have the strength. Two men strain their shoulders, but still the portcullis cannot be raised an inch. Someone notices a cable leading from the top of the barbican where the portcullis is held, up to a high window on the keep.
803295: Try to scale the walls instead
803296: Finally free of this nightmare! The sailors are able to help each other up to the battlements, despite the interior walls of the castle being smooth and featureless — almost as if they've been designed to keep people in... Once they've clambered down the ivy on the other side of the thick walls, your expedition party begins to look for somewhere safe to sleep — if it's not too cold and wet, that is.
803297: Only the able-bodied make it. The interior walls of the castle are smooth and featureless — almost as if they've been designed to keep people in... However, only when the skilled climbers reach the battlements do they realise that there's no easy way to help the rest up. "We'll come back for you in the morning," they say. Returning after a damp and sleepless night, they find the portcullis raised, yet can see no sign of their comrades. A thorough search of the castle is conducted, but the devilish place is found to be completely deserted.
803299: It's a foul night in the rain. There's minimal shelter from the elements within these smooth and featureless walls, and the rising moan of the gale is unbearable. Finally, at dawn, the storm relents. At about half past the hour of ten, the castle door swings open, and a friendly-faced man emerges from it. "What in blazes!" he laughs, "What are all you fellows doing out here!" He explains that he is the heir to this castle, which he claims survived a siege in 1422, and that the portcullis is a rather sensitive beast these days. Your men are pretty peeved, not to mention a little feverish, at the thought they could have spent the night in a comfortable four-poster bed.
803301: "It must be a trick, for it most certainly is not real!" says a young woman, who rushes forward, hand raised towards the figure. Just as she is about to touch it, it vanishes. "There's a pane of glass here... a mirror!" she exclaims. "Impressive, isn't it!" A diminutive and smartly-dressed man emerges from the shadows, hands aloft, "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this is my latest invention!" Relief turns to wonder as they marvel at the life-like mannequin he's created for the illusion. "Permit me to make it up to you!" he beams, flipping a switch which fills the hall with electric light. "Geoffery," he calls up to the rafters, "inform the cooks we have guests tonight!"
803302: "Disbelieve your eyes...!" The unconvincing advice only serves to startle the crew even further. The moment one of the crew plucks up the courage to take a step forward, the apparition abruptly vanishes. "What manner of horror is this that we have just witnessed? I will not stay here a moment longer!" he says. Finding the portcullis in the courtyard has mysteriously returned to the raised position, your crew take the chance to make a run for it.
803303: "It-it cannot be...!" An officer's hand quavers towards the apparition, but the faceless woman mirrors him, pointing her claw-like finger as if to single him out. At this sinister omen, everybody dashes for the entrance, screaming, trampling and shoving one another in their haste to flee. Finding the portcullis in the courtyard has mysteriously returned to the raised position, your spooked crew take the chance to make a run for it, only for the portcullis to suddenly fall. No-one but that marked man is crushed under its weight.
803305:
"The whales are still around us!"
Impossibly large trails of water break the wake of the ship, and the froth parts to reveal dark, leathery skin. The whales are gaining speed, and their impact is imminent.
803306: Launch the steam ship at full speed
803307: The wonders of technology! The steam engines roar above the whales' chant, and the ship lunges away from the creatures in a cacophony of grating metal and whistling vapor. An investment well spent.
803308: Maneuver the ship to avoid the whales
803309: A masterful maneuver! The captain stirs the ship alongside the school of whales, and the animals glide past the boat in a slow and graceful ballet. The crew salute their captain's skill, and revel in the moment.
803310: Hard to avoid what you cannot see. The whales are everywhere: on the sides, in front, at the back, and beneath the ship. The captain strains against the limits of his skill, but he cannot avoid the impacts coming from below, and part of the cargo is sent flying before the ship can escape.
803311: A school of whales is not a road you can simply navigate. As the ship shifts to the side, the closest whale reacts to the sudden movement by playing dead: it stops swimming, and lets itself fall at an agonizingly slow speed. The impact with the rudder is brutal, and bends the vital mechanism.
803313: A feat of strength for a gratuitous kill. The harpoon impales the leading whale, and the rest of the school collides with its body, their advance being suddenly, and brutally stopped. The ship leaves without a scratch.
803314: The harpoon strikes a calf, causing the school to attack. The wounded whale swirls to try and get rid of the iron rod, and its elders surround it, pushing the ship away from their young. The boat lists heavily to the side, and several men fall overboard.
803315: Throw a roped harpoon to save the drowning sailors
803316: A harpoon is sacrificed to rescue the men. The men grab the harpoon's anchoring rope and climb back on board, just in time to see the rope snap and fall into the abyss. The ship flees before any whales resurface.
803317: The rescue harpoon triggers the whales' attack. The roped weapon could have made a good rescue device, but the giant marine mammals were already restless from the previous throw. A whale simply tilts up its head, and a massive wave engulfs the drowning sailors, crashing against the ship, and ramming it away from the begging and screaming men.
803318: Get away from the flustered whales
803319: The fate of the drowning men is sealed. As the ship retreats from the whales, the captain prays aloud for the sailors' survival. No one among the crew is naive enough to believe his words, but they all pretend.
803320: Sing a military favorite to scare the whales away
803321:
The whales dance away from the ship.
"Eternal Father, strong to save,
Whose arm hath bound the restless wave,
Oh, hear us when we cry to Thee,
For those in peril on the sea!"
In a unison born out of a common love of the hymn, the sailors sing and brace themselves for impact — only to realize the creatures have drifted away. A tale of dancing whales will be part of this expedition's story!
803322: The performance's efficiency is questionable. Trying their best to be in unison, the sailors shout their hearts out more than they sing, and the underwater creatures don't seem to care. The group screaming occupies the crew for a long time, allowing the ship to drift closer to the school of whales.
803323: The crew embarrass themselves. The underwater whales cannot hear the sounds squirming from the ship, and it's for the best. Dejected, their ears ringing, the sailors blame each other for the performance, and the team's unity and pride are deeply dented. Getting squashed by a whale would have been a better option.
803324: Send a man in the diving bell to fix the rudder
803325: The sailor has rarely worked with such a view. As the hours disappear while he fixes the rudder, the whales continue their inexorable advance in a vision of lethargic, yet grandiose movement. When the rudder is repaired, the whales are still passing by - and too close for comfort.
803332: The diving bell's rope tightens, then floats back up. Both equipment and sailor are lost to the unfathomable depths and their gigantic inhabitants. The crew ponders whether the accident was caused by chance, or animal malevolence.
803333: Keep sailing straight ahead, at the risk of collision
803334: Neither ship nor whale tries to avoid the impact. Used to being a predatorless presence, the whale shoves aside the obstacle in its way and the ship is sent rocking. The creatures go on in indifference, reminding the crew of their meagerness.
803335: Fire canons in the water to scare the whales away
803336: The tiny cannonballs somehow drive the massive creatures away. As the sea foams and whitens under the force of the impacts, it hides what reaction the whales may have. When the froth clears, the animals seem to have dived away from the ship, but the men stay tense for a long while.
803337: Ten pound cannonballs against creatures of a hundred tons? A whale slams into the ship, then another one, then another. The repetitive impacts make the crew believe the attacks are intentional, and they rally into begging prayers and whimpers. When the ocean's fury recedes, they're left to count the sailors thrown overboard.
803338: Wait for the whales to leave
803339: The whales are not eager to retreat. Used to being a predatorless presence, a whale shoves aside the obstacle in its way, and the ship is sent rocking. The damage is extensive and will take days to fix. The creatures go on in indifference, reminding the crew of their meagerness.
803364: A local girl is dead, of smallpox; a disease your expedition has without doubt brought to these shores. As her mother weeps over her limp and hive-speckled body, it seems inevitable that the contagion will take more lives. "Perhaps we can vaccinate?" says the Captain, "at the very least we can recommend precautions to prevent the disease spreading."
803365: Have the ship's doctor produce a vaccine
803366: Such a well-prepared vaccination programme will cost... Your expert doctor adapts an effective preparation in the circumstances, using up a fair quantity of the ship's medical supplies in the process. One of the officers wonders if you shouldn't receive something back for all this charity...
803370: The locals see no other choice but to accept— anything to prevent the epidemic your doctors have so gravely forecast. Your crew readily receive their offerings without stopping to consider the dubious ethics of such an exchange. After all, it was they who brought the sickness to this place!
803373: You recruit an aspiring doctor! With little debate, the locals agree to receive the vaccinations against smallpox, probably saving their lives in the process. It is perhaps a side-effect of the openness and apparent selflessness with which your own medics go about the task, that a local doctor is inspired to join your expedition.
803374: The doctor falls sick. You can only assume the attempted vaccine has failed the locals also, because two weeks into the onward journey, its creator is in the grip of smallpox. Once the disease sets in there is no cure, unless you choose to trust the poor doctor's survival to God.
803375: God will help where medicine cannot
803376: A brave few serve as guardian angels, praying, washing, comforting the doctor. The acrid smell of the pustules, so particular to smallpox, is soon masked by haloes of incense. After several weeks the doctor's fever goes down and the rashes become less pronounced. While no miracle— the skin will forever bear the scars— it does mean the doctor's survival.
803377: Smallpox spreads with a missionary zeal. Following the priest's foolish suggestion that the crew all visit the doctor to offer their prayers, it is hardly a surprise when a spate of new cases are reported. Three weeks after the doctor dies, others are just beginning to experience the first agonising symptoms. Had your crew heartlessly abandoned the doctor, it would surely have been the better option.
803379: With regret, the doctor must be marooned. Men in gloves carry a stretcher up the beach beyond the tideline to a place in the shade where it seems likely the doctor will live out a few more days. "Fresh air might revive you," says one optimistically, but already the doctor has no strength to reply.
803381: The instructions are followed to the letter. The local people have never come into contact with smallpox before, but agree to adopt your measures against it. Your crew need reminding too; mouths covered when coughing, the avoidance of skin contact, and the frequent washing of hands in alcoholic solution. It is chastening that your mere presence has caused the death of that poor girl, but after two weeks without further cases, it is certainly a relief it does not appear to have spread.
803382: Your people find it impossible to get the message across. The locals go about their business as usual, disregarding the strictures you have tried to put in place. Sensing the coming epidemic, and as fears for the health of your own crew mount, it may be time just to leave...
803384: Saved by a cow with cowpox. Your doctors remember that the "vacca" of vaccination means cow, and extract cowpox from the pustuled udders of a local beast. Everyone receives the injection, which due to the lack of appropriate facilities the doctor is unable to purify. Fortunately this only results in a number of outbreaks of other, much less destructive infections.
803385: Things take a severe turn for the worse... Your doctors have little idea what they are doing, and their extraordinary decision to use a sample from the pustules on the poor dead girl to create their vaccine only accelerates the spread. In desperation, those still in health agree to board the expedition ship and escape while they still can.
803386: Leave as quickly as you can
803387: Smallpox has wiped out entire civilisations. That is the pervading anxiety as the expedition prepares for hasty departure. The locals seem unaware of the danger, perhaps thinking the death of the young girl an isolated case. Before leaving, one of your scribes grimly documents the customs and traditions of these peoples in case it should have to serve as the sole record of their having existed.
803388: You can choose to sell your vaccine to the locals
803390: "They say the isle of the dead is not dead at all; that a bone legion guards its secrets..." The rock that dominates the island looks like a skull — at least, if you squint and tilt your head. Marrow-pink stone rises a hundred and fifty feet above the forest, pitted with lofty caves that could be mistaken for a multitude of eyes. The dark scar of a mouth at its base could lead somewhere rewarding, if indeed, you are brave enough to delve....
803391: "Those stories you loved as a child — this is your chance to be part of one."
803392: "People in those stories had the chance to turn back, yet they never did. A spirit of adventure kept them going — and that is something we explorers should have in spades!” Galvanized, the crew agree to enter the caves. In this underworld, where day lives in permanent exile, lamps are lit but die by turns; suffocated by forces ageless and unseen. Your men hesitate to light them again; "The old light burns the eyes of the deathless," a voice whispers, "it will anger them."
803393: Ask them to trust in the person ahead to find a way forward
803394: Their conviction in one another is soon rewarded. The air thins, and a soft greenish light grows out of the darkness. Before long, a cavern has opened up before them. Fingers of limestone glisten up towards the aperture from which that faint and unnatural light gently falls, shining like a spot lamp upon the large stone sarcophagus that weighs at the cavern's centre, sealed firmly shut. It is marked with the words "Here lieth Ernesto Barragán, king of skull and bone."
803396: The mighty lid topples off revealing a sensational treasure! Your party have shown remarkable strength, and now delight in having cheated the wretched pirate Barragán and his followers in death. "No rest for the wicked!" the captain chuckles, though the adage may just as well apply to his own crew. "Gather what ye may and let us leave this foetid boneyard behind."
803397: The sarcophagus won't budge, but your expedition leaves the isle of death with their pride intact. "The unnatural cold was enervating..." one officer is quick to clarify, "...and those who built that tomb in honour of this ancient king of bone clearly meant it to last unto eternity, so determinedly was it sealed."
803398: Blow it open with a bomb
803399: A buccaneer's hoard! The detonation goes off with a pleasing muffled thud, thanks to the care taken when packing the bomb. "Ha-ha!" the captain rasps with glee, "Pirate kings be damned!" Through the fissure the dynamite cleaves comes a first glimpse of the sarcophagus' sensational gilded interior, and the many riches within!
803400: The bomb creates chaos! Loosely packed, and poorly positioned, the amateurish bomb brings the whole roof down. When the cloud, zinging with debris, finally clears, fallen rock is discovered to have sealed the tomb for all eternity. Though the crew leave empty-handed, the experience will have done them no harm.
803401: Lack of belief forces your party to retreat. The chain suddenly stops moving forward, and the echoes of a disagreement at its head filter back. "Snap out of it! Keep moving!" "But sir, I swear, that thing had no eyes! I won't move another step!" Despite their efforts to continue, the feeling your party are trespassing only intensifies, and they depart the dreaded rock, drained and deeply perturbed.
803402: It's only the wind and damp, light the lamps again!
803403: Your party's craft is rewarded, albeit not with the fountains of gold they had anticipated. The lamps are first cleaned and supplied with new wicks and fuel, before being relit and carefully shielded from the wind. The fractured cavity is exposed — adorning its bone-white walls, a pictoral history of the career of the mighty pirate Barragán, who once made this imposing rock his refuge. Feeling enlightened, the expedition leaves with a spring in its step.
803404: The smoke and soot force your party to retreat! While the refuelled lamps now remain lit, an excess of kerosene in the mixture produces dirty clouds that fill the lungs and sting the eyes. All further investigation of the skull's interior comes to an abrupt halt over fears the smoke may have done the expedition's health some permanent damage.
803405: The expedition party seem all the more doubtful."Children's stories? Is that the best we've got? And besides, it's precisely this sort of unchecked curiosity that brought the heroes of those stories so much trouble!"
803406: "Surely the promise of treasure outweighs mere superstition?"
803407: Your diplomat rattles off a fine argument. "Which is more likely? That an army of the dead protects that treasure, or that pirates invented the fable to scare adventurers like us from stealing it?" Galvanized, the crew agree to enter the caves. In this underworld, where day lives in permanent exile, lamps are lit but die by turns, suffocated by forces ageless and unseen. Your men hesitate to light them again; "The old light burns the eyes of the deathless," a voice whispers, "it will anger them."
803408: Your officer's argument is bare bones, his voice increasing in pitch with the realisation that it falls on deaf ears. In desperation, he lays a hand on the first mate's shoulder, whereupon the debate is resolved with a punch to the face. "I thought he'd never shut up!" someone laughs ― but after this episode, humour is likely to be in short supply.
803409: "We're going in. You don't have a choice..."
803410: The crew pull themselves together and enter the cave — a bit of a grilling from the expedition's most intimidating officer has done the trick. The cave is dank and stifling. In this underworld, where day lives in permanent exile, lamps are lit but die by turns; suffocated by forces ageless and unseen. Your men hesitate to light them again; "The old light burns the eyes of the deathless," a voice whispers, "it will anger them."
803411: The first mate's threats are weak, and any punishment would be better than facing an army of skeletons as far as the crew are concerned. "If... if you refuse... you will be whipped, do you hear? I don't like doing it, but I will if I have to!" The crew laugh, "Admit it sir, you don't even want to go into that skull yourself!" With the first mate's authority undermined, confidence in the expedition's leadership reaches a new low.
803412: Treasures and bone armies?! What nonsense!
803413: The crew are sad to have passed up an adventure. At first it's a relief, of course, not to have to confront a giddy army of bone sailors, whom if tales be true, are holed up within that skull-like rock, perhaps swigging spectral rum and grinding their teeth over the life they spent as flesh and blood. Perhaps. But what would your men know? They were never there.
803415: Give up. It's clear your crew are no heroes.
803416: The crew are sad to have passed up an adventure. At first it's a relief, of course, not to have to confront a giddy army of bone sailors, whom if tales be true, are holed up within that skull-like rock, perhaps swigging spectral rum and grinding their teeth over the life they spent as flesh and blood. Perhaps. But what would your men know? They were not there.
803418: Delicious desecration! What better way to enliven this truly oppressive place? As the fuse is expended, there seems a longer-than-expected pause... only for the boom to sound all the mightier. "Ha-ha!" the captain rasps with glee, "Pirate kings be damned!" Through the fissure the dynamite cleaves comes a first glimpse of the sarcophagus' sensational gilded interior, and the many riches within!
803424: You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
803425: You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
803426: You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
803427: You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
803428: You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
803429: You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
803430: You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
803431: You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
803432: You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
803433: You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
803434: You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
803435: You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
803437: It is no coincidence that the trail of roses left in Her Majesty's wake has ended in this pretty continental town. But what could have caused her to cross a narrow sea, poppy-flecked fields, and mythical river valleys? She has not simply waltzed over for the ambience — this is the heartland of her maternal family line, and she is here with a purpose.
803438: She's a Queen, there must be a sign of her somewhere...
803439: A nearby castle or country residence — of course! "Eliminate all other factors, and what remains is the truth," as the sleuths say — the Queen would never be content to stay in town. Calculating you are no more than two days behind the Queen's retinue, you're able to draw a circle on a map that encompasses only a handful of suitably regal stopovers. It is now but a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...
803441: Use your knowledge of the royal family to make a guess
803443: Your familiarity with the Teutonic dynasties stands you in good stead. Whispers at home are growing ever louder on the subject of the Queen's suitors, and her cousin Ernest seems to be one of the front-runners. You visit the outspoken prince consort at his ivy-clad burg, and having presented a letter Sir Archibald gave you, he nods and leads you through its low, rib-vaulted ceilings, past gilt-candelabras and canvas portraits. Though cordial, Prince Ernest seems a little twitchy.

The crew agree to draw lots. A scrawny man gets the shovel, and clears the snow to reveal Braine's face, who might look asleep but for his skin of leather. In his pocket, there is a letter to his wife.
"Dearest Elaine,
I've few breaths left. I die never having found the Passage — but then, no glory awaits any servant of Sir John. He was certain the ice would not thicken around us in the spring. The fate of the expedition now rests on circumnavigation of Terrier Island by short, perilous west shore, or by long, open east channel. I fear I know what Sir John will prefer.
Farewell, my Elaine."
803928:
A mere hundred metres from the graves, the men discover the remains of a camp at which the lost expedition wintered. They built a cairn — a small stack of stones — under which a tin cylinder containing a tightly-rolled letter is found. "They left a note of their progress," says the Captain. Lady Faithful recognises her husband's writing immediately.
"May 28th, 1847 { H.M. ships 'Styx' and 'Hades' wintered in the ice lat. 70˚ 05' N; long. 98˚ 23' W. Previously wintered in 1846-7 at Baffling Island, lat. 74˚ 43' 28" N; long. 91˚ 39' 15" W, after having sailed Wailing Channel to lat. 77˚, and returned by the west side of Cornell Island. Total loss by deaths to date: 3 men due to sickness — Braine, Gore and Seeley, God rest their souls. Leaving tomorrow for Terrier Island. Aim to reach Passage by end of June; we must be close now. John Faithful, Commander, HMS Styx."
