Beyond Tchilling Sound, the seaway divides. To the west lies a chain of small islands separated by partially melted ice. To the south: a long, dark headland crowned with snow that hazes out of sight.
803934: As you near the coast, a large human construction delineates itself, "Most probably an abandoned trading post of the Huddlesome Bay company." It leans hard into the wind, its once red boards now scoured pale. If Sir John and his crew came this way, they would likely have stopped here. "How are we going to get there, sir?" says the ship's boy. He has noticed that an ice sheet lies between your ship and the trading post.
803935: Take the safest route by avoiding the cracks
803936: Your crew's instincts are solid. Keeping just the right distance apart, they move at a purposeful speed, avoiding the cracks and dark splodges indicative of thinner ice. They reach the abandoned building without incident.
803937: Their knowledge is shaky. One of your groups avoids the gaping holes, but fails to notice the darker patches of thin ice. Cracking can be heard, but none of the group dare move. They hit the water with a woosh as the brûlée snaps. It is freezing, and they'll struggle to climb out on their own. If not rescued quickly, they'll die of hypothermia.
803938: Haul the sailors out with a rope
803939: The rope team keep balance. Lying down, and spreading out to distribute their weight, they throw ropes to those in the water, who thrash to bind themselves under their armpits. On a count of three, they are hoisted clear of the water. Wet and chattering with cold, your expedition takes refuge in the old trading post.
803940: Forget strength, what they needed was teamwork. The rope team disregard their own safety and pull as they would on dry land. The ice was never going to hold, and it soon collapses beneath them. Some manage to crawl free of the water and save themselves, but others slip away to fertilise the ocean bed. The survivors trudge for the thin comforts of the disused trading post.
803942: They make it. They're okay! The survivors are cheered across the line in a spirit akin to the finish of a cross-country race at school back home. Nobody left behind then, and nobody left behind now. Wet and chattering with cold, your expedition takes refuge in the abandoned building, offering up prayers of gratitude.
803943: To those in the water the encouragement sounds noticeably strained. Convulsing as they slip down between part-frozen cuboids, their resolve fades with the voices, the light above ever more distant. Knowing they could have done more, the survivors trudge on for the thin comforts of the disused trading post.
803944: Measure the thickness of the ice
803945: The ship's carpenters improvise with a rotary drill. It takes a fair bit of effort to get it turning, suggesting the ice is pretty solid. The first measurement is 11 inches — no hazard even for a sizeable group to pass over. Every few steps a new reading is taken, but it proves a mere formality, since the readings change very little. They make the abandoned building without incident.
803946: It was never going to work, using a heavy, blunt instrument to make the hole. Lucky as it happens that the carpenter is alone when his sledgehammer comes down, as it sunders the ice all about him and casts him into the freezing water. Turns out the ice is fairly thick, but that won't save the poor fellow now. The others trudge on for the thin comforts of the disused trading post in disbelief.
803948: The inevitable splosh. Despite the cold wind, it is still summer in the Arctic, and the weight of a large group of bodies would test thicker ice than this. Halfway across the sheet, there is a rasping crack, and your men are deposited into the water. In their struggle to escape they have to kick off their snow boots. Chattering, they make it to the thin comfort of the abandoned trading post with their feet in a terrible state.
803949: Resume the expedition under clearer skies...
803951: "At least it's a shelter," the Captain remarks. The men shut the doors on the wind, to find the building interior licked with frost. Rusted hooks hang from the beams, relics of the short-lived fur trade. "Comforts are few and far between out here. I doubt Sir John would have passed it by." There must be some evidence of the lost expedition here.
803952: Search for signs of recent use
803953: No sign at all. Undisturbed in ten years or more, these cabins are just as they were when the traders left. There should be prints in the dust, objects out of place, but there aren't. Everyone concedes it is very unlikely Sir John's expedition came this way.
803954: Find information about the local area
803955: Something to go on at least. Whoever the fur traders were, they left in a rush. Papers and maps are strewn about, some trodden and sodden into mush, a precious few dry and intact. Dockets are found relating to consignments received from a nearby Inuit settlement named Ivujivik, which also happens to be marked on a fragment of map. "The Inuit are sure to have noticed anyone passing through," says the Captain, "we should visit them."
803956: Go back and head west to Baffling Island
803957: Continue south toward the Inuit settlement of Ivujivik
803959: Over The Ice To Huddlesome Bay
803960: The crew return to the ship. Once at Tchilling Sound, they head west.
803961: The crew mark the position of the Inuit settlement of Ivujivik on the map, and set sail.
803962:
The route to the Inuit settlement of Ivujivik is a two day trek by foot across exposed ice flats. A small expedition party set off, leaving the rest at sea to await their return.
Although the going is tough, it is not that which preoccupies the crew. As night falls, they are sure something has been following them.
803963: Stop for the night and keep watch
803964: Your sharp-eared watchman keeps vigil. In the small dark of the Arctic summer, he catches the scratch of a bear's unretractable claws on ice. It is trying to approach discretely, but the watchman is ready. At the sound of his gun the rest wake with a jolt, only to find a big dead bear at his feet. They celebrate their trophy, and are soon back en route to Ivujivik.
803965: A mother polar bear! Your watchman isn't used to such long days, struggling to keep his eyes open beside the hypnotic fire. A loud growl. Mother bear digs her claws deep into his spine and drags him away. Moments later, she is back for more!
803967:
Years of ambush drills pay off. Quickly forming a circle, your men level their guns into the half-light. Sensing the danger they pose, mama bear grows more cautiously, and after a single circuit of your camp, disappears out of sight.
Full of adrenaline, your scout party reach the Inuit camp.
803968: Hands trembling with fear, the men grab for their rifles, but mama bear smells their nerves and is upon them. Finally, someone gets a shot away, and though it misses, it scares her momentarily. Her white coat is lank with the blood of several men. Those still standing flee. The Inuit are startled when your party arrive at Ivujivik the next afternoon looking especially bedraggled.
803969: Use cunning to trick the bear
803970: Your men know they have to stand tall to face down a polar bear, and waving their coats above their heads like flags, they succeed in driving the bear away. Full of adrenaline, your scout party reach the Inuit camp.
803971: Mama bear looks angry. Your men had assumed that staring might make her back down, but she has taken it as a display of aggression. Her white coat is soon lank with the blood of several men. Those still standing flee. The Inuit are startled when your party arrive at Ivujivik the next afternoon looking especially bedraggled.
803972: Continue to walk despite being cold and exhausted
803973:
The men are strong and dedicated. They tramp through the half hour of pitch-black darkness normally reserved for sleep, keeping good pace. Whatever was following them has soon given up. Gazing upwards, the party find themselves to be lucky observers of the aurora borealis.
They reach the Inuit settlement the following lunchtime with a sense of wonder.
803974: One of the men struggles to keep up with his unsympathetic comrades. He is the runt, the weakest of the pack, and the polar bear knows it. The rest of the group hear a piercing scream, followed by the sound of crunching and tearing. Moments later mama bear is bounding across the snow towards them, hungry for more!
803977: Ivujivik is a semi-permanent settlement. The Inuit appear worried, but nevertheless offer your men every hospitality, inviting them into a large iglu where they are served a hearty Suaasat— a meat stew— under the silent gaze of what feels like the whole village. A girl, Tapeesa, is able to translate, and the others warm up when they hear the story of your journey over the ice flats. Soon the subject turns to Sir John's lost expedition. Tapeesa shows you items that look like they belonged to the missing men.
803978: Offer to trade for the relics
803979: They were strange men. Who doesn't want to eat when they've been out in the cold...?
803980: Silver cutlery embossed with the names Hades and Styx. These are from Sir John's expedition ships! There are also cufflinks belonging to Sir John engraved with assorted marsupials, and a knife handle with the emblem of the Arctic council. Tapeesa says that about a year ago, some men came wanting to know about channels through the ice, and traded their things for information. She points to the west coast of Terrier Island on your map.
803981: Ask how they got hold of them
803982: Tapeesa patiently explains that they traded with men like yours about a year ago. The men wanted to know about channels through the ice, and traded their things for information. She points to the west coast of Terrier Island on your map.
803984: Decline, and ask how they got them.
803986:
Text for sandbox event.
Crew marches.
The march is tiresome but quickly it's not the efforts which preoccupy the crew. They have the strange feeling something is following them. Night falls.
803987: Stop for the night and organize watches
803988: Despite his exhaustion, the guard keeps his sharpness and notices the sound of soft paws on the snow. The beast tried to be discrete but the hunter is already ready. As soon as he has it in range, he shots, a precise shot in the head. The bear collapses on the floor. The rest of the men are woken up with a jolt. When they realize what happened, they praise the hunter for saving their lives. The group is now closer than ever. They left the ship as companions and reach the Inuit camp as friends.
803989: After such a long walk, the guard has a hard time keeping his eyes opened. He starts to drowse by the fire. It takes a strong growl behind for him to realize the danger, a polar bear!, but it is too late. The beast's claws rip a poor mate and dig as deep as his rib cage. In one scream he is dead. It then turns toward the rest of the group.
803990: Shot before the bear attacks again
803991: It takes extreme dexterity to seize the rifle, charge it, aim and shot before the bear has time to charge another man. With a single shot in the head, the bear collapses, growling.</br>Still breathing rapidly from fear and adrenaline, the crew reaches the Inuit camp.
803992: The hands trembling with fear, the man tries to seize his riffle on the floor, drops it, seize it again, charges it but has no time to aim before the bear leaps on him and tears him down. As the beast is busy with their companion, the rest of the group runs toward what appears to be a fire a few hundred meters away. It's an Inuit camp, rush into the safety of one of the hut as the local stare at them, startled. The bear doesn't seem to have followed.
803993: Make yourself look like a threat
803994: The men stand tall, take objects next to them to appear bigger, approach the bear to intimidate him and show they don't fear it. The bear buys it and runs away, his preys have become predators.</br>Still breathing rapidly from fear and adrenaline, the crew reaches the Inuit camp.
803995: Look in the eyes to appear as if they are not afraid but the bear is not intimated, it takes it as a sign of aggression. The men, trembling, appear to be no match for the beast. It charges and rip one of the men to pieces. As the beast is busy with their companion, the rest of the group runs toward what appears to be a fire a few hundred meters away. It's an Inuit camp, rush into the safety of one of the hut as the local stare at them, startled. The bear doesn't seem to have followed.
803996: Continue to walk despite the cold and the exhaustion
803997: The men are strong and determined. They continue walking for hours under pitch darkness, keeping a nice pace. The walk turns marvellous as the men become the lucky observers of aurora borealis under a stellar sky hindered by no lights. </br>They reach the Inuit camp in the early morning.
803998: In the dead of the night the group is more and more scattered as one of the men has a harder time following. He falls behind. This is the moment the beast chooses to target the weakest of the pack. The group hears a muffled sound, a piercing screams and horrible growling mixed with tearing and chewing noises. As the group turns toward the noise in terror, they see an enormous polar bear.
804000: Your ship is stranded on an iceberg! It is night along the east coast of Terrier Island. The meek light of your vessel seems to dissolve into the moonless blackness. Even at easy sail and under constant vigil, your ship runs the risk here, for slumbering ice giants leer from the darkness in all directions. "Dead ahead!" comes the cry, but it's too late! A low growl shakes the boat, as a wave dumps it atop a iceberg — in the shape of an upturned molar — beaching it there. The ship is undamaged, if only it could be returned to the water...
804002: Nothing in nature can prevail against human endeavour, it would seem. The crew watch with trepidation as the fuses burn down to the stick, before an ear-splitting series of detonations rings across the vastness, sundering the icy claws that had held your ship hostage. A small blizzard of debris blankets the deck, to the delight of all aboard, for they are free once more!
804004: Ice crumbles around such firepower. Any cannon that can be swiveled at the target is put to use, chipping away at the icy dungeon in which the ship has become wedged, until the vessel breaks free. Like a cheerful sea lion, the fair vessel slips down an escarpment and plops back into the water. The crew cheer and continue on their way.
804005: The iceberg fights back. Though the way is almost clear, the relentless cannonfire seems to have woken the ogre below, and to the horror of the crew the vast iceberg rolls slightly to one side. Great shards of ice detach and bounce over the deck, injuring your men. Quick action is needed.
804006: Get out and push the ship free
804007: Your men live for such challenges, and scarcely need telling what to do. Leaping down from the boat, they get behind her, knotting guy ropes as fast as they can. The iceberg still rumbles ominously, but it is your quick-thinking crew who prevail. Once clear of the ice field, the crew will be able to treat their wounds.
804008: It's an uphill struggle. The pitching of the unstable iceberg does not help one jot, as the men tumble and slide as they struggle to find their grip. Such is the effort required to pull the ship successfully down from the iceberg into the sea, no-one notices that one of the teams is missing. It appears they have fallen through a thin part of the ice to their deaths.
804009: Let the rolling iceberg toss you into the sea.
804010: Your ship performs a rather messy dismount. After its initial roll, the iceberg halts long enough to suggest it wants to stay in its new position — but then everything happens all at once. The iceberg spins violently, and the ship with it! The ship strikes the water at such an angle that serious damage is done to much of the lee-side. Fortunately, the crew emerge unharmed.
804011: Build something to help you escape
804012: The crew assembles a dozen hardy levers to free the ship. Flexible hickory planking is cut and reshaped into wedges, before being inserted into the ice at intervals of five paces, until they surround the stern. On a count of three the men lift — and to their surprise, so does the hull! Once it starts moving, there's no stopping it, and it clatters through all icy obstructions to the sea. Your sailors embrace — they have been very resourceful.
804013: The wrong wood is selected for the task. It is a decorative mahogany veneer, stripped from the Captain's cabin. "Whatever it takes," the Captain says with laudable magnanimity, but the whole business is futile. Despite the wedges being placed in great number at the stern of the ship, no amount of pressure from the crew can encourage the ship to move, since the levers lack the requisite spring. They'll need to find another way off this iceberg.
804014: Search for Sir John along the east coast
804015:
Free of the iceberg, the crew manage to circumvent Terrier Island via its easterly shore. However, they have found no trace of the lost expedition. You'll have to try the west coast, next.
Sir John must have taken the risky option.
804017: The west coast of Terrier Island is snaggled up with monstrous horns of ice. Navigation is going to be tricky. Will the narrows lead back once more to open water, or will your ship end up stuck? You can navigate carefully, get a better view of the channels from a nearby rock, or send scouts ahead in rowboats to see.
804018: Find a path through the narrows
804019:
To their relief, your crew reach the open sea on the other side. As there is a lack of consensus on magnetic north at this time, your navigators decide to ignore the compasses and trust their instincts, saving them a collision on more than one occasion.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804020: The compass readings are confusing. After several wrong turns, the crew realise magnetic north is not where they — or where anyone else imagined. Your ship finds itself alongside the run-off of a sizeable glacier, which, as it's spring, is melting. There are cracks, then an almighty rumble as the entire wall of ice threatens to separate and topple into the water!
804022:
Your crew escape! In mere moments, the masts are dropped almost horizontal to catch every last ounce of wind, giving you just, just enough extra speed to avoid the mountain of ice that comes crashing down into the channel. Waves from this rare natural event form a new avenue, leading out into the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804023:
Your crew escape! The engine room takes the initiative ahead of the orders from the bridge and stoke the fires. The ship picks up just, just enough extra speed to avoid the mountain of ice crashing down into the channel. Waves from this rare natural event form a new avenue leading out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804024:
Your navigators panic. Though the sails catch the breeze, the men fail to adjust course out from under the falling wall. Blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. A death and several injuries result. The rest are lucky that large waves from the icefall form a new avenue leading out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804025:
They are too close to the falling ice wall. Your engines are fired up but the resulting turn is not a sharp one. Blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. A death and several injuries result. You are lucky that giant waves from the icefall form an avenue of escape out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804028:
"Ha! Let it rain!" the captain bellows, as blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. Your powerful vessel surges through to safety! Waves from the icefall form a new avenue leading out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804029:
Your ship is no icebreaker. There are cries as blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. A death and several injuries result. You are lucky that giant waves from the icefall form an avenue of escape out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804030: Send men up the slope for a better view
804031:
The men are used to hard climbs like these and are up in no time to survey the labyrinth ahead. They report back with an easy route forward that leads to open sea once more.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804032: Your men say the climb is too steep, or at least, no-one is daredevil enough to attempt it with the limited equipment they have. Everyone is exasperated. You must find another solution.
804033: Send scouts ahead in rowboats to check
804034:
Follow the seals, that's the answer! Seals and more besides. From their rowboats your scouts are even able to follow a baleen whale as she surfaces for air. She leads them to open water, and your expedition ship follows.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
804035: No-one returns with a definitive clue. "Ivory gulls were circling above what looks like a large glacier," says one, "it may lead us to open water..." It's the best you've got, but soon your ship finds itself alongside the run-off of a sizeable glacier, which it being spring, is melting. There are cracks, then there is an almighty rumble as the entire wall of ice threatens to separate and topple into the water!
804038: The ship is now headed for the west coast of Terrier Island. The crew hope to find Sir John and his men soon, and pray no more obstacles will be thrown in their way.
804039: The ship is now headed for the east coast of Terrier Island. The crew hope to find Sir John and his men soon, and pray no more obstacles will be thrown in their way.

804061: The sea on the West coast of Labrador island is covered in ice. There is almost no space for navigation through really narrow channels and the water movements have pushed glaciers several meters up. The channels might really lead to open water again or end up getting the ship stuck in the ice. The captain is unsure what would be the best course to take.
804062: Try to find the right path across the narrow channels
804063: The captain is a true master of the Arctic. He compensates for the inaccuracy of the compass due to the closeness of the magnetic pole with a strong knowledge of the stars positions in this part of the world. He analyses the shapes of the glaciers and the position of the channels to deduce which routes has the most change to have an opening onto the sea. Take it, within a few hours the open sea is in sight.
804064: With the magnetic pole being so close, the navigation instruments are not reliable anymore. The captain can only rely on his sense of orientation to pick the channels which should lead to the open sea. Unfortunately the one he picked just hugs high instable glacier with no open sea in sight. Suddenly rumble, at starboard the glacier just under which the crew is about the pass by starts to collapse.</br></br>Crew action cause the glacier?
804065: Increase speed to pass before the glacier collapses
804066: Increase speed to pass before the glacier collapses
804067: Open all the sail in a swift movement, the crew are professional and well prepared. The ship speed increases at once and they manage to pass the glacier before it collapses. The great wave created by the glacier falling into the water expands greatly the channels and push the ice aside. Road to the open sea is now clear.
804068: The crew mobilizes immediately to push the steam engine, organizing the coal transportation efficiently and taking advantage of the propeller to push the ship forward at the exact right moment before the glacier collapses.</br>The great wave created by the glacier falling into the water expands greatly the channels and push the ice aside. Road to the open sea is now clear.
804069: Are disorganized, do they actually know how to pen the sails in a emergency situation? The ship is right under the glacier as it collapses.</br>Sailors crushed by the ice.  The glacier falling in the water created a huge wave, clearing the channel but putting the ship in danger.</br></br>Hurt, wouynded sailor fall into the sea, open sea is on sight
804070: Bad steam engine usage. Sailors crushed by the ice.  The glacier falling in the water created a huge wave, clearing the channel but putting the ship in danger.
804071: Steer the ship toward port and count on the hull to break the ice
804072: The ship is strong and breaks the ice. The ship gets away from the glacier just in time before it collapses. The great wave created by the glacier falling into the water expands greatly the channels and push the ice aside. Road to the open sea is now clear.
804073: The ship is no icebreaker. The bow is damaged but it's nothing compared to the men injured by the blocks of ice falling on the deck. The glacier falling in the water created a huge wave, ppeople fall, sad.
804074: Send men to climb the glacier to have a better view
804075: Strong men, manage to get to the top of the glacier without too much difficulty, just using ropes and ice pick. Once on top, they are so much higher than the ship that the right way ahead is clear. Note environment clue, map the route to take and go back to the ship. Lead the ship without trouble to the open sea.
804076: Climbing a glacier is no task for the weak and untrained. The sailors are not up for the task and keep slipping down. Soon, exhausted, they must admit another solution needs to be found.
804077: Send patrols to follow the channels in order to indicate the right ones
804078: The men are effective, restricting the channels worth pursuing to only one considering the water flow and noticing which the seals stride more, hence indicating which should lead to the open sea. Following the chosen channel over a few kilometres, their assumptions prove right. They go back to the ship to send the crew down the right path.
804079: They were told to follow the channels so just do that. The men do not try to identify which is most likely to be the right one and disperse in smaller groups to cover as much ground as possible. Many days are lost waiting for all the patrols to come back empty-handed, unable to follow the channels to an end (more focus on their lack of ability to follow the channel, cant traverse the land, give up too early). The ship captain is forced to pick a channel randomly. Unfortunately the one he picked just hugs high instable glacier with no open sea in sight. Suddenly rumble, at starboard the glacier just under which the crew is about the pass by starts to collapse.
804080: It is clumsy. Out of breath and struggling weakly against a strong current, your divers bludgeon blindly at the coral, sending clouds of particles up through the water. Little do they realise how fragile the hull has become. With one misplaced blow, it implodes, and the water comes gushing in. The crew must count themselves lucky that the tide proceeds to sweep the unhappy vessel to the shore. It seems you have shipwrecked on a coral atoll.
804082: Your diver takes to the sea like a fish to water, having ample experience. Still, the others worry when after five or six minutes, he still has yet to surface. Suddenly, the boat begins to wobble — it has been cut free! Soon after, your hero emerges from the water giddy and glistening — and brandishing some magnificent coral in their hands.
804083: The accident with the coral reef as left the expedition shipwrecked on an atoll. For a time your crew feel like children again — dancing along the sand and bathing in the sun, as they await a verdict on the damaged hull. When it comes, the news is not good: an extensive repair is needed, and with supplies so short, there is considerable disagreement. Why concentrate on repairs, given how long that may take, when you could scout for food and water.
804121: Search on other side of island
804141: The first severe blizzard. You've only just caught sight of the Baffling Island littoral when the headwind suddenly whips up, and a dark fringe of cloud appears in the heavens. All take cover below deck, as rock-hard pellets of ice begin to pelt the ship with such force as to cause lasting damage. "We've lost control of her," screams the navigator, but it'd take a hero to go back out into that.
804143: The thrill-seeking diver relishes the task. Covering themselves in bear fat and brandishing a sharp pick, they enter the water without a splash, resurfacing no more than five minutes later to the embrace of a pre-warmed towel. "All clear!" your diver says. Cheers go up below at the sound of the engines at full power once more.
